description:
This is my favorite sushi place in SF. I've been here twice in one week and it's been so delicious every time. The rolls are super unique, not stuff you would find at other sushi places. I especially recommend the Golden State Roll- I got it both times I went. Their fish tastes fresh and the cuts are thicc. 

The environs is casual but boujee. The restaurant is small so there isn't much seating, which means that if you don't have a reservation, you will have to wait a while. I came both times Friday night and had to wait around 20 to 40 minutes. The staff is also pretty busy so it sometimes takes a while to get something. The food is so good though that I don't care about that stuff.  

BOI I AM COMING BACK FOR SURE. But I would maybe recommend takeout instead, since like I said the place is very small and often crowded.
author: Brittany H.

description:
This is the most unsatisfied I've been after Sushi.... I'm so sad!! We got four different rolls and didn't really like any of them. They all sounded so cool and different and ended up being bland and dry. We got the lava golden state, and two special rolls one with pumpkin tempura and the spicy omega or something. 
There wasn't much fish in any roll. So don't expect to be filled up. Usually the three of us are full off of three rolls and we had four and were still so hungry we went around the corner and bought MORE food at a better place. Never in my LIFE have I done that. 


Service was friendly so I added a star but honestly that was the least satisfying $80 I've spent.
author: Hayley G.

description:
I've lived in SF for 10 years. I came here for a spontaneous last meal before I move. I made a resy for 1 on open table for the same day for 8:45pm. 

I had to wait about 5 minutes to be seated at the bar. People were very personable. After seeing my name on the reservation I was greeted by name for the rest of the evening. 

Even when sitting at the bar, you apparently still order with a waitress than with the sushi chefs. I couldn't read the daily specials on the board and was provided an iPad of a picture so I could see it more clearly. I did ask the waitress for an opinion on a tofu dish, but she either didn't understand what I was asking or didn't know. But told me to choose whatever I was craving and didn't have a recommendation. 

I ended up ordering the "spicy" tofu salad. Don't get this. It's basic lettuce with slices of tofu that has a spicy seasoning. But they don't season each piece. They stack them then season them. So only what is showing gets seasoned. But that was my fault thinking at a sushi place I should get some greens with my meal. Also, it's not spicy. 

I did get hamachi, ikura, salmon belly, otoro, and the uni from Japan. The sushi is very good for the price point. Is it the best sushi I've ever had? Not even close. But I knew that going in. It is very good tho! I heard from friends they're known more for their rolls. If I go back, I'll go with friends so I can order more stuff. 

But the sushi was well made. Fish was cut nicely, nice sizes. Sushi rice was a good texture and temperature. I would go again. 

I didnt like that all the sushi came out right when I had just gotten the tofu salad. But I didn't feel like I was rushed even tho I was eating at a later hour.
author: Jee Mee H.

description:
I'm really disappointed at how much O-Toro Sushi has gone downhill over the years. 

My co-worker wanted a Dragon Roll and I suggested that we should go to O-Toro Sushi because it's awesome.

Well, it's no longer awesome, it's terribly mediocre and looks like a handful of former customers feel the same way.

We shared a Lunch Combo Plate of Saba & Short Ribs ($16.75) which was fine but the rolls were a huge let down.

We ordered the Dragon Roll: crab, shrimp tempura, eel, avocado ($14.75) & O-Toro #2 Roll: asparagus tempura, seared toro ($16.95): https://bit.ly/2Lrt13F.

The Dragon Roll was meh. While I appreciate there wasn't too much filler rice, the unagi lacked that rich lushness. I'm not one for saucy rolls but it needed a drizzle of unagi sauce since its savory sweetness is more complementary than soy sauce.

The O-Toro #2 Roll was so WTF: https://bit.ly/2JlISjT. The toro was pulverzied and torched to extinction. Why even offer a roll topped with toro if you're going to torch it to death? Toro is not cheap but at least top it with thin slices and 86 the torch so customers can actually taste the toro. Or, add sufficient toro and increase the price. We basically paid $17 for a vegan roll. 

We went at opening so it wasn't busy but it took a while to receive our order and we sat at the window with fruit flies flying around. 

I returned to work and saw that their most recent health score is 79 which is scurrrry for a sushi bar. Eeeck. It's a good thing we didn't order anything raw.
author: Cherylynn N.

description:
Delicious! My 3 friends and I dined here on a Monday night at 6:30pm with a reservation and loved it. The rolls tasted fresh and I liked the menu options. We shared the golden gate, hip hop, and otoro rolls, which we'd all recommend. The tataki appetizer was a highlight too. 

One of our friends got the shoyu ramen, which was underwhelming. I'd say stick to the fish and sushi here. 

Service was friendly!
author: Emma W.

description: Dined here on a Saturday night with a reservation. The place is quite small and there was a long outside as we walked into the restaurant. However, we were seated right away and ordered our food. We ordered 4 rolls and grilled squid. Everything was good but there wasn't anything outstanding about this place either.
author: Nina Y.

description:
I heard San Francisco had good sushi so we went here for an early dinner with a reservation at 6 pm. We were seated right away.

I had the rainbow roll with alaskan crab, salmon and avocado roll, sake (salmon) sushi, and maguro (tuna) sushi. We got a bottle of Masumi sake and it was smooth like water, very easy to drink. Everything was high quality and fresh.

The food was great, service was great. I'd come back here when in San Francisco and craving high quality sushi.
author: Jess G.

description:
Kinda falling off. Tiny roll. Barely any fish in there. And got the golden gate roll is missing the salmon on top! 

Not coming back.
author: Jesse J.

description: This is a tapas bar, mainly. My friend and I came here to eat but were surprised to see it had a lot of shareables, which was fine by us. We must have ordered 6 tapas: beef, pumpkin croquettes, tuna, and multiple rolls. All of our dishes were delicious and rich in flavor. We also ordered sake which was fantastic. However, you have to spend quite a bit of money to get full. Some dishes come with literally 2 small pieces of fish for $20. So be prepared to spend some changeeeee
author: Elizabeth G.

description:
Eel: not that smoky, more flaky / fish-like than other unagi I've seen before, little teeny-tiny bones that interfere with the texture a little bit (not a choking hazard, but still get in the way). 

Salmon sushi: Rice was pleasantly sticky but too gingery for my tastes, fish was buttery, kind of melts in your mouth, and slightly salty. You can tell the fish is good quality, but it was sliced very thin and the rice overpowered the taste.

3.5 for food quality, but portions are on the small side (fancy restaurant alert!). The interior of the space was small but welcoming.

Ikura is salty style, very full
author: Nicole H.

description:
Loved the selection of sushi here. We arrived with just enough luck to snag the last table of four. The dinner rush immediately came in, and the wait seemed pretty long...

Meanwhile, we ordered what felt like half the menu of delicious sushi  

Do yourself a favor, order the seared salmon belly, otoro, uni (Santa Barbara is cheaper than the Hokkaido, so if your taste buds aren't attuned to the super subtle shifts in texture, skip the Hokkaido and get two of the Santa Barbara's)

We also got Kampachi sashimi, sea bream, the otoro roll (spicy toro, with mango), ikura, and salmon

And to make sure to round it out, we also got agedashi tofu, fried octopus, and seaweed salad 

Wash it down with a bottle of Junmai sake and you're golden

Yup, I'd definitely suggest you make a reservation and treat yo' self to some amazing sushi!
author: Camille S.

description: Friendly and inviting. Delicious menu. Great house sake, too!  Next time, I'll try the flight. Very reasonably priced.
author: Brian P.

description: The squid had zero flavor. The sushi rolls were tiny. Got the golden state roll and each roll was half the size of a regular roll. They also really really really skimped on the fish. Cant even tell if the fish was high quality since there wasnt much to eat inn each bite. I stopped ordering after the squid and one roll and went to another sushi restraunt. If I had continued to eat here, I would need probabaly 4-5 rolls to be full.
author: Diane Z.

description: So this place isn't bad, but it could be way better. I have to say the special sashimi and sushi is made 100x better than their rolls. I would recommend just skipping the rolls because the rice is not cooked correctly... it's mushy and inedible...
author: Toshi P.

description:
I guess this place is ok....if you've never had sushi before.  I realize it's hard to find a good sushi place these days that wont gouge your eyes out so O-toro is fine, fish quality is good and the place has a lot of items to order.

Pork belly - aight

Live scallop - NEVER, i repeat EVER, EVER MF EVER order this piece of shit.  They should really take this $20 item off their piece of shit specials menu and I can only blame myself for ordering this because I'm an idiot.  Want to see why I'm so mad? Order this and you'll find out.  

All the nigiri I got was fine.  Otoro, Trout, Eel, Sweet Shramp, Tuna but yea, I feel like there are plenty of sushi options in SF that are similar so this place is JUST PLAIN NORMAL
author: Vince L.

description: Jimmy the host is hands down the worst host in town. Should 100% not be in services. I walked in at 5pm, not one person in the restaurant.. he refused to seat me claiming I had to sit at the bar. No explanation, came off as a real jerk. Wouldn't know if the food is good, didn't get that far :(
author: David P.

description:
Otoro Sushi is a pretty good spot for fresh fish and small dishes. We've been meaning to come since we saw that this place is on the Michelin guide and recently got a dinner reservation. The food was great, around 4.5 for me.

It's easy to make reservations on OpenTable. The restaurant is really small so you definitely need to to avoid a long wait. It's a good spot for a romantic date. 

The menu consists of Japanese tapas, noodles, nigiri, sashimi and rolls. Be sure to check out their specials on the chalk board at the bar.

Service is painfully slow. It took forever to get seated even though we had a reservation. Seems like it's 1-2 people managing the entire restaurant which makes things pretty hectic. I felt bad for the waiter rushing around, but she did a good job at getting our food out promptly. She asked if it was okay to bring the noodles & dessert immediately after we ordered which was nice. I took my boyfriend here, we ordered around 9 dishes and it came out to $50 per person which was not bad. 

Caterpillar Roll - Eel, cucumber, avocado & tobiko. Pretty good! Wish there was more eel since the avocado and cucumber overpowered the flavor.

Chicken Udon - I really enjoyed this and wasn't expecting the udon to be that good! The chicken was really flavorful and tender. It came with mushrooms and seaweed. We really liked the broth and downed all of it. It was a good portion size to share. The only thing that I wasn't a fan of was how soft the noodles were.

Saba Shioyaki - Pretty standard mackerel. Comes in two pieces.

Lollipops Roll - Tuna, salmon, albacore and avocado wrap w/cucumber. This was a pretty unique option. It tasted a bit on the lighter end.

Yakitori 2 Skewers - Grilled chicken skewers. So delicious! This was probably one of the most memorable dishes of the night. They do chicken really well at Otoro.

Green Tea Cheesecake - We really enjoyed the execution of this dessert. Not too sweet per our liking. I'm usually not a fan of cheesecake but the matcha flavor was infused so well that I could hardly taste the cheese.

My boyfriend ordered the Hirame (Halibut), Sanma (Japanese Pike Fish) and the Madai (Sea Bream) specials nigiri. They all looked great, and he seemed to enjoy them. 

I heard the ramen here isn't that great so I'm glad we opted for the udon. I'd love to try this place for lunch since they have dishes like oyakodon and chirashi that aren't on the dinner menu.
author: Chelsea W.

description:
This is essentially a chill neighborhood sushi spot. I'd rate the overall quality of the fish and rice an 8 out of 10. 

I ordered 2 salmon & avocado rolls, cherry blossom roll, and salmon sashimi. Price came out to about $45, so considering this is San Francisco, I'd say it was a good bargain. 

Restroom was spacious and clean. It's a small place, so using OpenTable would be highly suggested, as you run the risk of a wait time. Service was sufficient.
author: K. A.

description:
I have this trick for eating mediocre sushi. You get yourself that big piece of candied ginger. Dunk it in soy sauce and lay it on the sushi. Say your sorryies to your tongue and put a nice round chunk of wasabi on that ginger. 

Now if you put that beautiful masterpiece you just created in your mouth, you will be hit, first by the 'subtle' wasabi which will bring tears to your eyes - only out of happiness of course. And then the sweet ginger as you chew more. Isn't that great? Well of course you'd also get some weird taste of rice and some random fishes plus maybe some avocado in the background. But who cares, amirite?

This is what I had to do in O-toro. When a restaurant can't get eel right, they have failed in my eyes. And the best thing about their miso ramen is that it wasn't too salty.
author: Ganesh K.

description:
A group of 4 came to O-Toro for dinner on a random Tuesday night. Reservations can be easily made via OpenTable.com 

The restaurant itself is pretty small so I would not recommend it for larger groups .The food here is decently tasty but very very expensive. The portion sizes are very small which makes it possibly sharable for 2 people, but very difficult for 4. For instance, we ordered a glazed cod, priced around $15-16, but it came out as one tiny piece which meant everyone had one bite. 

I think with other great japanese options around, I'd have to say O-Toro sushi didn't live it up to its hype. =/
author: Annie Z.

description: Affordable, large, and very tasty specialty rolls (sakura, dragon) make up for the mediocre otoro sashimi (felt watery and not fresh). They also skimped a little on the ginger, which in my opinion is very important and easy to get right. But definitely come here for the rolls.
author: Josh L.

description: This is hands down the best sushi in San Francisco, don't know who could possibly think differently. Get ready to get yummed.
author: Anna C.

description:
We tried this place one night after we recently moved to this neighborhood. 

Food: 

Miso Ramen -My boyfriend got the Miso Ramen which was not great but just OK. Granted, although being a Japanese restaurant, it's definitely not a ramen place, so we won't hold that against them. 

Mixed Tempura-The tempura was good , nothing special, just typical tempura.

Lava Special Roll & Hip Hop Special Roll - I am a sushi roll person. I really enjoyed these rolls. They weren't too small or overly riced. Would recommend

Lollipops Roll- My boyfriend really like these however I thought they were so-so. I've had sushi lollipops at other sushi restaurants which I enjoyed more.

Pork belly app: this was very flavorful and had good texture.

Ambience and Service: This place is quite small but we were able to get a seat at the bar without a reservation on a Friday night. The servers were extremely attentive, almost to the point of too much. I appreciate good service and being attentive however at some point, it becomes a disruption.

Unfortunately after this dinner, my stomach did NOT feel good. I have no reason to believe it was solely based on this food however I also have no reason to think it wasn't, as well. With all the other really good sushi places around, not sure if I'd come back to this place.
author: Katlyn H.

description: This place is OK. If you are out in SF and have a hankering for sushi and Japanese style tapas, this could be your place. That being said, there are better sushi places out there given the price point. We had several small bites including the wings, sunomono with taki, and grilled mackerel. We also tried the aji and sea bream nigiri. Everything was decent and the wait staff were friendly. However, after visiting places like Kirala (Berkeley), this place doesn't compare and charges you the same if not more. So, enjoy but don't expect much.
author: John N.

description: Came here for lunch with coworkers (I've been here previously for dinner and was completely underwhelmed) - this visit was also disappointing to say the the least. I think we just didn't order the right things... got a Chirashi bowl and the pieces of fish were super underwhelming (see pic) it had only one piece of mackerel, one piece of shrimp, 2 pieces of maguro, 2 pieces of salmon and 1 tamago. The fish were lackluster but the price we paid was way more than what the value actually was (20 bucks!) because I was not very satisfied with the meal, I decided to order 2 pieces of otoro nigiri which was ok but nothing out of this world. My meal came out to be 40 dollars, which I agree is my fault that I ordered an extra order of nigiri but I just wished that I was able to justify this spending. Next time I'll need to try the curry or udon or teriyaki bc my coworker raved about it!
author: Vanessa K.

description: The food here is outstanding.  We had a number of rolls, a chefs special roll, miso cod, wagyu beef and karage.  Service was also great!
author: Patrick J.

description:
Husband and I used to come here when we lived in the city. I remembered it being really good but after last weekend, not so much. We shared a bunch of sushi rolls which were just OK. The nigiri was expensive for what it was. I also got a weird vibe from this place. We sat by the bathroom/kitchen area and noticed that there were a ton of food that was ready to be served to customers but none of the servers even bother serving it? 15 minutes later the food was still there. I find that really weird. Like why don't you just bring it to the table? Not a big deal but I just find it weird that food was piling up and it was not being served to table. 

Anyways, won't come back. Plenty of other sushi restaurants worth going.
author: jessica t.

description:
Horrible customer service. Good luck getting your seats, even with reservation.

My party made a reservation for 5:45pm and they told us we had to be done eating by 6:45. Okay? Weird. But we wanted to go there so we said okay.  We get there and they say we have to be done by 6:30 now. They were not even ready to seat us, so we would have been given about 30mins to order and eat before being kicked out.

We just cut our losses and left, found another place to eat. I would never try to eat here again.

Horrible place with horrible service who don't care about their customers.
author: Morgan B.

description: Great experience. Market prices menu is delicious. I don't remember any name for those menu items (Japanese language), but I was happy enjoying 5 different plates for two of us. Great choice for Sake. Yummy. I was happy to share a shot of our Sake with our lovely server and a cook who makes us food. Very recommended
author: Svetlana K.

description:
Pleasantly surprised here. Make a reservation as the place is very small. 

I normally don't care for rolls because there's always too much rice and not enough extras but they did a great job with the rice to fish ratio. Everything had great flavors and staff were very friendly. 

I also think they prob have great takeout as they constantly had ppl coming in for it so I'll keep that in mind for next time lol.
author: Mandi W.

description:
Ambience: Well-designed, cozy neighborhood gem for sushi
Service: Nice staff but slow
Food: Fresh fish with good Japanese tapa selection

I would give it 4 stars if it weren't for the slow service. This has been my neighborhood go-to sushi spot for years because the staff is nice, the fish is fresh, and it has a really nice ambience where you could bring your man / woman / friend for a date. However, the in the past year, even when I've had a reservation, it takes a while to get seated and the service has been quite slow - perhaps because they are understaffed. It is definitely worth checking out though.
author: Marlene J.

description:
I haven't had such melt-in-your-mouth buttery fish since eating sushi in Japan! Came here for a dinner with 2 other friends on a Monday night and this place was already super busy by 6PM -- remember to make a reservation! This restaurant is rather tiny and packed.

I loved their special OTORO ROLL -- the spicy tuna had enough spice but the flavor wasn't too overpowering, and the mango on top was refreshing. I also tasted my friend's HIP HOP ROLL and loved the garlic white tuna along with crispy shrimp tempura. The SAKE (salmon) and O-TORO (fatty tuna) NIGIRI was so fresh and soft. 

My VEGETARIAN friend also enjoyed the variety of veggie rolls and highly recommends the JAPANESE MUSHROOM ROLL. I had a bite and it was perfectly pickled with just a hint of sweetness. The waiter said the vegetarian rolls are also VEGAN.

The service could be faster paced but I definitely understood that they had a full restaurant. Our server continuously checked in on us and assured that he would grab our orders soon, so we didn't feel completely ignored. Once the food arrived, he made sure we liked it and kept the tea flowing.

We enjoyed Japan-fresh sushi at a slight SF premium, but the taste was definitely worth the cost. I would stop by again when I am in the area, maybe before a show/concert in Hayes Valley. What a good Japanese find outside of the Richmond/Sunset area!
author: Bonnie Z.

description: Recommend this restaurant for people who loves real traditional Japanese sushi  unfortunately my brother doesn't like it but i do. This place is a little expensive but you can always come here for lunch. They have a lunch special that is worth your money!!! Around 30$-50 per person for lunch only...
author: Ivy Z.

description:
Had a reservation here last Friday night with two girlfriends. The place is pretty tiny but I enjoyed the atmosphere a lot.

My friends and I ordered a bottle of Sauvignon Blanc to start. For food, we split 3 different rolls. We ordered the O-Toro roll (salmon, avocado and tuna), spicy tuna with mango on top which was my favorite, and the Dynamite roll (asparagus, eel, and hamachi with jalepeno). 

The service was not great -The lady took a very long time coming back to check on us which was odd since the restaurant wasn't very big. She also was not super friendly.

Overall, I liked this place but wouldn't necessarily rush back here.
author: Ilana B.

description:
How does this place have 4 stars?

If you sit at the bar, you can see that their sushi is not fresh at all. You can see brown spots on their sushi. Also usually when you sit at the sushi bar, they give you a wooden block and you order from the sushi chef, but it doesn't work like that at all.

We had reservations but we had to wait 15 minutes to get seated (what is the point of a reservation)? 

You should come here just to get sushi rolls, not actual sushi and sashimi.
author: Ellen C.

description:
Came here with my bf to do some tasting and sushi hopping. We came to this location first. 

Price  & value: Costly for what it is. We ordered a 4 items, very small portion, came out to be $58.94. We ordered hawaii tuna poke $14.75, sauteed mushroom $7.95, grilled scallop topped with salmon belly $16.75 (this was a special for the day), hip hop roll $14.75 made with shrimp tempera inside, avocado inside, topped with garlic white tuna. The poke had about 5 pieces of tun in there, which was very disappointing, although the pieces were larger, for the same price at disneyworld I was able to get a HUGE platter of salmon. Price was definitely high for the value and assortment that you were getting. Wouldn't suggest this place if you don't want to spend that much money. I say this place is a 2.5/5 for price and value. 

Taste: Of the 4 dishes, my favorite was definitely the grilled scallop topped with salmon belly. I cant even explain the flavorful burst into your mouth. It came with 3 pieces on the plate for a total of $16.75. The sauteed mushrooms was probably the worst thing I've ever ordered at a restuarant. It was a combination of mushrooms stir fried with some oil...that was horrible. We paid a good $7.95 for it. Next the sushi roll came and it was very mediocre. Everything was average but price was steep. The only thing we enjoyed was the grilled scallop topped with salmon belly but that was also a good $17 for 3 pieces. Taste was a 2.5/5. 


Service: I enjoyed the service here. When we first got here, quickly seated, host kept checking in. The lady kept pouring and filling my tea. Somewhere down the line, she stopped doing so, and I had to request them to refill my green tea. Overall I would rate this place a 4/5. Small and cozy location, parking within a block away on the streets.
author: Amy Y.

description: This is honestly up there as some of the best sushi we have had, and pretty reasonably priced too! It's a fairly small place, but turnover is pretty quick and have never had trouble getting a table if you are happy to wait 15 minutes! Definitely try some of the specials and the sashimi is always great!
author: Lauren A.

description:
Mediocre sushi at best. Ordered the Caterpillar & Cherry Blossom rolls, as well as the O-toro nigiri with a friend, and neither of us were impressed. The rolls themselves were pretty small too. The fish wasn't suuuuuper fresh as I was expecting seeing all the raving Yelp reviews. Our total for all the items came out to $47.

We also had a strange experience with the service twice where the waitresses would push our plates closer to us while we were eating off of them, as they asked how things were going. It was just a little strange. Other than that, they checked in twice during our meal to make sure our beverages were filled which was nice.

Probably won't be coming back.
author: Melanie W.

description:
I'm giving two stars because of the service and ambience.

The sushi was terrible.  We ordered the hip hop roll, spider roll, some sashimi, and one of the collar appetizers (the regular menu one, not the specials board one).  I can't remember the last time I had sushi that was so tasteless.  Also, the rolls basically had five small pieces and were each really expensive for the amount we got.  My husband and I ended up going to RT Rotisserie afterwards because we were so disappointed.

I sorted the Yelp reviews by date, and noticed a lot more poor reviews like mine.  So, maybe it was great a couple years ago, but my experience was that the quality was definitely not worth the price.
author: Stella T.

description: Small restaurant, must be in the city. Don't let the size fool you, they have big taste. Nice intimate place, came for a family dinner and we really enjoyed ourselves. I have no idea what we ordered since my family did all the ordering before I arrived, but I know that all the sushi was great! Wait wasn't long and service was great. Would come back again
author: Andrew M.

description: I went there hungry & craving for sushi and left pretty satisfied. Overall good sushi and good service. I didn't try any of their cooked food so I can't speak for that but their fresh of the day sushi are must try. I loved the amaebi and otoro. Hamachi carpaccio was good,too. I didn't like the fact that they charge $2 for a cup of tea which tasted just like a hot water.
author: Aagii B.

description: Portions are tiny so make sure to order enough. At least it wasn't too expensive though. The rolls look a little bland. Didn't see any special items on the menu except their own otoro roll but it was average.
author: Tom P.

description:
It's okay. I had to sushi (2 piece, not rolls): uni, Toro, and eel. The uni was bad, and the other two were fine but I was expecting a bit more on the Toro since that's the name sake. 

All the rolls looked fine but doesn't stand out.
author: John S.

description:
When it comes to sushi, I can eat anything (from average to above average). However, rating wise - I am extremely picky and have rarely ever given sushi places a true 5 star rating.  O-Toro deserves this honor because of their exceptional quality of fish.

With their fairly large menu (mostly due to their small plates), I've had the chance to try a few items from their sushi/sashimi menu and also their tapas menu.  While their their tapas are decent, I would suggest limiting your order from this section and focus on their fish.  Being named "O-Toro," it's almost a given you should try their toro.  Warning: It is expensive.  However, since it's so fatty, you don't need a huge portion to satisfy your taste buds.  An order of the O-Toro Sushi (2 pieces) should be enough to cure an individual's curiosity.  Another option is to get an order of O-Toro sashimi and share with your party.  It is well worth the feeling of the toro melting away the moment it hits the tip of your tongue.  The same goes for any other fish you try (with salmon and yellowtail being my other two favorites).

For rolls, they keep it simple yet delicious- just how I prefer my sushi!  Unlike most other sushi restaurants, they don't pile on loads of crunchy onions or a bazillion different sauces that take away from the natural flavors of your sushi.  My personal favorite here is the 'Golden State' (snow crab, avocado, fresh salmon, and topped with bits of lemon).  The lemon just gives it an explosion of clean, citrus flavor - so complementary to the salmon.

I highly recommend O-Toro to all true sushi lovers, and I cannot wait to come back for more!
author: Judy C.

description:
This is probably just one of my favorite places for date night. I've been here twice so far and both times, I just had the most pleasant experience. There's something about this restaurant that's really soothing atmosphere wise.

I've had the ramen, nabeyaki udon, cherry blossom roll, and sashimi. Everything is delicious. I love it.
author: Mimi T.

description: Some of the best sushi I have ever eaten. If you are in SF and love tradition, quality sushi you must go. Large array of unique fish you won't find elsewhere as well. Great ambiance.
author: Jordan H.

description: Difficult to get in without reservations for dinner but the sushi was great quality and fresh. The rolls were creative, but I wished there were more salmon options on the menu as they're my favourite!  Delicious overall, on the pricier side but well worth it!
author: Charmaine L.

description: The service was great and the restaurant itself was very clean. I did think that the potion size was very small and a little to expensive for the sizes. I felt that the rolls were good but they weren't anything too special.
author: Amanda N.

description:
A bit above average, but on the pricy side. This place is fresh and has good quality food. Came by here for lunch last week and ordered a bento combination of chicken teriyaki and short ribs, the Hip Hop roll, the Otoro Roll, salmon nigiri, and toro nigiri to be shared with two people. We usually eat a lot so this is more than enough food. The bill came out to be around $80.

The restaurant was fairly crowded at lunch time but luckily we didn't have to wait. It is a relatively small restaurant. We were seated at the bar. The bento was about $16 for the combination. I thought the meat was excellent. It took a while to come out, which the servers were very apologetic about, but it wasn't too bad of a wait. I definitely liked the Hip Hop roll more than the O-toro roll, which was smaller and less special than I expected. The nigiri that we had was fresh.

I would come back to try more items on the menu if I am back in Hayes Valley. Nothing blew me away, but we did enjoy the food and experience.
author: Christina G.

description:
I've eaten at O-Toro a handful of times.  The food has always been good, but nothing special.

Pros: Consistently good food.  The restaurant is small, which gives it an intimate feel (although it can get loud - see below).  The owner/manager is always very friendly.  The prices are reasonable.

Cons:  Service is hit or miss.  During my last visit (earlier this week), service was veeery slooow.  The restaurant is also pretty darn loud.  There were a lot of "WHAT's" and "HUH's" during my dinner conversation, which wasn't very fun.
author: Connie S.

description: Took my brother here based on the Yelp reviews, and was disappointed at the mediocre overpriced fish. As is typical with many places in Hayes Valley, you're paying a premium for the location and the quality isn't there to back it up. Save your dollars and go down a few blocks to Tsubasa for your sushi/sashimi fix!
author: Nerri Y.

description:
I HATE to write a negative review for a business, unless they purposely do something unethical.  I always give them a second chance and a third chance.  But honestly, when you serve spoiled sushi and expect customers to pay $30 for its, there has to be some kind of accountability.    I ordered Torro sushi, it was spoiled and smelled like bad fish.  WE could not eat it as it smelled bad.   I simply asked to deduct this bad fish from my $200 tab.  And the owners said no.

Yelp is to help customers know when others have gotten screwed.  Well I payed $30 for fish that smelled a month old.
author: Bob H.

description: Their chirashi (sushi over a bed of rice) is totally overpriced. Good sushi but c'mon... a few, thinly sliced pieces for $25 seems steep even for SF.
author: Lisa S.

description: Solid sushi spot right near Civic Center and City Hall and all the theatres over there. It's pretty small (not much seating), but the menu was big and varied (both sushi and sake) and it was relatively cheap for such nice sushi. I had a great sake and a bunch of rolls. The Spider roll was big and flavorful. The special "lollipops" were veggie and fish wrapped in cucumber then cut into slices and skewered so they were like little lollipops! We also had a spicy tuna and mango roll that was awesome (and very spicy and sweet). And I had barracuda nigiri for the first time and it was firm, flaky, meaty, a bit fishy, and very very tasty.
author: Jeffrey S.

description: This is an older Japanese/sushi establishment in Hayes Valley.  It's perfectly located near the Opera/Symphony and makes for an ideal dinner right before the show.  I had a great meal with my friend here.  The menu is quite diverse and includes both raw and cooked items.  Highly recommend the braised pork belly, spicy squid, garlic soft shell crab and the grilled eggplant.  Sushi quality is good and they have a good selection of imported fish.  Dessert is limited.  Service was a little spotty on a Saturday night.
author: Andrew S.

description:
I've been addicted to using restaurant reservations apps lately, really makes things convenient. Planning on dinner with a friend, I decided to use my trusty apps to guide me in choosing the joint. Stumbled upon O-toro and saw the reviews were really good, so I definitely wanted to hit it up. 

When you get in, you'll notice this place is super small. Make reservations, it'll be so much easier. It's on the cusp of Haye's Valley and Civic Center and super intimate setting. Sushi bar or booth/table seating, low lit lighting and overall romantic ambiance. The staff was super quiet but helpful. For dinner, I wanted to try everything! The menu looked great. Here's what I settled on: 

-Sake Butteryaki from the Hot tapas menu for $12.75. Grilled salmon with a butter sauce. I thought this dish was good. The flavor was light, but present. I thought the salmon was a little dried out but it may have been sitting in a window for a bit. Not a bad dish though.

-Hamachi Belly with Yuzu Miso on their specials board for $14.95. OH-EM-GEE! This dish was to die for! The hamachi belly was marbleized and so delicious!!! The yuzu miso really enhanced the flavor overall. I really didn't want this dish to end haha!

-Shoyu Ramen for $12.75. Ended my meal off right! The ramen was cooked to perfection, the soup included things like bamboo shoots, pork, seaweed and other greens. I kind of wished they did a slow cooked, little runny boiled egg. That would've sealed the deal for this dish but what I had was super delicious. 

I've been trying to find a good sushi joint here in SF since I moved. This has to be up there as the top 5 joints I would frequent for years to come! If you're in the area, check them out!
author: Rockne H.

description:
This is fast becoming my favorite place to get sushi and takeout and a quick lunch. 

I have gotten the ten don lunch and it was delicious.

Very recently I had sushi here with a friend. We were really impressed by the special rolls like Caterpillar and Dragon. 

Melt in your mouth eel and avocado roll!
author: Allyson J.

description:
DISGUSTING. GROSS. EWWWW...

i am so disappointed. went to O-toro for the first time with my bf and sister. it was my sister's last night in sf so we wanted to go out for sushi! we lyfted it here because we wanted it that bad.

we got seated pretty quickly. in like 15-20minutes. we get water. we're drinking water. bf drinks about half his glass of water until my sister asks him if he's wearing lipstick/lipgloss. of course, my bf is like wtf no, and my sister says "there's a crapload of lipstick on ur cup" (see pic for reference)

first things first, that's gross. it's not even a SMEAR of lipstick, it's a perfect mark therefore that shows us that this cup was not washed. EWWW...

we waive down the waiter and let him know and he doesn't even say sorry... like wtf? RUDEEE... he says he will bring us a new one, and as he is going there, the manager asks him what happened and i see him explaining the glass. 

i would expect the manager to come over and apologize or something for his lack of cleanliness in the restaurant, because it's his responsibility. but nope, he doesn't say a word or even look at us the whole freakin night. EWWWWW...

the waiter is getting a new glass of water for my bf. and i see him checkin to make sure it's clean. shouldn't all the glasses be clean? do you really need to check if it's clean? do you wash ur dishes? are you saving water by giving us someone elses? EWWWW...

secondly, we are waiting for our food and he brings out a little tray of ginger and wasabi. which is awesome. i love ginger and wasabi. but it would be nice if there was actually wasabi in it! -see pic for reference -  there was ginger but NO FREAKIN WASABI... like wtf? not sure if he wanted to give me that little microscopic piece of wasabi or if he completely forgot it. but obviously he did not forget to put wasabi in it because then there would have been no microscopic remnants of wasabi, but why do i see leftovers of it. therefore it can only mean one thing, he gave us someone else's leftover of wasabi... EWWWWWW..

how sad, cause the food is pretty good. but then again, the dirtiness of the restaurant makes me questions everything. if the water glass and wasabi trays don't get cleaned, how clean can my food possibly be? it makes me wonder... EWWWWW...
author: Alex C.

description: Great place to come and get dinner. Tiny and sweet. Love the community it's in have to get here early to be able to walk around and check out shops.
author: Kyle C.

description: Amazing sushi and sashimi. Very fresh and beautifully presented. We got there about an hour before closing and although the service was not superb, it was good. Would eat there again!
author: Victoria N.

description:
Dinner review 

Tempura - 3/5
Otoro Nigiri - 5/5 
Dragon roll - 4/5
Cherry blossom roll - 2/5
Hip hop roll - 3/5

Overall, true to its name the Otoro was "as good as it gets."
author: Mark O.

description:
Went here for late dinner around 8:50pm on a Thursday night. This place was packed and very noisy. I had to almost yell when I was talking. 
Nonetheless, the food here is really good! Must try mango with tuna roll, Asparagus wrapped with Kobe beef, some sake, mushrooms and nigiri. 
I am sucker for fresh wasabi and this place had itsad that they didn't serve oyster shooters.
I will be coming back again soon!
author: Christina L.

description:
Following the calamitous Brexit vote, I have never felt closer to wanting to move to the Bay Area. Otoro Sushi us just the place which draws me here

The west coast does good sushi so effortlessly. I enjoyed a great lunch. Only disappointment was that the o-toro hadn't arrived for the day but the Chu-toro was also very good

It's worth a trek out to Hayes Valley for this quality of fresh fish
author: Yee Gan O.

description:
I thought this place had pretty fish quality for the price. The rolls and selection had a little more fusion-y / modern vibe to it. They have a good selection of sake and sake flights. 

Make sure you come early, as the place is small and they don't have a lot of tables. I've tried to come around 5:30pm several times, and had to sit at the bar since they say all the tables are reserved. Also, the last time I went, the waitress kept reaching over me to serve food and refill my hot tea. Usually waiters/waitresses will put the food or beverage off to the side. So it was very bothersome.

Overall great place to come by if you live in the area, but not worth traveling for otherwise.
author: James S.

description:
The best sushi place I've ever been to. Omega spicy and golden gate are my favorite. Omega spicy has salmon on top which is torched by the chef with a greenish spicy sauce, it tastes amazing and not too spicy. Golden gate roll has a small piece of lemon on top which was the perfect combination of salty from the soy sauce and sour. I LOVE otoro and this is a regular spot that my boyfriend and I go to.

(There's usually a long wait for dinner. We went on a Wednesday night before and waited an hour for a table. A couple weeks later, my boyfriend made a reservation 15 mins before on open table and we were seated right away!)
author: Connie S.

description:
Off the paths of Hayes Street, this place offered promise but I was not satisfied. 
Food is a very pricey and the portion size on the small end. Presentation is nothing fancy almost plain. The roll  we ate were average and did not stand out in any manner.
Lots of customers came on the night I was present so I am not sure of the true appeal.
Service was friendly and accommodating.
That's all for my review.
author: David H.

description: I went to get a chirashi bowl and they told me that it's gonna be $25 instead of the listed $19 and then came out with a bowl with 6 pieces of fish...wtf! The waitress was also rude
author: Martha S.

description:
Yummy sushi. Good service. Simple menu. 
One of my fav sushi spots. They have gluten free soy sauce and will make sure Celiacs eat safely.
author: Rocio S.

description: Nice, soft sushi. Unusual fish. Let them pick for you.
author: Evan Z.

description:
I have been hesitant to eat sushi in SF because people ranked Nara (Lower Haight) so highly, and it was an ABOMINATION. 

With Tsubasa packed, I decided to go to O-Toro and was pleasantly surprised! All we got was nigiri and everything was fresh and delicious-- we got salmon, mackerel, sardine, sweet shrimp, uni, fatty tuna, and amberjack, and I have no complaints.
author: J. A.

description: Otoro used to be a frequent spot for me but after this I will not be back. On my last visit my friend and I (who I hadn't seen in several months) ordered a large sushi dinner. We were catching up between bites, nothing insane. Waiters/Waitresses came by to try and collect the sushi plates before we were done several times. I didn't think much of it. We finished our meal and signed the check leaving a generous tip. Then as we were visibly packing up our bags and saying how nice it was to see each other, the restaurant manager came over and asked us to leave bc we had taken too long and he had "other reservations." There was no one waiting at the door or host/hostess stand. We went outside and wrapped up our good byes in the cold. We both found this very rude. Our meal was not hours long. We were just 2 friends catching up and giving them lots of business while at it. Apparently it's expected for guests at Otoro to inhale their sushi and leave.
author: Amber I.

description:
Loved that atmosphere at O-Toro and that they take reservations (surprisingly hard to find a good sushi place that takes reservations!)

I came with two friends and we split three different roles. We ordered the O-Toro roll which was my favorite. It's very simple---salmon, avocado and tuna. We also ordered a spicy tuna which was a little too heavy on the spicy mayo for my taste. But I liked that it came with a piece of mango on top. That was different! We also ordered the Dynamite roll of the specials menu. This was asparagus, eel, and hamachi with jalepeno. I felt it was lacking something. Maybe the eel wasn't a big enough piece, or maybe it needed eel sauce. It was good, but I was expecting something a little more exciting. 

Our wait staff were nice enough, but not particularly warm and engaging. It was more like they dropped the food and then would disappear for a while. 

I'd come back to O-Toro for sure, but I think I'd probably stick with the more simple rolls where you can really taste the fish
author: Sophie S.

description:
Solid. But too pricey for what you get. I spent about the equivalent as I do at Tsubasha (couple of blocks up) where the quality of the fish and preparation is considerably better.

Wouldn't order the gyozas or otoro #2 again. Stick to the nigiris. We liked the baby snapper one a loooottt. Next time we'll try some of the tapas as well
author: Laura D.

description: Disappointing. When I went inside to put my party of 3's name down the staff seemed very irritated with me so we waited outside to stay out of their way. Unfortunately the host forgot about us and, after prompting a few times, we finally sat down more than an hour later (when we were told the wait was 20 min and they sat parties that arrived after us first). After we finally ordered, half my food was forgotten. Overall a very disappointing experience and I won't be returning and would spend my money elsewhere.
author: Elizabeth L.

description: Quite fresh fish, unusual and tasty choices on the Tapas menu and great non-fish options as well. The Aji Tataki was beautifully presented.
author: Peter Z.

description:
O'toro is very small, cute sushi restaurant in Hayes valley. We got there around 7, and the wait was about 25 minutes. It went by quickly, the host was very nice, and took everyones drink orders while we waited. We ended up with bar seats which was cool- it's always fun to watch sushi chefs do their thing.

When we were ordering, it bothered me that the waitress always pushed the most expensive dishes on us. It felt a bit weird. We ended up with a shishito stuffed with spicy albacore appetizer, a golden state roll, and a few orders of nigiri. The roll was my favorite- the little pieces of lemon on top of the salmon was a nice touch. The nigiri felt a bit small, and the shishito peppers were just okay.

I didn't think this place was bad by any means, but it didn't feel remarkable, while also being quite pricey. There are way better options in the city for sushi.
author: Nivita T.

description:
We came to the Restaruant because yelp gives a good rating. We spent good money for two people mostly ordered tapas. However, I do not think the owner was honest about the seating.

There were one two person table next to the window and one in the dark corner also the bar seats. When we first walked in, the waiter asked us to wait and went to clean the table by the window for us. A minute later, the owner walked out from the kitchen. He asked us if we preferred to sit at the bar or the table in the dark corner. I said, I would like to sit by the window. The owner said that table was reserved. (The table has no reservation card) so I kept staring at the table after I sit down at the dark corner, no one was sitting there for a good 20 minutes. After 20 minutes, the owner seats a couple there and I do not think they had reservation.

I believe the owner "choose" his customers for a "better" seat. I do not want to use the D word but that is how I felt.
author: Lily T.

description:
Went here for dinner with a group of 5 girls. Service was slow and not very friendly. They forgot my friends seaweed salad and when she told them they never apologized and brought it way late after they had cleared everyone's dinner plates and still charged her for it. 

The sushi is your standard sushi spot, nothing special, a bit overpriced for what you get!
author: Kristina B.

description: This is a really comfortable local spot with good food and a really nice sake list. There's both traditional sushi/sashimi/tataki and noodle bowls, and some fun, modern innovations like their lollipops -- sashimi on a stick cleverly made round like a lollipop (no rice for the carb conscious). Good value. Service is attentive and quick. A little on the loud side bc it's small and rectangular and busy. But it's also cozy and intimate. Good for vegetarians, too. Friendly owner operated. We've been twice and will go back when we're in the area around SF Jazz.
author: Leyla H.

description:
BOMB Sushi!! The reason I'm giving it 4 stars is because the restaurant is SO small and the wait was so long. My friends and I put our name in at 7:30pm on a Tuesday, the host told us to come back in 30- 45 minutes. We came back at 30 minutes, but it took us another full 30 to be seated.

However, once we finally got seated, our waiter was very friendly and attentive, and the food was delicious. My favorite was the O-toro roll with spicy tuna, avocado and mango nom nom. Also tried the Golden Gate which I didn't love because the crab tasted kind of weird to me, but it was still good. The Cherry Blossom was very flavorful and fresh. The dragon roll and hip hop were also very food (hip hop was very garlicky so only get if you like garlic). Each roll was about $15, which I think is less expensive than other sushi places, where signature rolls could be $18- $20. We also tried the miso soup which was basic but really hot and not lukewarm!! (I hate when my miso comes out lukewarm).

Overall super delicious, but next time I will make a reservation.
author: Jenna G.

description:
I have eaten here twice. The first time was really excellent. The second time, this time, not so much. 

Our young waitress was very nice and working very hard. But the service was poor and it looked to me like the dining area was short-staffed -- one waitress for something like 10 tables plus drinks for the bar. But what irked me was the owner. He was not helping at all to serve tables. He was walking around trying to get tables to turn over, but meanwhile tables were waiting a long time for pretty much everything and it was clear he was not going to lift a finger to help. If a table asked for help getting drinks, he would say I'll send your waitress over. 

I was disappointed, and I blame the owner. He should help out.
author: Michael B.

description:
Came across O Toro sushi while in a pinch to find a place for dinner on a Thursday night. Located in Hayes  Valley (sort of) O Toro is surrounded by tons of restaurant options, if sushi isn't your thing.  

The place isn't very big, has about 15 tables and then a few seats at the bar. The waitress showed us to our table and brought us warm cloths to wash our hands, which I thought was a great idea. 

To start we had a saporo, Tempura and ribs. I liked the beer and the Tempura, but for me the ribs were nothing special. For our sushi , we ordered a variety of different rolls,  including salmon roll and Tempura roll..the rest I cannot remember.  All of what we ate was fresh and delicious and served really quickly!

The only downfall was that they have a menu with all the fish of the day and speciality items. It hangs on the wall beside the bar. However, they don't point it out to you. I would have loved to order off the special menu, since the food listed sounded great. Oh well,  maybe next time.
author: Aletta B.

description:
O, O-Toro... if I eat enough Otoro, I will soon become as big as Totoro.  

I found O-Toro on Yelp because I was looking for a place that was nice, decently unique, and affordable.  I cannot necessarily say that O-Toro satisfied the last criteria, but it was definitely a fancy hassle of a culinary expedition: on my showing-people-around-SF list.

We got the SHISHITO STUFFED WITH SPICY ALBACORE ($6.95) to share.  Although I generally find appetizers underwhelming and overpriced, this turned out to be addicting flavor explosion--I would be happy eating plates of this for a meal!  It's somewhat similar to the shrimp stuffed bell pepper dim sum, except with a big kick from the shishito pepper, spicy albacore, and spicy mayo.  I wasn't sure what to think when I saw the dish arrive with bonito flakes, but the bold nuttiness added a nice extra dimension.  It also threw me off guard that it's not sashimi, but cooked albacore which looked and tasted suspiciously like imitation crab.  (However I would trust them not to have imitation albacore.)

Since they don't offer the sashimi or any other type of sashimi combo for dinner, it forced me to think.  I have reached the age of straying away from saucey crunchy fusiony rolls, so I confronted the difficult, sophisticated (and expensive) choices for nigiri.  

I got the O-TORO NIGIRI ($12) because restaurant namesakes tend to feel obligatory.  Maybe my expectations rose a little too high, because I failed to detect anything mind-blowing and would honestly have preferred a leaner tuna with better fish flavor that wasn't diluted in fat, i.e. the regular maguro.  The price wasn't listed on the menu due to the seasonal availability, and $12 was steep for the two pieces of nigiri... $6 perfectly good lunch money (or two days of coffee money) vanished into thin air in one bite!  (well, technically not thin air, but don't get me started on metabolism)

I really liked the GARLIC ALBACORE ($5.50) which was infused with garlicky goodness and turned out to be excellent with the rich albacore.  The SAKE ($5.75) was good too, with minimal strips of fat which placed a strong emphasis on the actual salmon flavors.

The nigiri can rival the badass sushi of Socal--large cuts that drape over the sushi rice and a glistening freshness that makes your mouth water just from looking at it.  The presentation was nice but I thought it was a bit too whimsical with the seemingly random garnishes of cashew, radish, and cucumber (I debated rearranging the one of the awkwardly placed garnishes for my food pictures)  

At the end we were still hungry so we added the GYOZA ($6.75).  I expected it to be exactly like all the other premade salty frozen gyoza, but for once it tasted fresh: the thin wonton skin, perfect tad of browned crispiness, and vegetable-based filling rather than the usual hamburger-grade mystery ground pork.  Another unexpected yummy was the dipping sauce: it was very much sweetened which made the gyoza even more complexly delicious.

Overall O-Toro has undeniably good food, but at over $30 (without drinks--this is definitely restricted to special occasions, or if I want to show off to non-SF peeps about how SF has good food.  

Note: If review intrigues you, I suggest checking out Domo in the area!  I only chose O-Toro because it takes reservations, but seriously how can you not resist the thought of Domo (even though the restaurant is way too classy to be named after that silly Domo-kun)
author: Edna C.

description:
Last night was date night for us as newlyweds. The food was good and great service. My husband paid the bill and I went to the loo. 

When I came back, the manager (or perhaps owner since he didn't introduce himself) approached us to ask why the tip was so low? He was trying to understand if the service was bad or the food not good? It was somewhat embarrassing because we were seated at the bar and all of the customers could hear his line of questioning since the space is small and intimate. Then he walked away when we told him nothing was wrong. 

I spoke to my husband, who is not a native here. I found out it was due to a cultural misunderstanding. In Europe, it's not customary to give a tip since it's already built into the price of the meal. 

So I went over to hand the manager more tip money and apologize profusely for the honest mistake. I explained the cultural misunderstanding. He seemed shocked when I gave him more money to make up for the insufficient tip.

As we continued with our date night, it left a sour taste in our mouths; and essentially ruined our date night. Now my husband is left with a bad impression about restaurants here in the US and would rather cook at home from now on. 

I'm still thinking about it 15 plus hours later. Hence the reason for this review. I've never seen a manager come up to a patron to question the amount of a tip. Times have changed.
author: Jesse J.

description: If you're into fresh sushi at reasonable prices, go to O-Toro. I have consistently had a positive experience here. It's worth it to make a reservation as the place is on the more 'intimate' side. The first time I dined at O-Toro I was pregnant and had the udon. It did not disappoint. The next time I was not pregnant and indulged in super yummy yellowtail toro, albacore and salmon sashimi. However, they are known for their namesake otoro - and you will see why after you taste it. I will be coming back often!
author: Liz O.

description:
We can here before show at SFJAZZ. They are super friendly and accommodating.
The store is small but I think they turn around quick. All dishes we had was delicious. I love the way they cut and decorate each dish with thin sliced veggie. Highly recommended
author: Akiko I.

description: The hostess is really rude. She skipped me and my bf on the wait list and was making calls to people who obviously wasn't planning on dinning in. I asked very politely how long she ignored me so I assumed she didn't hear me I asked again she rolled her eyes at me and placed her finger up as if I was a child. At this point I didn't even want to eat there so I left. I'm pretty sure the food here is awesome but please get your hostess in line. We all have bad days but never in my life have I treated a customer like that. I Won't be coming back.
author: DiDi D.

description:
Underwhelming. Sushi is passable. Great for grabbing quick bites before show, but sadly fish is small and not as fresh as you'd expect it to be, considering they are flown from Japan. However, the service is very good. And they are very attentive, and when I told them that I only had thirty or so minutes to eat, they sat me quickly and fed me even quicker. Dining alone, women get attention. That's sort of the general rule of thumb, especially if you sat by the bar on your own. So, you get that going for you if food is not of your top concern. But It is, for me. Quality of food takes precedence over ambience and attentive service. 

There are some silver lining to this spot. It's right next to Rich Table, one of my top restaurants in SF. So if you are unable to make that gruesome wait and are tired of walking, this could be your spot. Just that it's not going to be mine. Bookmark for this spot, removed.
author: Victoria E.

description:
Last night was date night for us as newlyweds. The food was good and great service. My husband paid the bill and I went to the loo. 

When I came back, the manager (or perhaps owner since he didn't introduce himself) approached us to ask why the tip was so low? He was trying to understand if the service was bad or the food not good? It was somewhat embarrassing because we were seated at the bar and all of the customers could hear his line of questioning since the space is small and intimate. Then he walked away when we told him nothing was wrong. 

I spoke to my husband, who is not a native here. I found out it was due to a cultural misunderstanding. In Europe, it's not customary to give a tip since it's already built into the price of the meal. 

So I went over to hand the manager more tip money and apologize profusely for the honest mistake. I explained the cultural misunderstanding. He seemed shocked when I gave him more money to make up for the insufficient tip.

As we continued with our date night, it left a sour taste in our mouths; and essentially ruined our date night. Now my husband is left with a bad impression about restaurants here in the US and would rather cook at home from now on. 

I'm still thinking about it 15 plus hours later. Hence the reason for this review. I've never seen a manager come up to a patron to question the amount of a tip. Times have changed.
author: J T.

description:
We had reservations for a group of 4 on Friday night and when we got there they said it would be a 15 minute wait. It ended up being a 35 minute wait, and I understand Friday nights are busy, but this was a poor operations management and it looks badly on a restaurant if they can't even get this right. Without really apologizing or offering us a drink, we ended up being seated but then it was another 15 minutes till they brought us water or the menus. We ended up eating more than 1 hr after our reservation time.

That being said the sushi was pretty good, we got the golden gate roll, dreamy sensation, california and the dragon roll which was specially good. 

I wouldn't really recommend this place because of its service, which is a shame given their food is actually good.
author: Marta V.

description: Great experience! We had a couple rolls at this place and all exceeded expectation. The fish here is really fresh and great quality. Highly recommended it to anyone who's in town. Plus you can't go wrong with the green tea cheesecake! ** the besttttt****
author: Ruth T.

description:
Came here after a late evening weightlifting session with some friends as a going away treat.  The staff were preparing to close up shope, as the sashimi display case had already been disassembled; yet, they were nice to allow us to step in and take our order as the last order.  That alone deserves some brownie points.

The tapas style apps menu was nice.  We ordered the tako-yaki (grilled squid),  the goma-e (spinach with soy, sesame and peanut sauce) and I also got the yellow-tail sashimi.

All in all the quality of the fish was solid.  The goma-e was great and the tako-yaki was enough to share.  The plates are large enough to share.  I actually shared some of the udon broth from a friend's udon and it was OISHII!

Recommend this to anyone searching for some post workout proteins and healthy carbs...or just a GOOD meal (screw post workout...) at any time!
author: Hiromi N.

description: The food is good but not much better than other great spots like Sushi Zone, Tsubasa or Sagoi Sushi. The service is bad.
author: Ember R.

description:
I love Sushi, n at minimal, have sushi 3 or more times a week.  With that said... I wasn't blown away by my sushi experience here.  We ordered our own handmade roles, n ther cherry blossom role, uni nigiri n special salmon sashimi.  Uni was tasty n cherry blossom role very blah,n salmon was just ok... N also pricey.
Limited wine n beers, n menu.  The staffs awesome n helpful though. Also small n sper crowded little resto.
author: ThuZ W.

description:
Sushi quality: nothing special. You can always tell a good sushi place if the salmon is good, and it wasn't. They're known to fly their fish from Japan and known for the otoro(fatty tuna). It looked promising, but it didn't have the melt in your mouth texture that filled your mouth with its rich creamy flavor. 

Ambience: small and cramped. Make reservations. Super loud because cheap alcohol prices make ppl rambunctious. Wouldn't recommend bringing a group larger than four. 

Service: waitresses are nice but it took 5ever for sushi to come out. Maybe because it was a Friday night, but my udon and tempura came out before the sushi. 

Prices: $6-10/ per two pieces of sushi. The five pieces of salmon was $12-15( I forget) 

Overall...not cheap and the quality doesn't add up.
author: Christina O.

description: My friend thought the fish and uni were fresh. He was a fan of the restaurant and would come back. I thought it was pretty good, but the rolls were a little small. My favorite were the O-Toro fatty tuna and the Amaebi sweet shrimp sushi. The sushi came pretty quickly and service was good overall.
author: Annie L.

description: Had sushi here tonight with the few friends and had a good time!  The service was great - we got a table right away since we had a reservation. I thought it was a nice touch with warm hand towels when we sat down. The rolls were not too expensive...on average about $15 a roll. I had the Miso Ramen which I thought was OK... Didn't have much flavor and the noodles were thinner than I'm used to. The salmon sashimi was fresh and thick so that was nice. I might come back to try some more rolls but it's definitely not a ramen joint.
author: Brittany G.

description:
The Ankimo (monkfish liver pate) deserved 4-5 stars by itself. The rest of my fare, not so much. 

It's O-Toro, so I felt I had to try the Otoro (fatty tuna) sashimi. It was fatty, but pretty veiny at the same time. We ordered the five piece for $30 but I was pretty done with it after the 3rd bite. The asparagus covered in kobe beef was a bit of a let-down as well. It was cooked nicely, but there was nothing about it that wowed me. I could go on about some of the other dishes, but I'll try and focus on the positives. 

Got there at 11:30am for lunch: no wait. Gold flight sake: good selection. 

Verdict: I personally wouldn't recommend it, although it's possible that I'll come back and give it another shot.
author: Chris C.

description: Meh service. Took forever to get through our meal. We waited so long between courses. Food was good but not stellar. May return but I think in the area, Domo is better.
author: Cathy L.

description:
Ran into this small place as my niece and I was strolling down Oak Street, feeling hungry. When we stepped inside the place, we were asked if we had reservations (the place was quite packed) and I told the staff that we did not. His expression was concerning.. I noticed that there were enough bar seats opened which he didn't even offer until I asked. We got the chance to sit down and glance at the menu before realizing we were pressed on time so we decided to tell the staff that we are going to order to-go instead. He said it wasn't a problem and we let ourselves up off the bar area and walked to the side of the restaurant with the menu to decide what we wanted to get. 

My niece and I decided on getting a roll with unagi (eel) in it, so we chose the Dreamy sensation. For appetizers, we shared the agedashi tofu. 

Food was just okay in my book. The Dreamy sensation had a decent flavor, but with the cream cheese and avocado, the flavor of the unagi wasn't strong at all. I felt like I was eating a roll with mostly fat and no protein. 

The agedashi tofu was overly soggy. The food was done and packed inside a to-go container but we waited 20 minutes for them to make the single dreamy sensation roll to-go so the appetizer ended up getting soggy while sitting in its own steam. The dipping sauce was good, it made the tofu more tolerable. 

Service here sadly didn't make up for the long wait time. We were never offered anything to drink while waiting, and the staffs kept walking quickly passed us as to avoid talking to customers who aren't dining in.
author: Tuan N.

description: I've eaten here twice. Both times I thought the food was good but nothing special. There are dozens of other sushi restaurants in the city that are just as good or better but are less expensive.
author: Dong L.

description:
Fish was super fresh that didn't break the bank. 

All the rolls we got had a great combination of texture n favors. 

Presentation was great.

Small little environment but the atmosphere was good. 

Trying to make sense of the avocado pit they use for the soy sauce cover. And the avocado pits y have growing. 

My favorite was the lollipop roll, wish I had taken a picture. 3 types of super fresh fish with avocado all wrapped in a thinly sliced cucumber.
author: Fran C.

description:
Very fresh sushi, friendly staff. The only drawback is the space. The restaurant is small with limited tables, so if you don't have a reservation, you may have to wait for a while.

I would recommend it to give it a try, they have really good sushi after all.
author: Richard W.

description:
Marta loves eel and always orders a Catapiller Roll. This one was very disappointing.  The eel was almost nonexistent. The Hamachi was great though. 

They also had done Beef Tongue with Shiso  leaf. OK but on the chewy side. 

The service was very good for a busy Saturday night.
author: Cal H.

description:
Since Domo had a wait and we were trying to look for something else to try nearby, we decided to check this place out.

I would say the sushi was pretty mediocre, especially for the price. Between 2 of us, we spent a little over $50 for 1 roll to share and a few pieces of nigiri, and definitely didn't leave full. Although there was no wait, the service was extremely slow, so I'm not sure if it actually saved us any time in the end.

I LOVE uni, so I tend to judge a sushi place by its uni. The uni here was not among the better ones I've had, but also not among the worst. The highlight was probably the o-toro roll, which was good, but still nothing to write home about.

Next time, I'll probably check out one of the many other sushi places nearby!
author: Kavita S.

description:
Maybe it was the fact that they were 15 minutes late on our reservation or that it took 10 minutes from requesting water to get water but the service here is terrible. And 5 minutes after taking our order was last call for ordering food, which would have made more sense if it hadn't taken so long to get the ball rolling. When paying $15-17 per sushi roll I anticipate better service. 

It was also way too loud (and I usually like social noise) - they literally had no acoustic attention on the ceiling at all. 

The food may have been redeeming but don't order spicy tuna anything. It was way over mayo'ed and tasted slightly sour. Overall a disappointing experience.
author: Samantha H.

description:
Instant ramen is better than their miso ramen. Bland  broth, bad quality noodles, egg was just a hard boiled egg, nothing special there. The pork was three super thin pieces that smelled old. 

Needless to say, I'm not returning here.
author: Emil A.

description:
Giving this place 5 stars for all the reasons that matter-

Very affordable dishes with surprisingly decent sizes, and an ample selection in the menu. I got the miso ramen (roughly $13) and a side of spicy salmon roll (roughly $8). The ramen was HUGE although that didn't stop me from finishing every last bite. 

The quality of the seafood here is commendable! The salmon was incredibly soft and rich in flavor. I tried my friend's shrimp tempura and that was also delicious. My miso ramen was an explosion of flavors, even though I ordered mine without the pork. 

Overall, the place in itself is small and charming, in one of my favorite neighborhoods. Will definitely become a regular here.
author: Alejandra L.

description:
Reservations highly recommended. 

We had one, and saw that those who didn't were turned away.

Which was odd because there were about 3 empty tables where they could have been seated, and those tables remained empty throughout our 1 1/2 hour meal.

About the food, my friend was looking forward to their Omakase, while I just went with their regular menu. I made a wise decision, since my friend's $75 Omakase consisted of only 3 small rolls of sushi and some mixed nigiri and sashimi; maybe another 7 pieces in all. She left hungry, and opted to go to Smitten's ice cream afterwards to drown her sorrows and get more carbs from the ice cream.

I had the fried garlic soft-shell crab, which was delicious. The truffle hamachi-meh. The shisito pepper hamachi-blech (overcooked hamachi stuffed in a dry pepper), and negi-toro roll (good)...and some anikmo...just okay. And their homemade gyoza..which tasted like it was from a frozen Costco bag.

I was expecting more hits than misses, and so I was disappointed. I would give the garlic soft-shell crab 4 or 5 stars though if I was just rating the dishes and not the overall experience.

I also don't like the fact that I when I asked for refills on tea, our waitress forgot multiple times, but managed to remember the table next to us and fill up their tea.

Due to the hard to find parking, okay sushi, and mixed service, I won't be back.
author: Jack R.

description:
This is the place that I hate to love and love to hate. They have an unbearably longest wait in the world for a table (the place is *tiny*), but they have the FRESHEST and most unique sushi in town!

What are my recommendations? 

Almost anything on the menu, especially the sashimi! It's the freshest sashimi that I've had, and I go to A LOT of sushi restaurants (just read my list: http://www.yelp.com/list/sushi-is-so-oshi-san-francisco)

Highly Recommended:

* Anything on their Specials Board
* O-Toro Sashimi (melts in your mouth!)
* Spanish Blue Shrimp Nigiri (they deep fry the heads for you as well -- delicious!)
* Whole Spanish Mackeral Sashimi (they deep fry the carcass for you after you eat the sashimi -- much, much tastier than it sounds!

Recommended:

* Sweet Pork Belly
* Tara: Glazed Black Cod
* Uni Nigiri
* Tobiko Nigiri
* Tamago Nigiri
* Sake Sashimi
* Hamachi Sashimi

Good:

Dragon Roll
Caterpillar Roll
Sake Roll

Pros:

+ FRESH fish
+ Excellent service
+ Unique selection of wild and farmed fish
+ Authentic Japanese-owned
+ Gluten-free Soy Sauce 
+ Brown rice alternative
+ Optimally located near SF Jazz Center, Symphony Hall, and Davis Hall

Cons:

- Loooooong wait time, even if you have a VIP Open Table reservation!!!

**Tip: Best times to be immediately seated are early evening around 5 p.m. or late evening after 9 p.m.
author: Diana V.

description: This was good sushi at normal prices.  They lit oil lights that smell strongly.  We blew ours out and the server removed it promptly.
author: Sondra H.

description:
The fish quality is mediocre and potions are tiny. The service is very slow (even to get the credit card back).
On the positive side, the dish presentation is very nice
author: Georgi N.

description:
Love this place. My go to for casual sushi. The fish and skewers are fresh and delicious.

Do get the Otoro #2 if they are serving it.
Beef tongue skewers on point.
Dynamite roll blew me away.

Do not order ramen if you are a ramen lover. If you do, do not expect to be impressed.
author: Kathy Z.

description: Worst service. Waited for a table for 30 minutes only to have the manager seat a couple of regulars that I overheard didn't have a reservation - we didn't even say anything, but the manager looked at us and yelled, "They have reservations!!" Didn't appreciate being lied to. We, of course, walked out. This was the second time that I had a run in with the rude staff. I will not be coming back here - which is a shame since I've been several times. No food is ever good enough to justify treating your customers that way. We ended up going to Tsubasa Sushi only a couple of blocks away and had amazing sushi AND stellar service.
author: Cathy C.

description:
A striking balance of high end sushi and service in an unpretentious manner. You'd feel comfortable coming just before the opera, or as part of a fun night out on the town.

This narrow, long sushi restaurant is decorated with only two things (a large fish and today's special menu) as they have appropriately focused on making each piece of sushi an experience. If you sit at the bar, you can watch the sushi chefs perfect a roll. And if you sit at a table, you can unashamedly admire the craft. The menu is simple and focused on sushi rolls- so come prepared to use chopsticks. Great sake menu worth ordering from. 

Expect to have friendly service as the waitress can help you order the best (which sometimes is the most affordable) dishes!

Make a reservation, if only to help you move to the top of the wait list. While the food comes out quickly, most tables stay a while because they keep ordering more!
Ideally go by yourself or with one other person (great for dates who you're trying to implicitly impress!!), but definitely no more than 4 people (it's a tiny restaurant!).
Be adventurous by splurging on some specials- order the fatty tuna, oysters, and/or otoro #2 if they are on there!
author: Regina D.

description:
Let's be clear:  this is not a bad place, but for the price, there are a lot better.  First, the positives:  It's a cute little place, the sushi is presented well, and the quality of the fish was good.  So what's not to like?

1.  They have fully bought into the trend toward "innovative" concoctions full of trippy stuff that doesn't belong in sushi.  They even call their appetizer menu "Japanese Tapas", which should clue you in right away that they don't respect either Japanese or Tapas.

(Disclaimer:  If you have read my other reviews, you know I am not into non-traditional ingredients in sushi. If you are into that stuff, then disregard #1 above.)

2.  When we were discussing what to order, they kept trying to upsell their most expensive items, including the not-very-traditional appetizers (sorry--Tapas).   We stated several times that we wanted traditionally-made sushi before the waitress stopped suggesting the other junk and took the orders.

3.  The service was TOO attentive-the waitress constantly pushed us to order more even when we were still trying enjoy what we had in front of us.  She aggressively poured more sake when we wanted to pace ourselves.  It simply didn't feel comfortable.

4.  In the end, even the simple, straight-up Nigiri was made with small portions of fish (the pieces of fish are supposed to overhang the pat of rice), and overall the price of dinner was about 60% more than I have paid at comparable or better places in San Francisco.

I go to dinner in Tokyo on a frequent basis, and I know what the real thing is like.  While San Francisco is one of the few cities outside Japan where I would feel comfortable taking Japanese guests for Japanese dinner, I certainly won't be taking them to O-Toro.
author: charles h.

description:
Fatty tuna, fatty tuna! Come get ya fatty tuna!

We got towed during my first SF Elite Event and both needed something to cheer us up after walking 2 miles & paying 500+ to get the car out. And what better way than noshing on the most desired part of a tuna belly?
