I did a quick Yelp search for sushi and ended up here five minutes later. The kind hostess seated us immediately. Ambiance is modern yet comfortably cozy.
Ravenous, we ordered seared hamachi, pork belly, a dragon roll, baked green mussels and of course otoro! I saw that they also offer Bi-Rite ice cream but did not end up allocating enough stomach space for dessert :(

Baked mussels appetizer were spicy, cheesy and very tasty. Dragon roll and beef skewers were pretty standard but we got them as a filler anyway. The sashimi is definitely the winner here.
Seared hamachi comes with a bit of jalapeño which gives the fresh, lightly grilled fish  a good kick. Their otoro has the perfect light pink hue with nice white marbling and a few oily lines.  It melted in my mouth and had my eyes rolling back in my head. No, I wasn't on anything other than a sashimi high! ;)

I'm not a fan of the pork belly, as the fat-to-meat ratio is essentially 100/0. I eat a looot of pork belly and can't say I've ever had pork belly this rich or heavy in my life. You may like it but I found that it threw off the balance of my meal with its especially sweet buttery flavor. At $12 for two pieces, I did not feel like it was worth it. I'll stick to fish fat next time. :)

Otoro put a huge smile on my face that day and remains one of my favorites for sushi in the city. Thanks Sugai-san, totoro out!
author: Jenny Q.

description:
My friend picked everything our table of 3 ordered. She's a regular, everything she ordered was melt in your mouth delicious. Most of the nigiri she ordered was off the specials board, which she says she always orders from. We also shared the sake tasting, my favorite was the cherry flavored sake!
Small cozy intimate restaurant great place to catch up with friends.
author: Rosalyn S.

description:
Take out from here is not good. However, every time my husband and I eat here we are always pleased and always over order. His favorite roll is the dynamite which is fresh hamachi with jalapeno. Mine is the shrimp tempura roll topped with tuna. We also love their tapas options, they have a great dish which is asparagus wrapped in kobe beef and soft shell crab. 

Great for date night and when you are in the mood for fresh sushi. 
Service is excellent!
author: Tahima B.

description: Pretty awesome.  Going to the ballet. Time constraints.  It is crowded.  There is a wait.  We were late.  Worth waiting.  Omg.  Best hamachi, scallops, octopus, tuna, everything-- Awesome.  Service was good.  Great environment.  Nice place for pre opera, symphony or ballet.  Really good food. Excellent chefs.  Good prices.  Awesome!
author: Elisa B.

description:
SO. AMAZING. 

I went to Japan a few months ago, and this is the closest I have found to the incredible sushi and food experiences there.  

Do not skip the pork belly. It is the best pork belly in the city!  Two pieces sit in a small bowl with a deliciously sweet and savory sauce on the bottom.  The perfect layer of fat is heavenly.  Umami!

Ask which of the nigiri is seared, and get those.  O-Toro uses something like a creme brulee torch to sear the tops of the fish every so slightly.  You get a very light charred flavor while still experiencing the delicious raw fish underneath.  Really incredible.  

Tip: The line is always out the door, but they you can order wine or sake while you wait. Or to skip the wait altogether, use Open Table to make a reservation!
author: Jaching H.

description:
Intimate and small sushi joint with more of a hip vibe. Sushi quality is pretty good here and prices are reasonable for what you're getting. Service is fast and attentive but doesn't rush you.

The monk fish liver appetizer is great. It's presented well and tastes just like pate with a bit of a nice hint of fishiness.

The golden gate roll was good. Seemed like real snow crab and not that fake crab fish substitute. The spider roll was also well done. 

The sushi itself was certainly above average quality but wasn't near the tastiest I've had for the types. I had the yellow tail and the mackerel.

This won't be a mind blowing Japanese experience but you won't be disappointed either. I think with its ambiance and service it wins me over to come back at some point.
author: Victor W.

description:
We called to get a reservation for dinner saturday night. Everything was full but they told us walk-ins were still welcome.

We arrived right before 7. There was another person waiting before us. They said the wait would be around 20 minutes. It ended up being less than 10, cool! Around 7:10, a line started forming in front of the restaurant.

Everything is pretty pricey besides the gyoza, rice, and miso soup, LOL. That's very common in many japanese restaurants. 
What I liked at O'Toro was the atmosphere and lounge music. Not always the case in similar places. The staff was attentive, too.

We chose the salmon-avocado rolls, spicy tuna rolls, 2 scallop nigiri, 2 tuna nigiri, miso soup and the gyoza. The waitress asked if we wanted live scallops. I passed.
We had ordered a rice but the waitress forgot it. The gyoza was served very hot (5 pieces). It was good even if I prefer mine a bit more dough-y. This one was grilled it seemed, which is good too.
The sushis and rolls were good but NOT incredible at all.

I was searching for that special touch that some chefs put to make their dishes unique, but I did not find it.

We were excited to try the green tea cheesecake but they were out so we ordered the red bean mochi and a sesame ice-cream scoop for 4$: I think they could give at least 2 scoops for that price... The mochi tasted fresh, I liked it. It wasn't too small, either.

Over 50$ for two w/o tip and not entirely full at the end of the meal... Not too cool. 
The restaurant is nice though and I do recommend if you're in the area and don't mind spending extra money for decent sushi!
author: Leslie S.

description:
Still the best sushi in the neighborhood. The owner is a joy and always professional. The sushi is fresh and top-notch. Call ahead to get a reservation if you can, but if you can't get a reservation there are usually some tables that open up. The space is on the smaller size, so it's not ideal for huge groups. 

We've been coming here for years and have no plans to stop!
author: A A.

description: It was busy on a Saturday day night, so of course, there was a wait. The host was attentive and even asked to take our drinks while we waited. The food was delicious and the staff were on point!
author: Maria G.

description:
O-toro is my favorite sushi place in the city. My go-to date spot. Small, not too loud, great sushi. I've yet to have a bad meal there in the past 7 years.

Jimmy is great guy and runs the place very well.
author: Stephen L.

description: Awesome affordable place for sushi. Their fresh fish catches are awesome for sushi or nigiri. Also really enjoyed their garlic soft shell crab and kalbi. The grilled squid was okay nothing mind blowing. Get the seared sake (salmon) belly if they have it. That is one of my favorite nigiris there. Definitely will be eating here often!
author: Rohenne L.

description:
This review is for a year ago

1st time: The property is very small and usually crowded hence fort I would have to take a star due to inconvenience of accidentally bumping to the customer to the left, right, or just walking around. Let start from the beginning, I came here after work and I heard great reviews about the place so why not give it a try! I'm a fatty when it comes to good food and trying new place, we ask the chef can we have an custom omakase menu with of course including the O-Toro on the menu as well. The chef was nice enough to accommodate us with a wide variety of selection. The food is good, however for the price and portion it's not worth the value. You can get much better quality for a slightly better price and much better dinning experience at other restaurant such as Kusakabe near by. BUT this place stand out because of the no hassle, no reservation needed. For a party of 8 our total was around $1,100 including tips and 2 order of the yuzu sake. Overall, every friendly place and great if you want last minute spot for good food but couldn't get last minute reservation at other places.
author: Reeve N.

description:
I rarely give 5 star reviews, but I am struggling for a reason not to give them 5 stars. We didn't have a reservation, but there were seats at the end of the sushi bar, which is just as good. The waitress was the perfect combination of non-nonsense and helpful, and all of her suggestions were excellent. 

The sushi itself was incredibly tasty, each one having perfect texture and flavor. We shared two bottles of unfiltered sake which was phenomenal. We only left because the place was so busy we felt bad taking up two seats. Will return.
author: Jordan C.

description: There can be kind of a crazy wait here, but the sushi is fresh, the service is good and the atmosphere is nice. It's pretty cozy though even when you do finally get a table, so make sure that you are comfortable with getting to know your neighbors... :)
author: Lai-Nin W.

description:
it BLOWS my mind that this place has 4 stars. Most unjustified rating I've seen on Yelp in this last year. Maybe hayes valley dwellers need to get out more? ;)

Domo sushi, around the corner, is much better. So are most of the sushi spots in the mission (saru, kiji)

Cozy hayes valley spot. We sat at the bar and were stumped by the sushi menu. There were barely any sushi! 1.5 pages of japanese dishes and a small section of sashimi and sushi - and just the basic stuff. The specials menu was on a board to the left of the bar - we could barely read it from where we were sitting.

We had a tuna crudo "special" appetizer, the chicken karaage, and some sushi and sashimi. Everything was mediocre but at the "hip trendy hayes valley" pricing =[ 

We went for one more chance to salvage the experience by asking for Mochi for dessert. The waitress said they only had red bean mochi, which is fine - we don't discriminate when it comes to mochi ;) we went for an order each since we both loooove ice cream.

And then of course, out comes not the ice cream mochi, but rather a red bean paste filled rice wrap. And it was huge - about 2x the time of normal ice cream mochi.  Huge disappointment. She couldn't have told us it wasn't ice cream??
author: Alice Z.

description:
Ok, here we go. My first bad Yelp review.
I re-downloaded the Yelp app to write this.
Let me say, I love food. And I really love sushi. I sometimes have negative experiences at restaurants, but then I am full and content because, again, I love food without much reservation. 
But not tonight. 
I stopped with a friend at this restaurant to grab some take out. We ordered three rolls. After waiting 30 minutes, awkwardly standing in the doorway and watching other people eat, we went up to ask what was up but didn't get a word out before rudely being told it was not ready. So we wait another 15 min. When we were given our "meal" it is about on par with Safeway quality sushi. But smaller. And more expensive. And took 45 minutes.
So tonight I am hungry and not content. So I wrote my first bad Yelp review. I will now go to Taco Bell and be more satisfied.
author: Amelia H.

description:
Solid go-to sushi spot.

Whenever I'm craving some no-frills, real sushi, I turn to O-Toro and fortunately or unfortunately, that happens quite a bit! 

Located in the heart of Hayes Valley, O-Toro is cute, intimate and quaint with extremely fresh fish and a killer daily specials menu. The sake selection is great and it's usually not too hard to find room for 2 at the bar with no reservations. 

Here's what I recommend ordering: 
1. O-Toro (fatty tuna): Obviously this is the way to go. The 2 pieces are tender, fatty and the texture is so perfectly smooth
2. Scallops dynamite: Delicious baked scallops with a cheesy-mayo sauce
3. Cherry blossom roll: Yummy salmon, tuna and avocado roll 
4. O-Toro roll: Obviously another must-have with spicy tuna, avocado and mangoes

They also have a bottle of a delicious sparkling sake that pairs with all the fish so perfectly - ask the waiter/waitress for the name as it completely slips my mind! 

So on your next craving for some yummy sushi, consider heading over into the heart of charming Hayes Valley. 

Happy Eating, Yelpers!
author: Priya S.

description: Great Japanese fare ranging from the standard to the more unusual. If you ask the wait staff for recommendations for adventurous cuisine, they'll be candid with you. We went for a friend's bday and they sang happy bday AND brought out candled cheesecake :)
author: Nancy K.

description:
Mmmm...Otoro Sushi, what can I say? The only other experience where I've dined at a sushi restaurant that serves fresh fish flown in from Japan is Morimoto's in Philly but that's a whole stratosphere of experience.  Back to Otoro, we came pre-curtain for a romantic evening out.  

We started with the Hamachi carpaccio with truffle oil and that was heavenly.  We then ordered the fatty tuna sashimi ($30 for 5 pieces - the bf's eyes widened) which were awesome fresh and delicious.  Then we tried a couple of rolls and another small plate - all were good quality, well balanced in flavors and delicious.

Wine on top of that, dinner for two came up to shy of $200.  So not a cheap night but well worth it.  Do arrive early because the acoustics are bad, i.e. it gets loud when it gets busy - typical SF restaurant complaint.
author: Favoloso M.

description:
This was just average and pricey for what you get. The food was good, but it was nothing special. 

AMBIANCE: It's a very cozy restaurant with sushi bar and not that many tables. We made reservations on opentable so it wasn't a problem, but some people who walked in to a full restaurant opted to wait. 

FOOD: The dishes are small so it's like izakaya style where you order a bunch. However, there are also ramen and udon options if you want your own bowl of noodles. 
DO's: They have a good selection of nigiri sushi. We tried the toro, their namesake & at $12/2 pieces.... it's not cheap, but that's the usual. But toro is really rich & fatty, you should try it once in your life. Somewhere. Many of their rolls also sounded good. My favorite was the Kabocha tempura roll with albacore. Their sashimi was also pretty fresh and tasty. They like to boast that some of their fish is flown in from Japan, and I can believe it. I would also recommend the shishito peppers stuffed with albacore tuna, except a few of our peppers were a bit too charred in my opinion. 
DON'Ts: kalbi ($12). So we shouldn't have ordered kalbi from a "Japanese" restaurant. Smallest pieces of kalbi I've ever seen. For $12. The Hip-Hop roll was also pretty boooooring. I don't understand why people highlighted it on yelp. The scallop dynamite was also big on the mayonnaise, easy on the scallop, which I didn't care for as much. 

SERVICE: Average. Whatever. Mundane. Nothing special. A-OK. 

Don't be fooled by the abundance of good ratings here. This is really just average Japanese food in my opinion. I've had far better quality at comparable prices, or even less. I would definitely not wait for a table here, but if you're in the neighborhood and it's not busy, go in for some rolls or sashimi.
author: Sara S.

description: Anyone who didn't enjoy this place has no taste for great sushi. O-Toro is incredible, their dishes are consistently prepared to perfection and their Chefs are such a joy to interact with. The entire staff is friendly and knowledgeable and you will find plenty of traditional cuts of fish that are unavailable at lower end sushi restaurants. They're Sake menu is really great too!
author: Brice R.

description:
I'm not sure if it's just me but this place had me sticker shocked.

My last meeting was in the city and looking for a bite I stopped by this well reviewed spot. It was good. Fresh fish, attentive staff, with an atmosphere that is perfect for an intimate conversation or just to hangout.

With that said, I think it was a little over priced for the small portions we were served. The hamachi sashimi for example was $15 for 5 pieces which in some places could have been 2.5 and more affordable. I probably could have gotten a bit more for my money if I explored a little further into the city. 

On to the next spot!
author: Jerico P.

description: You got to try there sushi it is amazing so fresh one of the best sushi in San Francisco . I highly recommended you don't get despondent.
author: Helen D.

description: The fish was really fresh but the rice was a bit dry. The service was good. I really liked the baked mussels, uni rolls(there were two types) and some of the nigiri roles. The green tea cheesecake was a bit disappointing.
author: Chet L.

description:
This place was alright. Nothing special and definitely annoyed we waited 45 minutes to eat here. Wish we had just waited at Domo instead. 

Very pricey for the quality. We also saw our rolls sitting there for the longest time before they actually served it to us. Waitress barely checked up on us and knocked into my sake glass and spilled some while putting our food at our table. 

Sushi was nothing special. We got the lollipop roll which is adorable because it looks like an actual lollipop on a stick. Toro was yummy but then again it is toro. There was constant vibration coming from the ground and the large table behind us was CRAZY loud. I think they were friends with the manager/owner here. A table next to them got so annoyed they asked to move tables. Smart move. 

The sushi here is very forgettable. Would not dine here again.
author: Tiffany V.

description:
The thing I liked about this place was that they had a specials board with fresh fish flown in from Japan. I had a plate of nigiri with baby octopus (special), hamachi belly (special) and white tuna with garlic. I also had a side of edamame, miso soup and tried the plum sake. 

The hamachi belly was easily the star of the meal. It's just smoky enough and the fish was lovely and fresh. The white tuna was also quite tasty and the octopus was just ok. The edamame and miso soup were good and the plum sake was so sweet, it was pretty much dessert wine. It wasn't bad- I think it would appeal to the dessert wine lovers. I also tried my friend's roll which was a vegetarian roll with a seared salmon on top and it was good.

I liked that O-Toro catered to both roll lovers, like my friend, and nigiri lovers, like myself. The prices for nigiri ($5.50-12 for two pieces) were, in my opinion, much more reasonable than the special rolls which came in at around $15 for 7 pieces. I know that means the roll is less than the nigiri but nigiri is also more fish and the taste relies on the freshness and flavor of the fish more, so overall, I felt it was a better deal. 

I had a good time and would come back!
author: Ninette C.

description:
hmmmm, i think more like 3.5 stars.  might have been because i was feeling a bit under the weather, and so was my gf. we ordered an assortment of nigiri - ebi, salmon belly, o-toro, uni, unagi, aji, kanpachi, hotate, etc., and 2 rolls. the fish was good, but the rice wasn't warm and inviting like it is at kusakabe.. (we also didnt sit at the sushi bar, so perhaps that is a downfall..?) the rolls though, were not impressive. the rice was definitely soggy due to mayhaps the sauces and tasted average at best. sigh! but the service is very attentive, and they filled up our matcha teas diligently! overall i enjoyed the experience, but will not be back for the fish.. there are other items on the menu as well, soup noodles, hot plates, appetizers...

check came out to be ~$135 for food and tea.. which is pretty reasonable i guess, considering we ordered otoro twice.. ha!
author: Christina L.

description:
I've been to this place many times and have always had good service. Until this time. I was so disappointed my family has decided we will not go here again for a while.
This review is not about the dining service. Instead, it's about a take-out order. I called and placed an order for dinner 2 days ago. Everything is fine until I arrived to pickup our food. The food wasn't ready, but the male host decided it is not important to inform me. Instead, he wanted to take my payment the moment I walked in. When he returned with my cc, he did not feel it's important to make sure he handed it to me. So he carelessly left my cc and receipt on the railing which leads from the front door into the restaurant. This was not as if I'm sitting down at a table so it would be acceptable to leave it in front of me. He left it in the open, away from me, and did not bother to make sure I get it back. With that kind of carelessness with my cc, I do not think I'm going back for a while. After taking my payment, he left me standing by the door for a good 10 mins, never bothered to offer if I wanted to sit down.
Next the food. I ordered 3 different rolls and 1 special roll, total 4 orders. Imagine my surprise when the host handed me a single take-out container. The fact that a single take-out container holds food worth $41 was already shocking enough. When I arrived home, I discovered that not only was the portion small, but we can clearly see sushi being physically jammed into the container to make them fit. A large percentage of Japanese dining is on the presentation. This restaurant obviously does not take that in high regards. Some of my rolls were flat, like someone used their palm to try to compress it.
I'm so disappointed with the service I will not be coming back soon.
author: S K.

description: Fresh fish, maybe a little pricey for the quality. Enjoyed a bottle of sake, tempura, and a few sushi rolls. I was not as big a fan of the rice, which didn't feel as high quality as the fish and all of the other ingredients.
author: Avery A.

description:
I've been wanting to try this restaurant for some time because a friend had recommended it. It wasn't until my second try that I finally was able to make it happen. I highly recommend making reservations here. Even with reservations expect a small wait ~10-20 min. Without reservations expect a wait of over an hour. Due to the size of the restaurant, I don't recommend coming here with a group larger than 4. 2 is ideal though because they only have a few tables that can accommodate groups of 4. The food here is great and did not disappoint. Also the rolls are pretty large so keep that in mind when ordering.

What we ordered:
hamachi stuffed shisito peppers - delicious
karaage chicken - only OK. nothing special
Rolls - Cherry Blossom, Rainbow, Spicy Tuna
author: Alice H.

description:
We are staying for the week in Union Square. I started looking for a sushi restaurant by using Yelp (which has been spot on the whole trip- thank you everyone who writes a review!). The places close to the hotel looked decent but had quite mix of reviews - folks either loved or hated the places. I asked the hotel and they recommended some of those same ones.

So I continued to scroll the list and came across O-Toro. Not close to Union Square - caught a cab- in the Hayes neighborhood. But the reviews made it sound like a hidden gem - and they were right! 

We got an early reservation which was good as it was packed by the time we left. 

The sushi was wonderfully fresh - I had the sake sushi and Mauro. I also had the O-Toro roll which is spicy tuna with avocado and mango - amazing. My husband and son liked it commenting that the mango was particularly good in a way they did not expect. My son had 2 dragon rolls - and he generally does not love sushi. My husband had the mackerel appetizer and really enjoyed that.

We also had some ramen and udon. Those were so-so which is why I am given 4 instead of 5 stars. But the staff were very friendly and helpful and is definitely a place we would go again (lucky are those who live near by!)
author: Lisa J.

description: This is my first time at otoro. This is my first time eating otoro. This is the only place to do it. I'm never drinking water again. It was so good that me and my boyfriend ordered two more pieces at the very end just so I can walk out with its taste still in my mouth.
author: Gigi J.

description:
The shrimp on their hip hop was so amazing that we got the dragon too.

The otoro was fantastic too and the service all around was good.

Five stars.
author: Daniel Y.

description:
This review is based on their udon only. I did not have the sushi.

The reason why I am only giving this place two stars is because the udon was so not worth the money. $13.95 for flavorless udon is not my jam. We had both the beef and the chicken and it felt like I was just eating tasteless broth. I've had great udon and this was not it. I would not get it again here. Can't comment on the other food.
author: Viktoriya Z.

description:
How this place has an average of 4 stars is beyond me! 

We ordered the tempura, tori karaage (fried chicken), sake butteryaki, and a few rolls. The tempura and fried chicken was decent. The sake butteryaki and the rolls was extremely disappointing. There was virtually no tuna, hamachi in the rolls - it was all mayo and radish. The sake butteryaki - was literally salmon grilled with nothing. 

The service - the guys were nice. But they were understaffed and totally unorganized.

The only positive thing I can say is that it is small and intimate, with simple decor - so it could be a cute date spot.
author: Maxine W.

description: Good food, good service and pretty clean. Sushi was very much so fresh and the rolls were wrapped nicely. Perfect of amount of fish and rice on each dish. The manager guy in the front was super friendly and very helpful. Thank you for that!
author: Rebekah S.

description:
It was my first time making reservations via OpenTable directly on the Yelp site. Had a 9:45pm Friday night time reserved. Jimmy greeted us immediately as we walked in. They were packed Friday night so we (party of 2) waited for about 15 minutes before our table was avaiable. Jimmy apologized for the long wait.

The "specials" chalk board menu was hard to see from where we were seated so Jimmy dropped off an iPad with the specials for us!

Ordered:
-sake gold flight (3 different "gold" sakes)
-Tori chicken karaage
-Shitake Tsumire - mushroom stuffed with ground beef

Nirigi:
-toro 
-sake
-hamachi
-uni
-tobiko
-garlic albacore
-amaebi

Rolls:
-Cherry Blossom - salmon, avocado, topped with tuna
-lava - shrimp tempura, cucumber, topped with tuna

The sushi was great! Very fresh, melt in your mouth. I had uni one years ago and hated it..but my friend encouraged me to try it again. I had a little piece and actually loved it. It was fresh!

The service was great. Our tea and water were refilled promptly. The restroom was clean and they have an area back there to hang up your jackets.

The music was pretty loud and there's only a handful of tables so I'd suggest making a reservation.

Can't wait to come back for more sushi!
author: Tim Y.

description:
We came here before the symphony on a Wednesday night.  The place isn't big and very typical of a sushi place in terms of decor, didn't have the vibe of the neighborhood which I was hoping for.  The place is pretty small and while some comments said full bar, it wasn't, just wine, beer and sake.  

The sushi was not great, it was bland, not creative and absolutely no flavors.  The fish compared to rice portion was nice, they definitely didn't skimp on the fish. It also seemed like it was quickly spalled together rather than expertly put together.  The restaurant just didn't leave an impression of wanting to come back especially when we have an amazing place right around the corner from our house.  If you're not a sushi lover, there are other items on the menu so they do have a variety.
author: Inga W.

description:
O-toro 

Address: 205 Oak St, San Francisco, CA 94102

We ordered salmon & white tuna sashimi, so expensive, 15.95 for 5 pieces! The ramen is the worst I have ever had in San Francisco. Look at the egg, it's fully boiled. The miso soup tastes like alcohol, I'm not sure the ingredients in the soup. As an Japanese Restaurant, they can't even make good ramen. I has to say it's very disappointed experience.
author: Vanessa Z.

description:
Went for a late lunch at O-Toro to try them out.  Had the worst service from the bald Asian guy.  I took some pics and the guy yelled at me "no pictures" oh right, cuz he hasn't seen the 77 pics on Yelp right?

Then he asked if I wanted table or bar.  As a single diner bar is always the better spot.  He didn't ask the other single people after me.

FREE tea but only if you ask for it.  Water not given automatically.

Got the chirashi $16.75 - instead of making my meal, he makes the table behind me first even though they had just ordered more food, but I hadn't gotten anything yet.  Only 7 small slices of fish & lots of rice.  Guy had to remind him to put ginger & wasabi.

Garlic albacore $4.50 - 2 pcs of nigiri, nothing special.

One unisex bathroom.  Charged it.

Not a satisfying meal, wish I went somewhere else.
author: Ann L.

description:
This place is a hit or miss.

One time the fish was super fresh and delicious. The next time it was eh...

It's a reliable choice when I want sushi but I don't want to go far.

I came for lunch and ordered the Chirashi...and was shocked at the lack of variety and the small portion. I know it's a lunch item but $20 for what I got wasn't really worth it.

It almost turns me off from coming back because I feel so ripped off. But we'll see. I might cave since it's an 'okay' place to get sushi when I want it most.
author: Sujin Y.

description:
Just had dinner there tonight! Highly recommend reservations, the place was almost full at 7 PM and by 7:30, had a few groups waiting. Called earlier in the afternoon and had no problems putting my name down for 7:15.

The Pork Belly was definitely the highlight! Can't say that 2 pieces for $8.95 was easy to justify though. Flavor was perfection and it was fatty goodness, but the price is steep for the two layered hunks of meat/fat/skin that you receive in a small bowl. 

Rainbow Roll + Lava Roll were just fine. Appreciated that the shrimp tempura in the Lava was crunchy, even after 20 min, and that the Rainbow Roll had real crab in it. However, the flavors for both were underwhelming and generally not impressive. They both tasted like rolls ordered at any other sushi establishment, albeit smaller, less tasty, and more expensive.

Service was okay. Took a noticeable while to get my friend's and my orders taken and to receive our food, and only received a check-in/water refill at the end of the meal. 

Also, $4.95 for one piece of red bean mochi was no bueno. My friend hadn't had it in a while so he opted for it, but I would personally get dessert anywhere else. We even got Loving Cup rice pudding after the meal, since we weren't full!    

Would come back only if in the area, rejected by Domo, and keeling over from sushi cravings. And even then, there are plenty of other yummy restaurants in Hayes Valley to check out, so this may have been a one-time visit.
author: Tina Y.

description:
Excellent sushi and great service! I really like how they have fish flown from Japan. Be prepared to spend money!

For my boyfriend and I, we got Hiphop, Lava Roll, and Otoro #2. We got the two piece of barracuda flown from Japan. And I highly recommend the hamachi carpaccio, it is well worth the $18! We also got the tempura and our total came out to be around $100.

Would i come again? Yes!
author: Linda X.

description:
SOMEONE forgot to plan dinner before the theater.. and that somebody was my husband.  Okay fine, it was me.  I was in my regular groove of volunteering at the animal shelter after work on Fridays, and we had Book of Mormon (hilarious, btw) tickets for 8 PM that night.  Somehow I was like, I'll just head straight from volunteering, covered in animal hair and saliva (we call it "love"), right over to the theater, easy!

Luckily O-Toro had reservations available at 5:30, so I left my furry friends a bit early and met my husband there.  It is a small, cozy, clean joint away from the hustle and bustle of Hayes Valley's main shopping/eating streets.   A few tables were occupied when we got there, but halfway through our meal, it filled up.

We went for: tempura udon, lava roll, agedashi tofu, seaweed salad, gyoza, and the beef skewers.

Stars: tempura udon (but then again, I'm a huge noodle soup fan, so anything on a cool evening is good), lava roll, agedashi tofu.

Okay: seaweed salad (super tiny portion)

Pass: beef skewers (super overcooked), gyoza (no flavor)

Service was great, and they had lots of menu options that are all very reasonably priced.  Love the location as well - great for a pre-theater dinner, or pre-Smitten ice cream meal!
author: Tori S.

description:
We had a nice time at O-Toro last night. Probably the best thing we ate was a chef's choice selection of sashimi. Unbelievably fresh and delicately delicious. 

We had a tasty dragon roll too. The tempura was good. The soft shell crab had too much breading and was cooked too long or something - the "crust" was nice and crispy and garlicky, but you couldn't taste the crab at all. 

I think you can wait a long time if you just drop in, but they do take reservations. Since I live closer to Ebisu and prefer it, I wouldn't go out of my way to go to O-Toro, but it's a very good option for pre Symphony/Opera/Ballet/SFJazz/City Arts & Lectures....
author: Gwynnie P.

description:
Definitely one of my most favorite Japanese restaurants in SF. Casual, intimate, friendly, modern atmosphere, and above all, deliciously served food... truly a no brainer. 

Upon entering O-Toro's doors, you'll find just how perfectly small and cozy it is. Enough to seat parties of 4 and 6, yet close enough to make you feel as if you're not being lost in a huge chain. 

Immediately greeted by the host, you're shown your seat and placed with a menu in front as well as a hot towel to wipe your hands with before your meal. Otoro has constant specials going on and mouth watering seasonal dishes. I've tried both their lunch and dinner menu and have been equally satisfied with both. The sashimi is incredibly fresh and presentation has always been absolutely perfect. 

I always seem to start with good ol' miso soup, a wonderfully flavored broth. Their tapas are delicious! Hawaiian poke, agedashi tofu, ankimo monkfish pate, plain edamame, halibut and amberjack sashimi to start. OMG soooooo good. The portions are perfect for just a little taste of everything. Also, perfect for sharing! The actual sushi rolls were equally tasty! I've had most of the rolls, but I think the Cherry Blossom remains as my fave! Then again, it's so hard to choose! All washed down with sake or sapporo, but of course!

If you're in the Hayes Valley neighborhood, be sure to stop by and try out some amazing Japanese food!
author: Ann S.

description:
Consistently good.

I'm always torn between ordering sushi or an actual entree. Lucky for me, Jocelyn W is always willing to split a roll with me ^_^

Service is always great here and he's always smiling! 

Saba shioyaki. DO IT.
author: Susy C.

description:
Double date night! We came here on a recommendation and we were not disappointed.

Location: Prime Hayes Valley location.

Ambiance: Smaller than one would think from the outside, but it makes it more intimate. Great mood lighting for a date night. There's table seating and bar seating.

Food: Excellent sashimi. Their hip hop roll is also pretty good. We ordered two salmon sashimi's, the hip hop roll, the spicy tuna with mango roll, and spider roll. We also ordered some edamame and the asparagus with kobe beef appetizer. The asparagus with kobe beef was really good. The sashimi was definitely fresh, and I thoroughly enjoyed all the rolls we chose. 

Drinks: They have a variety of sake and wine options. We ordered a couple bottles of wine for our meal and I loved both of them.

Price: Not too bad for sushi in SF.

Would I return? Definitely a solid spot for sushi! Glad I found another alternative aside from Blowfish sushi.

PRO TIP: Make reservations. This place fills up fast and it's small!
author: Leana L.

description: I have lived in SF for 15 years, and tried most Sushi restaurants.  O'toro is hands down my favorite sushi restaurant. The fish is so fresh you cannot beat it.
author: Chelsea C.

description: The service and food here is great and very fresh. I always order the chicken terriyaki and they are always accommodate minor changes. The chicken consistently tastes fresh and never too salty l.   Great sushi restaurant with good lunch menu. The staffs are very warm and nice as well. My yelp order is always prepared on time.  I am a weekly customer and will definitely bring friends to share
author: Tran K V.

description:
Sushi:
2 piece hamachi was SUPER fresh with the perfect meaty fish to delicate rice ratio.

Udon:
Got the tempura udon. Flavorful broth, but noodles could be softer.

Call ahead and get a reservation. This place is small. Would recommend for an intimate dinner or at the most 4 people. There were many couples having date nights when my friend and I were there.
author: Ana P.

description:
O-toro O-toro. Getting to Hayes Valley can kind of be a pain in the ass but it seems to house some of the cutest little restaurants so I drag myself there every so often. The place is super small and it's usually about a 30 min wait to get a table in the evenings. The food didn't astound me but then again, I only had some sake and one roll so it wouldn't be a fair judgment. 

There are better places in the area.
author: Tania S.

description: I stopped here around 8:45 on a Friday night. I didn't have a reservation and was dining solo. I waited for about 30 minutes for a seat at the bar but it was worth the wait. I had the Poke, Lava Roll, blue fin tuna nigiri, and Amber jack nigiri. Everything was delicious and the wait staff was very patient with me after I accidentally knocked over my wine. It's not cheap sushi by any means but it was definitely the best I've had out of the 3 places I've tried this trip. All in it was $75 with tip. I will be back the next time I'm in town.
author: Samantha W.

description: Home made Gyoza! Omg it's so good. Best Gyoza in SF by far. The fish is fresh and beautiful in cut and color. The staff is friendly and prices are fair for the quality. Will be back!
author: Vanessa L.

description: Horrible service. It took me 40 minutes to get miso soup. Didn't make it to the sushi and the appetizers were not impressive.
author: Valerie B.

description:
I came here with a friend at around 8:30, and the wait was about half an hour; no biggie. You kinda have to expect some sort of wait for a place this small. 

As others have mentioned, the service was pretty subpar, and this is coming from someone who normally doesn't pay attention to service. Growing up with Chinese restaurants has made me not care if a restaurant's staff is rude or unwelcoming. As long as I get my food in a timely manner, I'll be happy. When we were seated, we ordered a small bottle of sake which never came. By the time we figured that we weren't gonna get our sake, we just decided to not have it, and it wasn't charged on our bill. 

The food wasn't that great, either. There were some real quality issues with the fish here. They were out of certain fish that day, so maybe it's been a while since the previous shipment?

Ankimo - A lot of the ankimo pieces tasted a bit too fishy. The texture also could've been smoother, and chunks kept falling apart when I tried picking them up.

Otoro Sashimi - I liked that the pieces of fatty tuna were pretty large, but there was a lot of connective tissue that made it tougher. The center of each slice was also cold. This made the tuna not taste as rich or have that melt in your mouth effect because the fat didn't render.

Halibut Sashimi - Dry and a little rubbery.

Saba - Fishy, and the texture was a bit tough.

Garlic Albacore Nigiri - The albacore was very mushy.

Amaebi - Could've been sweeter, but the fried heads didn't taste bad. The batter was a bit thick though, and the head was strangely stale. My friend complained that hers tasted very bitter.

Glazed Black Cod - This was probably the best fish of the meal. It was rich and smooth, but the glaze was too sweet for my liking. It got in the way of the fish's natural flavor.

Originally, we were planning to add some more food to our small order, but we didn't feel like staying. For the price, I think there are a lot better options for Japanese food in the city.
author: Nei N.

description: Had a lunch combo salmon teriyaki and tempura. The salmon was huge and full of flavor. The tempura was done just right with grated daikon in the dipping broth. The Japanese potato tempura reminded me of moms cooking. So good. Most of the time places use yam so it was nice to get the satsumaimo. Can see why they get listed in the Michelin guide. Only 4stars because it was $20 for lunch which means it's a bit out of the price range for everyday lunch. Might have to try the oyakodon to see if they might be reasonable.
author: tomohisa w.

description:
Loved Otoro! Sushi was delicious!

To start, Otoro does this wonderful thing where they take reservations. So you show up at your reservation time and don't have to wait at all, it's brilliant! Here's to wishing more sushi places follow suit.

The sushi at Otoro was incredibly fresh and tasty. We mostly got nigiri sushi, trying a bunch of different rolls from their specials (they even fly fish in from Japan!). Yum, yum. The rolls came out pretty fast, especially considering that that Otoro was pretty busy!

We also tried the hamachi carpaccio - do not leave Otoro without getting this! It's a delightful mix of hamachi and avocado and mango that makes my mouth water thinking about it.

Thinking of a complaint about Otoro is hard, but the tables are a bit too close together (like a lot of places in SF). The toddler on one side was kicking me and the group on the other joined in one of our conversations.

Not to worry - the sushi here makes up for everything! Looking forward to going back ASAP!
author: Emily L.

description:
What happens when one pregnant girl goes to dinner with four other girls and four of the five are craving sushi?  

You guessed it... they end up at O-Toro!  

This was my "girls night out" this past Wednesday night, and it worked out just fine!  O-Toro had plenty of alternatives to raw fish which made me (the pregnant one) very happy.  I had the mixed green salad, the black cod appetizer, veggie tempura, and a side of rice.  The others had lots and lots of sushi including some specialty rolls that looked delicious.  O-Toro has quite the variety and great presentation to go with it.  I will definitely need to return after Baby M arrives.  Oh, and my ice water went down easy but I think everyone else's saki and beer went down even easier!

Service was actually really slow at our corner table, but I was in good company, so I didn't mind.  I would suggest either sitting at the sushi bar for faster service or choosing another restaurant if you're not in the mood for a "leisurely" meal.

Oh, and I am referring to myself and the rest of my party as "girls." I hope that doesn't offend anyone!
author: Gabi M.

description:
I absolutely love this place.
O toro is where my husband and I go for our wedding anniversary dinner.
The staff is amazing and so are the sushi chefs.
They have the time and patience to make you something which is not on the menu.
The quality of sushi is great.
I wish they would get a bigger place to accommodate all the people who have to stand in queue for their turn to be seated.
author: Alina H.

description: Literally my favorite sushi restaurant.  Jimmy is absolutely amazing, the fish is so fresh.  We moved to Marin about a year ago and I eat here every time I have the chance.  The pork belly is delicious too ;)
author: Rebecca J.

description:
After eating here a handful times now, I must say, O-toro is becoming one of my favorite sushi joints. Anywhere that has (access to) sea bream, amberjack and butterfish  when they're in season from Japan --- is on my list. I love how quaint the environment is, how bustling the energy is - esp on busy nights, and even how close together the tables are (I have a little Euro in me). 

I think O-toro is quality sushi. 

But don't expect to get out of there under $60/pp.
author: Meredith R.

description: Just as it states a sushi bar. Nothing stood out. The o-toro was good. Nice and fatty. I also order hikado uni, which wasn't that fresh tasting to me. The ikura wasn't very tasteful. Although the spicy tuna roll was good.
author: Viet P.

description:
Decided to come to this restaurant spontaneously with my boyfriend because we wanted sushi for the night and saw that this place was 4stars in the neighborhood we were close to. Don't get me wrong the food was alright the golden state was on point along with the rainbow roll. However, the California roll, spicy tuna and the hip hop roll were average just because it doesn't taste as fresh, like it's been out for a while. 

Now about their service......

1. We just walked in got greeted welcome which gets us excited to be there, but after that all we got was a stare down, then the waitresses kept walking pass us and we had no idea whether or not to seat ourselves or to just stand there until someone decides to seat us... Afterwards they had their manager seat us after he contemplate for 5 mins if he should because he had some reservations coming in...
2. One waitress came over with a dirty plate, smiled and greeted us asking what we wanted for drinks. My boyfriend couldn't hear her because it was too loud in there with everyone chatting it up. So he thought she meant are you ready to order which led him to list what we wanted. Then she interrupts saying I can't take your order right now as you can see my hands are full I can't write anything down, all I asked was what drinks would you like I'll get them first then take your order when I get back with your drinks. And when we took our order she was giving attitude, speaking to us like we were dumb.
Honestly, couldn't she be a bit more patient besides making us feel uncomfortable, like we don't belong there.
3. When we decide to split the bill with cash and card, the waitress took it and we were waiting, wondering what is taking so long for me to get my card back. 10 mins later the manager came with the cash and card asking if we were paying cash, then putting the rest on the card. We looked at each other and said yes... in our heads, we had no idea what they thought the cash of $60 would-be for, we think that they thought they got $60 for tip..

I don't mean to give a 2 star, I barely do that. But I didn't enjoy my experience here it seem as if everyone around us had fun or enjoyed their time. I just don't understand why we were being treated with this service all night.
author: Victoria G.

description:
Enjoyed a fantastic dinner here with a group of friends; the sushi is delicious, and I loved every specialty roll we tried. 

We made a day-of reservation for 9:30 PM, and due to the small, intimate space, still had to wait 25 minutes or so for our table. Since we weren't in a rush, we didn't mind, but this is something to keep in mind if dinner is the first thing on your night's itinerary. 

As I mentioned, O-toro is a small space - there are only a handful of tables and some spots at the bar. Our party of 5 fit comfortably, but I'm not sure much larger groups would be able to sit together so I'd call and ask before arriving. 

Once seated, we ordered appetizers, including the baked green mussel and stuffed shishito peppers. Both were flavorful and tasty, though the shishito peppers were my top pick if I had to choose. These pack heat so be warned if you have sensitive tastebuds!

When it came to sushi, our group decided to divide and conquer, ordering almost every specialty roll on the menu. My favorites included the Otoro, Golden State, Hip Hop, and Dreamy Sensation. I highly recommend trying these four as the flavors and fish vary enough that you can appreciate the quality and variety of a number of rolls, yet they all complement each other nicely. 

There are a lot of reviews for O-toro that say it's overpriced, but I was pleasantly surprised at how low our bill was given how much food and drinks we ordered. It might be better to come here with more people so you can try more dishes and split the cost, which is what we did.
author: Meg R.

description:
Looking for a late snack after a concert at the symphony hall and saw O-Toro popped up on Yelp app search result. The instant I saw the name O-Toro, I was drooling (in my mind thankfully) like Pavlov's Dog. 

The restaurant is stylish but very tiny. There are only 6 to7 tables and a small sushi counter. All tables were already filled when we arrived but fortunately it was only a short wait. Seated at the sushi counter right in front of their daily special chalkboard. I was delighted to find out they have Butterfish, one of my favorite sashimi cut. To those who haven't tried raw butterfish, the texture is actually not buttery but rather firm and crisp. The butterfish nigiri I ordered was of good quality. Sawara (Barracuda) nigiri, garnished with green onions and radish, was fresh and flavorful.

The maki were quite delightful as well. Ordered two of their specials - Takashi (Pumpkin Tempura top with Garlic Albacore) and Omega Spicy (Avocado top with Salmon Belly). Takashi was great. The garlic sauce on albacore topping was a good contrast to the mellow sweet pumpkin tempura. The salmon belly topping on the Omega Spicy was amazing. They were these kisses that melt in your mouth and leave a lingering sensation on your tongue. Unfortunately the filling was plain and the portion is tiny. They are really quite stingy with the sashimi toppings. Krabby (eel Avocado and Snow Crab) on the regular menu was good but ordinary. 

Many patrons ordered their warm izakaya dishes that looked quite promising. I heard they serve bi-rite ice-cream. You really can't go wrong with that. The decor of O-Toro might look posh and trendy but the service, despite being a bit slow at times, was friendly and down to earth. It is one of those neighborhood gem that the locals love. 

I am quite happy with the quality of their sushi. Would love to return again and really order some otoro.
author: Mona W.

description:
Okay, so this place has some bomb food. 
However, they lost our reservation and we ended up waiting an hour to be seated. 
*GRUMPY FACE* 
They did make it up however by giving my table a free large sake, and you know that made everyone happy! 
Overall, excellent food, a bit on the pricey side, but I would return for a special occasion.
author: Muriel M.

description:
This is a cozy place to enjoy Japanese food!

Great fresh sushi and cold/hot tapas!

It is pricey but definitely worthy to try!
author: Sujung S.

description:
So, this place. As you can see I wasn't that impressed with though it was a solid spot with great prices, nice decor in a super chill 'hood. What didn't do it for me you ask? The sushi duh. I went with some friends and we went family style ordering a bit of everything including edamame, rolls, sashimi, bulgogi (short ribs) and more rolls. I really didn't love anything though all of it was aight. My friends did enjoy the food but, lets be honest, I'm much more into food and actually write Yelp reviews so I'm a little more into the details.

Everyone on Yelp writes about this spicy tuna roll which I just wasn't a fan. I do like that they change up this otherwise boring roll with mango but, similar to most spicy tuna rolls, the fish just didn't taste that fresh and it was a Saturday night. Other rolls included the Golden State in which the lemon on top was crazy over powering and not subtle at all and the Cherry Blossom with salmon and tuna, which was quite delightful and my favorite of the evening. The short ribs weren't that meaty and extremely charred. Though to be honest I've never had the rib version of the dish. I always find it delicious and heavenly in my burrito or rice dish so, I really don't have much to compare it to rib style but again wasn't the hugest fan. 

Overall, we didn't pay a boat load for in my opinion for quite a bit of sushi and a few beers and if in the 'hood definitely check it out, you can tell it's quite popular. Personally, I think I'll keep exploring SF.

** Small place and would suggest reservations but, on a Sat night a table for 3 at 7:45 PM was a 20 minute wait.
author: Stephanie Y.

description: Very reasonably priced for the quality of fish. Order some appetizers and several nigiri - agadashi tofu, black cod, Amaebi, toro, hotate, blue shrimp. Everything was very good. Amaebi was delicious with one of the large heads I've had, which happens to be my fav. They also have blue shrimp which not that many places have.
author: Lillian V.

description:
Otoro Sushi, San Francisco, has very good food. We ordered sashimi, sushi, seaweed salad, sautéed mushrooms, and miso soup that my friend and I shared. The sashimi and sushi were quite fresh; we especially liked the salmon and the scallops. The sautéed mushrooms were excellent. The 2 waitresses were attentive and polite.  The prices were reasonable for SF.

The place is small so I recommend reservations.
author: Robert H.

description:
This place is terrible for 3 simple reasons:

1- the staff is RUDE (they will demand that you have a reservation even if they are empty)
2- they are stingy with fish and the fish isn't great
3- their non-sushi dishes are disgusting (I had their chicken soba an the chicken was almost unrecognizable) 

On top of that, they have a $25 min per credit card and are not accommodating
author: Andrew T.

description:
Good sushi, but BEWARE!
They'll charge you if you have ginger more than what they think it's appropriate!
author: Amir A.

description:
Best sushi in SF. If you find somewhere better, tell me, because so far there have been no true contenders!

Even the udon and teriyaki are delicious - this is a genuine Japanese gem.

Also, friendly and helpful service at both the sushi bar and tables. Came early once to a reservation and they were helpfully accommodating!
author: Crystal M.

description: Sat at the bar. The people were friendly but service was definitely a little slow. I do not recommend the ramen at all. It was not very good at all, but the Sushi was great! and the Chicken karage was also delicious!
author: Bori B.

description:
On my first visit to Otoro the host told my date and me and another couple that he had a four top and wondered if we'd be up for sharing. The response from the four of us was pretty unanimous - if sitting with strangers meant eating sooner we were up for it. It ended up being a really fun night of sharing stories with new friends and tons of really great food (a mixture of cooked dishes and sushi).

On my second visit to Otoro I came with seven other friends; problem was I'd only made a reservation for six. Again the same affable host made it work (starting with nigori near the bar and then moving us to a table). I sat across from our group's vegan and ate mostly veggie sushi this go round. I enjoyed myself as much, if not more, than the previous visit.

Standouts: garlic soft shell crab, spicy tuna roll (seriously, this one is special), spinach goma-ae, BI-RITE toasted coconut ice cream.

Otoro is tiny and usually packed so make a reservation before turning up.
author: Miriam W.

description:
This is my go to sushi place in my 'hood. Jimmy and the rest of the staff are great and they have probably the best toro nigiri I've had EVER. The hip hop rolls are an ingenious. And, best of all, THEY HAVE CHICKEN HEARTS! Yeah, I know...that sounds very gruesome of a thing for me to eat, but I'm not heartless (obviously it's the chickens that are heartless now...HA HA HA....get it? Yeah...that was bad). Their grilled chicken hearts are one of my favorite appetizers ANYWHERE. 

In summary (haiku style):

If I had nostrils
Like Huggy Bear's I'd snort lines
Of their chicken hearts
author: Bill J.

description:
Really liked the sushi here albeit quite expensive for the size of the rolls.
I really enjoyed the pumpkin tempura roll with garlic albacore on top. Service was nice and the location is convenient to grab some Smitten ice cream after! :)
author: Angela D.

description:
After reading the great reviews, we had high hopes, even though the prices were a little higher than normal ($8 for a California roll?). 

The positives - sushi was fresh, they can do brown rice instead of white, and the edamame was good. 
Now the bad - the rolls were way too small, we asked how many pieces were in the specialty rolls (assuming there would be 8) and she confirmed there would be 8 so of course we were disappointed when only 6 baby pieces showed up on the plate, the servers were sassy, the prices are too high for what you get, and they didn't have fried rice (let down). We've definitely had better sushi in the city for much less $ and actually left full
author: Anna F.

description:
I came here since this was my friend's favorite place to go to and this place did NOT disappoint! I got the sushi that had pumpkin tempura in it and it was delicious! The pumpkin (asian) was sweet and creamy and it complemented the raw fish perfectly. 

We also go this sushi lollipop thing which was light and fresh but perhaps I would choose something different next time. Also we got the rainbow roll which is quite delicious and fresh.  Overall, the fish was fresh and delicious and I can't wait to try the other things they have on the menu! 

I'm sure I'll be coming here more often
author: Meena N.

description: While visiting SF I was very excited to experience some local sushi. I have been blown away by O-Toro. Hostess and waitress very friendly. Ordered Fresh Salmon, Blue Fin Tuna and Spicy Scallop. The Spicy Scallops were so amazing I ordered a second round! Salmon and Tuna were also very good. Ordered the Hip Hop roll and it was just okay. Cozy and happy place.
author: Melanie M.

description:
Came here for the second time and ordered off the specials this time. Still absolutely impeccable. Good wine list too. 
Hands down worth all the rave and even wait this time on a Wednesday night (no reservation but we're able to sit down after about 20 min wait at around 8:30pm).
All the sashimi is superbly prepared! Everything on that menu is tasty!!
author: Van-Anh N.

description: All the food I had were very very good. Very fresh fish, one of the best sushi restaurant I ever been to.
author: Hongcheng Y.

description:
Disappointed by the stunningly mediocre quality of fish and preparation, given the price point of about $80 pre-tax and pre-tip for a mid-sized one-person meal. The restaurant was also very loud to the point where it was uncomfortable. 

I tried to like the place, I really did. But I was sorely disappointed and although I tipped well because this isn't the fault of the service workers, I won't be coming back.
author: Hans H.

description: Fish is fresh, but very expensive. I got the omakase 78 and my friend ordered a mix of hot and cold dishes that came up to 98.
author: Mona L.

description:
I loved this place.
Atomosphere is really nice. Interior is stylish so good for the dates but can be stil casual. Servers are friendly. 
Sushi tasted delicious. 

I ordered Uni, salmon, Otoro, Amaebi, Ikura, hamchi and sapporo beer. 
With order of Amaebi, they deep fries head of amaebi(sweet shrimp), they also tastes yummy:) 
One thing about Ikura though, some people might find them a little bit different from other place, because Ikura here are already marinated in soysauce(?and other stuff), so they are already flavored. It's good though. 

Plus, servers and Sushi chefs are nice and sweet. 
I will be back soon! 

P.S This place is not a big place, so probably not a good place for groups.
author: Mii L.

description:
This place has been on my list to visit for some time now. The most notable thing I can remember was the really delicious, fresh melt-in-your mouth sashimi which brought this from 3.5 to 4 stars for me. As for the other stuff:

Kakuni (pork belly) - wasn't that great as we got 98% fat and zero meat - Overall I've had much better at other Ramen shops in the city.

Soft shell crab - just ok, kind of salty with all the other stuff on the plate

Hip Hop roll - pretty good although I wish their selection of rolls were more diverse for a pricey place like this

Shiitake Tsumire (stuffed mushtrooms) - surprisingly really good - you can't go wrong with this dish if you love mushrooms

In general, I would only come here for sashimi - their selection of rolls wasn't to my liking at all and the other items just didn't wow me. I'll stick to my beloved Elephant Sushi.
author: Sandy T.

description:
The rolls are inventive and some of the combinations are pretty interesting, but unfortunately the service really has consistently been one of the worst experiences I've had in the city, and has been consistent over multiple trips.  If you seem to be a low spending table, it'll take a while for you to get seated, and on top of that, the staff really does prioritize the other guests, especially if they're getting higher margin drinks (my party has noticed this over the multiple visits that we've gone).  If you don't get higher priced items the waitresses won't even bother serving you until the very last minute, and will act surprised if you try to even ask for the check.

I am really forgiving on many experiences, but the consistently bad experience that I've had at the restaurant made me throw up my hands and give up on it.
author: Scott S.

description: We LOVE this place! Although it's a little far from our place, we'll travel to get our sushi kick. The place is small - so make reservations if you can. I like their sushi, agedashi tofu- especially their special roll that has japanese pumpkin (kabocha) tempura roll.
author: Megan M.

description: Incredible! Some of the best nigiri style sushi I've had. Recommend making reservations though, the seating area is quiet small.
author: Cody A.

description: always friendly, attentive staff! we always feel so welcome and the food is always fresh and delicious. one of our favorite sushi spots in the city, have been going for years and never been disappointed.
author: Josephine H.

description:
Cool location in the Hayes Valley. I like how Rich Table is right in the same area(walkable distance). I can get my drinks after eating at O-Toro Sushi. 

Food - Generally, i like what they have in their tapas but not that big fan of their rolls. The ankimo is actually one of the best ive had in the city. They used like a citrus based sauce or something but its really refreshing for the palate. Their chicken skin and hearts, beef tongue and spare ribs are really good too. But i wasnt happy with the rolls. it was good but its very typical(like i could have it somewhere else at a cheaper price). There was nothing much special with the taste of the rolls( I had the Spider, Dragon and Cherry Blossom). So i felt like it wasnt worth the money. 

Ambiance and Service- Theyre both good. The place is quiet enough that you can talk to each other but still have the feeling of a lively atmosphere and the service is really good. I always got my water and tea filled, and they always ask how the food is. So, im generally happy with it. 

Overall, i would go here if im in the area, but i wouldnt drive all the way here (unless if its for the ankimo).
author: Cavin T.

description: Great sushi. Easy going atmosphere and good for families too. Very accommodating with kids. Fresh tasting and highly recommend the Saba and Philadelphia rolls!
author: Miss C.

description:
We call and they say "no wait" and then arrive 10 minutes later and there are "no tables available" and "a really long wait" because "all the tables are reserved" (even though they're empty). 

Get your sh!t together guys.
author: Jordan H.

description:
I met someone for an early Saturday dinner before heading to the opera, and this was their recommendation. I'll be back.

It's a tiny place, so unless you're eating at 5:30pm (like we were), reservations are probably important. We were initially seated at a table by default, but then decided we'd prefer to sit at the bar and they moved us quickly and with no problem.

We stuck with the sushi (no rolls) -- unagi, salmon, salmon roe, amberjack, and miso soup. While not cheap, it was all excellent, and I would gladly come back and pay at O-Toro vs. other places. The rice was a perfect consistency, the fish slices generous, and the flavors rich and buttery. I was impressed by my first bite, and that wasn't an anomaly. High marks for the meal.

The atmosphere was quiet and calm (but not casual) and had a "neighborhood restaurant" feel, with good, prompt, but non-intrusive service. As mentioned, we were there early in the day when they were half-full, so it's possible that things get louder and service gets more curt when they have a full house.
author: Dan C.

description:
cozy atmosphere, fresh fish, no stern-faced server/sushi chef, no signs that says that the restaurant reserves the right to refuse service to its clients, just what one looks for in a japanese place.

Dishes that I liked:
Uni sushi
o-toro sushi
giant clam appetizer (clam sashimi cut to 5 pieces served in a shell)
mini-daiginjo (not too dry not too sweet sake, perfectly balanced)
pork belly (very tender!)

what to avoid:
kobe wrapped asparagus -- kobe beef was a bit too chewy around the asparagus. I like the bacon-wrapped asparagus version in izakaya much better.
author: Rebecca C.

description:
Made our reservation on Open Table and our table was waiting for us.

Very fresh fish and absolutely delicious. But nothing out of the ordinary that knocked our socks off.

Service was very attentive and orders were quick to come from the kitchen. We ordered a couple of extra rolls. They have a specials board with some very unique fish.

The only thing that kept it from being 4 or 5 stars was the price and the fact the food was very good but not amazing. Just very fresh but very ordinary sushi. For the price, it needs to be amazing. 

I noticied that Yelp has changed the rating to three $$$. I gave them four $$$$.

We paid about $70 per person with tax and tiip to leave feeling full. Dishes like pork bellies and scallops were tiny for the price, upwards of $12 a dish. For two pieces of pork belly or four tiny scallops.

And we did not order any alcohol. This place is not good if you are on a budget. I will label O-Toro as very expensive.

Still, my all time favorite is Elephant Sushi on Hyde Street. At 33% less than O-Toro.

Was worth a visit, but I won't be returning.
author: Norm G.

description: pretty small place which could mean a long wait, amazing service, fairly basic but delicious and fresh rolls. I really liked the vibe of the place and would come here again
author: Melissa T.

description:
Yesterday, I joined several colleagues for lunch here. While the spicy tuna and the spicy hamachi tasted fine at the time, within an hour, I was frighteningly ill. My face, neck, chest and arms turned fire engine red, my head was pounding, my stomach pained, my vision was blurring and I was light headed. And I wasn't alone! Two of my dining companions, who also had sushi, experienced the same symptoms. I was lucky that I didn't have diarrhea and vomiting, but one of my colleagues did. The diagnosis? Scombroid food poisoning, which is a toxic reaction to eating spoiled dark fish. 

Today I called the restaurant to alert them, and I was surprised by how non-plussed the gentleman who answered was. He wanted to know why I hadn't called yesterday? "Because I was in misery and wanted to die!" He said no one else had called to complain, which is untrue because one of my dining companions also called Otoro. 

I obviously won't go back, and I hope no one else felt so horrible after eating there yesterday.
author: Pam W.

description:
This was a difficult review to write.  My last favorite sushi restaurant changed owners a few months ago and I haven't found another to replace it.  Unfortunately after coming here a few times, O-Toro is not the replacement restaurant, it is however very good, hence why this review was a difficult one for me.

O-Toro is a small restaurant mid block on Oak Street, between Octavia and Gough.  They have roughly 7-8 bar seats and maybe 6 tables.  The wait during lunch isn't ver long, but reservations are your best bet.  The ambiance is excellent, the staff is wonderful and attentive.

The sushi is incredibly fresh, I don't have any criticisms, they even have fish flown in from Japan.  I've had their Hamachi, Maguro, Hotate, Tako, Unagi, and other nigiri.  Their ramen is top notch, served with the soft boiled egg, spinach, corn and the requisite roast pork.

I shall continue my quest for my favorite sushi restaurant, but boy was O-Toro close.
author: Calvin T.

description: I went to O-toro last night and it was amazing! We ordered the poke salad, bbq eel with the sauce, sashimi, spider roll, O-toro roll, and the sesame ice cream. That dinner was a dream come true. Everything was fresh! The sashimi was fantastic and it melted in my mouth! Jimmy, the owner, was there and took care of us! This place is great and I would definitely be coming back.
author: Trang N.

description:
4.5 stars but round up to 5 stars!!!

My friend and I decided to come here at the last minute.  We made the reservation at 9pm but we got there like an hour early.  Luckily the restaurant had seats at the sushi bar.  

The guy (I guess the owner) was super friendly.  The staffs did not have smile on the face but they were professional and efficient.

They have extensive menu including small plate, hot dishes, noodles, sushi and special rolls.  Also they have the daily special on the board.  

We have ordered

Agedashi Tofu 5/5 - Prefect!  The tofu was crispy outside but soft inside.  

Edamame 5/5 - Fresh and flavorful

Toro Sushi (two pieces) 5/5 - It was so good.  The fish was fresh and melted in the mouth.  

Hamachi Sushi (two pieces) 5/5 - It was as good as Toro.  Very fresh.  

Chicken Udon 5/5 - It was good.  The chicken was tender and not dry.  Udon was chewy and not overcooked.  Soup broth was flavorful.

Dragon Rolls 3/5 - It was ok.  Not memorable.  The roll was on the small side.  

Salmon Avocado Rolls 4/5 - Decent roll and salmon was very fresh.

I will definitely go back to try the items on their special menu.
author: Liza T.

description:
One of my favorite Japanese restaurants! I've only been here once and cannot wait to come back for a date night!


The place is small, intimate, modern and trendy.  Walking in, one could already detect that this is not the kind of Japanese restaurant that serves bento boxes.

We started with your typical Miso soup and edamame. OK.... good start. 
Then we had some Kaiso salad (seaweed salad)-- super fresh crisp seaweed. Alright, what's next? 
Then out came the Hamachi with Yozo Teriyaki... which is pretty much thin slices of Hamachi drizzled with sauce. The hamachi was so fresh and the sauce complemented the fish perfectly without being overwhelming. I was really starting to get really pumped for the next dishes.
OMG....Nasu Denguku!! It is Japanese eggplant with Miso sauce. I got really greedy with this dish and almost didn't want to share! 
We also had the O-toro special roll with avocado, topped with mango. Great combination of ingredients, yet again. And their salmon sashimi, oh lord.... so fresh, so damn buttery! BEST salmon sashimi I've had HANDS DOWN!!

Service was great. The server got our orders quickly, came out with food quickly, made sure everything was great.

O-toro capped off our night beautifully!
author: Carmela A.

description:
Just don't go here!!!!! If you are a sushi lover you WILL be disappointed. I spent $160 for a very disappointing meal. All the dishes were just slopped together, giant pieces of tethery fish and random food pairings that didn't go well together. The shishito peppers were burnt and just didn't taste good. But to top it off with a name like "O-Toro"  their toro is actually far from pleasing. Really really chewy! NOT HOW TORO should be AT ALL!!
I really regret coming here and won't be going back with places like sushi bistro around. I have had better sushi from Whole Foods.
author: Amanda C.

description: Service and atmosphere was great.  Food was only worth 1 star. I'm the type of person who orders my usual classic favorites, never too adventurous since I am not a fan of Asian fusion.  A friend was in town from NYC and asked to go to a good Japanese restaurant. I wish I took her to K's Kitchen. My friend was sweet and thought everything was delicious. But really? The O-Toro didn't seem too fresh (too fishy), which cost $40+ That's about the only thing I remember from the menu because it was all so unmemorable. Oh, the truffle tuna tar tar the waiter highly recommended was just wrong. Slightly creative idea, but just doesn't work. Definitely a no for a return visit.
author: Savinie L.

description: Ok place for lunch but nothing more. Bad service. Don't understand how they have received a recommendation by Guide Michelin
author: Petter B.

description:
We'd give 3.5 stars (we consider 2 stars to be average).. Food was decent but inconsistent and the space was a little too loud for comfortable conversation.

The nigiri we tried (bluefin tuna, butterfish, and sardine) were a little above average, but sadly a bit too heavy on wasabi- I mean shoot up your nose, eye watering heavy on wasabi. Definitely not we expected from a place as well rated as O-Toro.

We also had the miso mackerel appetizer which was delicious. The mackerel is well marinated with miso and each bite was savory, slightly sweet, and so good. The pork belly, one of the specials of the day, was yummy as well- marinated and full of flavor, although a bit salty. The spicy miso ramen (+$1 for spicy) was also good and decently sized. 

Overall a yummy meal on a Friday night although close to impossible to have a conversation.
author: Amy D.

description:
Ate here on a Thursday night and ended up being the last table sat.  Happy they accommodated us.  Sushi was the freshest, my friend got the lava roll and the tuna was so fresh - that roll was my favorite.  
I got an eel topped shrimp tempura roll and that was great.  We also tried the otoro roll.  
Hamachi was amazing.  
This is top shelf sushi and I loved that they offered us warm hand wipes before our meal.  
This is my new sushi date night spot.
author: Koa K.

description: The otoro which is the tuna belly melted in your mouth like butter and thats not a fucking joke. The halibut with sisho leaf was delectable and fresh. You could eat this nigiri all night! The local sea urchin was rich and bitter and delicious. This place is small and intimate with many specials on the board for everybody. Extremely good and fresh fish with a sophisticated special menu. Definitely going to come back here to eat!
author: Timothy Jim Roger S.

description:
Ohhhhhhhhhh Toro!

I will admit this is one of my go-to spots for sushi. For me, this place presents the perfect balance between price and quality and it's almost never crowded here an. For about $40 you can get in a really decent sushi meal!

Highlights:
- Ankimo here ranks a one of the best I've ad
- Seared Salmon Belly
- Uni
- Black Sesame ice cream is a MUST!

I wish they hadn't gotten rid of their dons (rice bowls) and their hot dinner platters, but if you're coming here for nigiri anyway you're in for a treat.
author: Joanne Y.

description:
This experience got me to come back to YELP after I have stopped giving reviews.

What a mediocre sushi resto in SF.  How can they think they can get away with this with DOMO just down the street. I hope that Hayes Valley produces a few more Sushi places to encourage these people to pick up their game or close.

The server, female, made us feel like we were annoying her.  She was smug. The Sushi Chef, an older Japanese man, would not engage with us when I wanted to ask about a fairly new fish on the scene, a perch, and was rude and silenced us.

The fish cuts are slim and the rice quality, a very important part of sushi, is low grade...very low grade.

I was disappointed and not happy about the bill...the amount nor having to pay it.

Skip this place, I promise.
author: Kate S.

description:
Bumping the place up from four to five stars. I've been here at least a dozen times now, and I'm impressed by the consistency and quality of what I get. I've tried the chicken and fish, as well as most of the noodle combinations. Takeout means an otoro roll, sitting in means a tour of the sushi. All is well here.

It's impossible to be a regular and not realize an attachment of sentiment to a place. If I were to write an SF Noir, I would definitely have a scene at O-toro.

It would be a dark and heavy night, where Gough is filled with the futurist rush of cars, and cautious, hurried strangers in long overcoats pass by as ships on a foggy night.

A light glows like an ink blot over the wooden sign: O-toro Sushi, it says, with a marlin or tuna logo underneath. You're not sure. Ten years on the job, next to the ocean, you don't know if you should be impressed by how many unexplored nooks and crannies there are in a city this small, or surprised by your ongoing ignorance of oceanic life. You shake your head and push the door open with undue resolution.

The room seems darker inside than outside, the lighting here scarcer, but more deliberate, bringing about a satin feel to the negative spaces. Faces above candles glow, in twos or threes; faces excitedly sharing gossip in hushed, punctuated beats for emphasis; faces listening to conspiracy with frowns of seriousness and furrowed brows. Your eyes scan the room quickly, settling at the end of the bar (of course) where a man in a black sweater and a black hiking vest is pouring himself a glass of sake. You zero in like a laser beam and settle in at the bend in the bar, hanging your coat over the bar chair and using the opportunity to simultaneously sweeping your surroundings for lazy or treacherous ears.

You're at an age where an extra year can be revealed with a telling wrinkle around the eyes -- but not so with the bearded easterner, whose dark but salting hair could mean he's your age, or a decade more. He finishes a glass without giving notice.

"When you order Omakase," he suddenly begins, pouring himself a glass of sake, "is it out of an ignorance of the menu-"

He abruptly turns and locks onto your eyes, a sake glass halfway to his lips: "Or blind trust in the chef?"

The room slows to a halt, and your mind races. He's asking if you're a reductionist or a holist. You're both. You're neither. But that's not the point. His selection of words indicates he's trying to pigeonhole you. There's only one way to respond.

"I do it out of ignorance of the chef," you say with intense confidence, holding your breath but maintaining your gaze.

He drains his glass evenly, his eyes never leaving yours, when you notice the slightest hint of softening at the end of his eyes.

"Alright," he draws slowly. He pushes an overflowing sake glass in an enamel wooden catcher to you, not bothering to meet your eyes. "No more games."
