Your chest deflates with silent relief, but you maintain a hairbreadth of tension. You're all ears now.

To be continued...
author: Christophe C.

description:
Excellent sushi
Excellent sake choices
Ototo fatty tuna hamachi belly raw blue shrimp and kakuni pork belly are a must 
A tad slow in delivery of food
Otherwise a solid 4 stars
author: Jay G.

description:
Even on a Tuesday, parties of 1 will only be seated at the bar. They seemed putout that I even came. They will not seat 1 person anywhere other than the bar even with numerous tables for 2 available. 

There were no bar seats available and as a result they said they could not seat me and turned me away.

If they seat me on my next attempt, I will update my review then. Until then, I am simply shocked that a potential customer was turned away and not even given a wait time.

After my experience I noticed other reviewers had the same experience I did....
author: Zoe D.

description:
I had high hopes walking into O-Toro; the cozy ambiance, the bar seating, and the extensive sake selection certainly added to that.

Unfortunately my choices for dinner left me quite disappointed.  I decided to go with Sashimi: OToro, Albacore and Himachi.  None of the pieces were tender or buttery.  My palate was craving freshness that melts in your mouth...instead I fed it chewy, large pieces of fish.

Perhaps the rolls with all the sauce frills might be the better option next time.  On the plus side, we didn't have reservations and our wait was only ~10 minutes.
author: Nikki G.

description:
Just like Jiro Dreams of Sushi, I dreamed of sushi after dining here.

The sake flight was educational and perfect for sharing among our small group. We learned about three  basic types of sake; each requires different brewing methods and a different percentage of rice milling. 

Out of three yakitori orders (chicken, chicken heart & fried chicken skin), the best was the skin (crispy and light). 

The otoro was beautifully fatty and marbled (melts in your mouth like butter). The presentation for the aji was breathtaking and upon finishing the meat, the aji bone, head and tail are deep fried. It tasted like fish potato chips (flavorful, amazingly light as air and crunchy). My favorite was the Madagascar blue shrimp sushi which was really light blue in color with the head deep fried. 

Ambience is intimate and great service considering one waitress. After a long stressful week, this  was the perfect place to unwind with friends and enjoy fresh lovingly prepared food.
author: Sophie C.

description: We loved this place. We're massive sushi fans & found this very tasty. The place is cute too & our server was extremely friendly. Would recommend.
author: Fi M.

description: Poor quality. We ordered a chirashi and a tekka don. Both came with just 7 poorly cut slices of fish, no soup, nor salad.  The fish was dull looking--far from fresh and chewy/sinewy. Just those two things and a cup of tea $60.
author: Candace C.

description:
I drove down Oak Street en route to do a quick errand and O-Toro's elegant, inviting space made me do a double-take. I made a quick mental note to swing by "soon."

Funny thing is, when you least expect an obsession to take root, I decided that "soon" had to be that night, no exceptions. 

I found parking right away around the corner on Gough Street (beware the crazy drivers careening down that street to cross Market and get onto 101). 

As I walked in, the entry was sexy and stunning, a beautiful yellow orb and sleek black stools and tables with gorgeous lights gently illuminating the bar and the tables.

The atmosphere is really amazing, very inviting. My only  complaint is I had a damn hard time reading their menu given the low lighting. I guess that's a small price to pay to soak up some great ambiance.

I admit, I went a little nuts ordering both a large plate of sashimi and two speciality rolls. I first started with butterfish, toro and hamachi sashimi and then their O-Toro roll (spicy tuna, avocado topped with cooling mango) and the Lava roll (shrimp tempura and cucumber inside with tuna on top with spicy sauce). 

As another Yelper mentioned, I liked how O-Toro does their rolls: They're tightly packed so you can pop a whole piece in your mouth without looking like a fool. 

My little one had O-Toro's yakatori (I sampled, it was tender and delicious) and he very adventurously (hey, he's only 4) had their Bi-Rite black sesame seed ice cream that he really liked.

I really love that there's a superb sushi restaurant in my neighborhood. This is going to be my "go-to" spot when I'm really craving sashimi and sushi. 

I'm going back "soon." So that means, probably tomorrow night (O-Toro is closed on Sunday).
author: Jennifer O.

description: A client recently recommended this spot. This was the first time I followed up on a clients recommendation and I was thoroughly impressed! The atmosphere was similar to a bar at a nightclub, but the service was very intimate. The sushi was extremely fresh, and I was delighted to taste real crab in their rolls. Perfect atmosphere for a date!
author: Paul G.

description:
Came here the other night without much planning, after unexpectedly meeting up for dinner in the city after work.  It's a small, loud kind of place, with a trendy, modern approach to sushi and Japanese style small plates or Izakaya.  I think the only reason we would have come here was because I was able to get a reservation -- otherwise, we might have been waiting a long time, even for bar seats.

The food was good, if not remarkable -- the Otoro (fatty tuna) sashimi was a nice treat.  Prices were a little high, but not unreasonable.  The biggest problem was the clientele, and the seating.  Because we were *so* closely crammed together, I couldn't help but overhear the conversations of not only the drunken, loud 40-something former-fratboy douchebags on my left, but also the drunken (and getting drunker) mimosa-swilling, brunch-ruining, Berkin-bag swinging Marina girl douchebags on my right.  Overall, the whole "ambiance" made me want to get the check and get out of there as fast as possible.
author: James P.

description: You have got to try this place. Hands down the BEST sushi in Hayes Valley! Great service, ambiance and versatile menu.
author: Alyssa P.

description:
My co-worker and I went here for a warming bowl of ramen. The shoyu ramen was delicious and well-portioned ($15 with tip) and the restaurant was really peaceful and relaxing. 

There was one odd thing about the ramen, which was that the bamboo shoots were oddly sweet - like it was soaked in sugar water. I was not a fan. The broth was also not as rich as better ramen that I've had (super salty), and the slices of pork were not pork belly (the pork was oddly lean). 

That said, a decent bowl of ramen for the portion. I'd consider coming back for some sushi.
author: Jay P.

description:
I'll preface this by saying that my review is based solely on the food. Not that I was impressed by the reaction I got when I pointed out one of their dishes to be bad, or their general slowness, but I digress. 

My girlfriends and I (table of 3) ordered the following: 

Shishito stuffed pepper w/ spicy albacore-- Bland. I can pass on this. Hype and good don't always go hand in hand. 

Hamachi carpaccio-- Delicious. We got two orders, before we realized it was $18 per plate, for 6 slices of fish. Oh well, you live and you learn; it was still delicious. They even add mango and cucumber slices on the plate, to compliment the hamachi.

Live scallops-- Good. Fresh. Tiny. Maybe we got a baby scallop..

Live uni-- Not good. In fact, it was bitter. 

Nigiris: Hotate (we thought this was a better deal than another live scallop), sake belly, hamachi belly, amaebi, kanpachi, otoro-- Nigiris were fresh = Great!

Cherry blossom roll-- Decent. It's pretty hard to go wrong with salmon, tuna, and avocado. 

All in all, I think this place is mediocre. A high price tag for small portions and not very fresh fish. I probably won't come back.
author: Jessica W.

description: Fresh sushi and great service. I had the Hamachi and Miso Ramen. The Hamachi was really good - super fresh and tasty. Their menu is pretty traditional Japanese, something I've been seeking in the Bay Area for a long time!
author: Chris K.

description:
Service is on point. Walked in at 7 pm on a Friday, no wait and got seated at the bar straight away. Waitress was warm and welcoming, served the dishes staggered as courses, which was cool. 

The hot appy's were tasty, the fish was fresh, but the rolls were on the bland side. I don't like my shit smothered in sauce, but it also didn't taste like much, couldn't taste the fish much on the rolls, because they were sliced kinda thin.

Overall, not bad, but there is better sushi to be had in the city. I'd come back in a pinch.
author: Ashley U.

description: The wait aside, perfect 5 if you truly love sushi that leads with beautiful raw fish.
author: Aiyana N.

description:
probably the best bang for your buck omakase I've ever had. ($85)

the live sea urchin was incredible.
author: Sasha B.

description: No vegetarian broth (not even the miso) - wish they would add it so we could return with our omnivore friends who love it here.
author: Shal J.

description:
What a nice random find!  My brother and I originally wanted to go to another izakaya restaurant in the area but it was on a 2.5 hour wait so we trusted yelp and found ourselves at O-toro! The restaurant is small and only has a few tables but that makes it that much more charming and cozy. 

We ordered a few small plates as well as many of the different sushis - delicious! We started off with agedashi tofu which was good per usual. Light crispy tofu - deceivingly filling. We also ordered the Hamachi carpaccio which there are enough reviews on but it was pretty good! Not amazing at first but the fish was so fresh and the side mango/ refreshing veggie (not sure what it was) made the combination outstanding.  

We ordered a variety of sushis and they all melted in your mouth. Our favorite was the albacore tuna. It was both of our first times trying it and I just have to emphasize that the sushi just melted in our mouth. 

Two things we'd probably pass on next time: sea eel and the scallop dynamite. I like eel and there was nothing wrong with it but it wasn't amazing like the other sushis - just good as you would find at another good Japanese restaurant. Scallop dynamite is not what we expected. We thought it'd be raw scallops but it was cooked in cheese and kimchee. Not bad either but I'd rather eat something more authentically Japanese or fresh at this restaurant. 

Overall a really good experience!
author: Jennifer S.

description: Excellent sushi and Japanese food.  The otoro, seared hamachi belly, uni, and agadashi were really good and fresh.  They lose a star because the tempura batter wasn't quite as light as it should have been.  They also had proper gyozas. I will absolutely come here again.  Love the small friendly atmosphere and the staff is great.
author: Debbie L.

description: I'm new to the city and was worried that I wasn't going to find a sushi place as good as the one from home... Until I went to o'toro! This place is amazing!!!! The fish tasted SO fresh and the prices were reasonable! We got the lava, the dragon and the phili roll and all three we just so delicious and filling! My favorite was the lava roll (I think that's what it was called). I think I've found my new sushi spot in SF!!!
author: Kelly W.

description: Amazing fresh sushi. Little place can barely see it. But the quality of the sushi is amazing! The iced green tea drink is yummy too.
author: Alessandra T.

description:
3 stars for lunch experience.

Service was adequate but not particularly warm or welcoming. I feel like I'm being particularly nice to the server to get him to warm up to us, but he didn't care much for his guests. At some point it feels like we are bothering him just because we are dining there. 

Food was just average. Nothing especially yummy or memorable. The prices range from 12 to 18 for the lunch menu item which is okay but not a good deal.
author: Pancakes D.

description:
From a traditional stand point, I had to admit I was excited about Otoro Sushi.  But the uni was from Mendecino instead of Santa Barbara - think bargain over quality. The amaebi was frozen. The ikura was old. Not cheap either.  

There was some good parts that I can't take away. The sencha (green tea) was really strong. They had real wasabi, for an extra fee. The rice was high grade and perfectly packed under the sushi, falling apart nicely in your mouth. They were honest about what fish was most recently received. Everyone spoke Japanese. They had otoro (fattiest tuna) and even engawa (halibut wing - the muscle that moves the fin). 

But the quality just wasn't there. The selection was, but nothing *popped* freshness. Darn, I really thought I found something good here...
author: Grayson K.

description:
Best toro nigiri EVER!
Book a table before if you don't to wait 45 minutes, the place is very small but the food is awesome!
author: Jose C.

description: RUDE manager (Asian bald guy w/ glasses) save yourself some time & don't even come here!!!
author: Gg S.

description: I used to love this place and raved about it. The last time I ordered to go not only did they overcharge me by $30 they got my order wrong. The man that took my order said he would fix my order and my overcharged bill. He only fixed the overcharge. I was stuck with a california roll (which I had not ordered), and some disappointing toro and salmon nigiri.  The fish was not fresh and I will not be returning here again.
author: Bon N.

description: The portion sizes are tiny - very small sushi rolls and less baked mussels on the plate, etc. - and the prices are much higher than most sushi places. The food is good, but not outstanding. Nothing inventive or mind blowing, that's for sure. Very average service. I'm not sure why I would ever return given the better options all over the city.
author: Mark S.

description:
Good beef udon, yummy pork belly appetizer, and excellent service. I'll have to come back for sushi again! Tried the shoyu and miso ramen too, also good. 

We made reservations an hour before we got there just in case. It was empty at 7 on a Tuesday, hopping by 8:30 or so when we left. The service was prompt and good. The beef udon hit the spot; it was light yet flavorful. The atmosphere was cool, good for a date or to hang out with friends. 

The sushi seemed a little pricey to me, but maybe I need to readjust my price calibrator after just moving here. I'll have to try it sometime for sure. 

Good stop for good ramen. Definitely look at their daily specials for hidden gems like the pork belly!
author: Sneha P.

description:
Saba miso - very tender saba, not too salty for those of you who fear miso, comes on a bed of greens. Great appetizer, or for those who don't like raw fish (WHY go to a sushi bar then???) but definitely a must try!
Agedashi tofu - better than other places, has much more going on then a simple tofu and tempura sauce, so I found this delightfully surprising. Note: we were told you should mix the garnish ontop into the sauce before eating all of it together. 

Hotate nigiri- nice portion, comes with citrus tobiko (yellow tobiko, can't say it tastes strikingly different, but interesting), Hotate was very fresh and melt in your mouth
Walu nigiri - butter fish, hefty daub or wasabi on this one, not to mention a stray piece of garnish that somehow ended up on my fish.. But anyhow, just wanted to try a different fish, pretty good- less fishy than hamachi, milder flavor than even maguro but a tiny bit chewier. 
Orange blossom- the rolls are rather small in portion for price, but also much easier to eat? The sake was quite delicious though really thin slices. 
Otoro (roll)- interesting roll, spicy tuna (strong kick) and mango- both flavors are very bold so a great spicy sweet roll. 

Silver sake sampler - great deal! they give you FULL, to the brim shots of each sake, can be a lot of sake for one person (if you're not trying to get buzzed, so feel free to split between people)

Another note - make a reservation, they really honor those and will save the table, so we went in just before 6p on a Saturday and with just 2 people we still had to wait 20 minutes to be seated as 2 of the tables were saved for reservations.
author: Adrienne L.

description:
It's been a few years since my first 5-star review of this great restaurant, and I wanted to share my appreciation for the consistency of one of my all-time favorite places to visit and get takeout from.

Jimmy and his team provide quality sushi that is worth revisiting again and again.  The food ranks with the much higher priced restaurants in the city, but it is the service and atmosphere that makes makes O-toro extra special.

You are doing yourself a disservice if you life in San Francisco, like sushi, and aren't making a reservation for O-toro right now.  Thank me later!
author: Mitch M.

description:
My dear friend took me here last week for my birthday dinner and to catch up. We had a reservation so we were seated  immediatly. But I can imagine it's hard to eat here without one since the place is pretty small and intimate.

They had a ton of specials on the wall and even more options in their menu. Everything sounded so delicious, so we just settled on sharing a bunch of plates.

-Seared Sake
-stuffed shishito peppers
-toro nigiri
-spicy scallop nigiri
-cherry blossom
-fresh uni
-another roll that i cannot remember the name of

Everything was amazingly fresh and came out in good timing. We actually ordered a couple of the items later because we were still hungry for more, and there wasn't a long wait for it.  If we lounged any longer I'm sure we would have just kept right on ordering through the whole menu!
author: amelia g.

description:
While making my way to my table inside the very small O-Toro Sushi, I knocked over the water on the table next to me...with my butt.  You'd think this would keep me from overindulging in sushi, but when in California I love my sushi. I love it so much that I even dragged an 8 month pregnant Gabi M along with the promise that there'd be plenty of cooked stuff for her to eat. See Gabi M's review if you're looking for good cooked options at O'Toro.

The non-pregnant girls (so happy to be included in this group this year) ordered way more rolls than we thought we could eat, but somehow had no problem polishing it off. I found the fish to be very fresh (like most sushi I've had in the bay area) and delish. 

I'll hit the gym before my next trip at O-Toro, although the people sitting at the table with the spilled water incident were just fine after I sent them apology beers.
author: Andrea R.

description:
This place gets so busy!  The sushi tapas were great, here's the quick and clean (not dirty).

Context: came with a few friends from college right before the SF Symphony.  Originally our reservation was at 7:15pm (which would cut tight to the symphony time) but the owner was kind enough to seat the 5 of us despite being reserved out.  

- Atmosphere was semi-jazz, dark lighting with candles and not too loud to the point where we could have a lively conversation
- Food:  Go straight for the sushi tapas. we ordered:
- Miso salmon
- Garlic soft shell crab
- Agedashi tofu
- BBQ squid
- 6 rolls
- 1 udon

Tip- stick with the tapas.  the rest of the stuff you can get at most other restaurants

The salmon was really good!  Service was great here, wished I got more tapas to tapas-it-off!
author: Justin S.

description:
I love Jimmy -- he handles customers really well (even gives free ice cream)!! I love the fresh quality fish O-Toro uses on my nigiris and sashimi - and oh boy I love the bluefin tuna belly - melts in your mouth.

I won't ramble away on my reviews, but do make a reservation (tip #1) to get a seat on fri/weekends. (tip #2 and #3) If you love fresh fish, order their fresh flown from JP sashimi/nigiri. If you are in love with rolls, they HAVE zee best Golden State (salmon with lemon on top) roll and Lava Rolls - the upgraded version of mouthgasm. Finish it off with Nigori sake :)

I don't think you'll regret coming here. 
There are lots of sushi place claiming to have fresh sashimi, but this is by far one of the few chosen ones in SF!
author: Giovanni F.

description: My favorite sushi place in SF! Sure it's cozy but the fish is good and you can see on their chalkboard which fish has been flown in from Japan that same day. There's been a wait every time I go (surprise) but if you're standing inside the restaurant you can order a bottle of sake (or whatever drink you fancy) to pass the time.
author: Laura S.

description:
All I can say is wow. My expectations about this place were definitely exceeded. 

Disclaimer: I am a Sushi Critic. Meaning - I LOVE SUSHI! (not like "I am smug and I drive a Toyota Prius and do yoga" but more like "I lived in Japan for a year and Japanese food is probably my number 1 favorite food") 

So back to the review - when you walk in to the place, its small and cozy. Candle light and intimate- great place to bring a significant other if you want to get into that "feeling". The first thing they do when you sit, is give you a HOT TOWEL! A HOT TOWEL!!! A+++++ So not is this place just cozy but now you feel super clean and ready to eat. 

They have a pretty comprehensive sushi menu, however, I think their focus is more nigiri rather than rolls. I order two rolls, miso soup, edamame, a beer and hot sake (which was more than enough for me +1) and the bill came out to a whopping $40. Can you say balling! 

The two rolls that I purchases were delicious and tasted super fresh. The staff is incredibly nice (almost suspiciously nice). The sake was bomb.com and the overall experience was enjoyable. 

If you are in the Hayes Valley and looking for a great sushi place - come here! Cozy place with delicious food is always a A Plus in my books.
author: Pablo P.

description: Maybe this is just the New Yorker in me talking but I've been to quite a few places smaller than this space and also quite as packed, but service here was noticeably slow.  Some recent reviewers also seem to agree.  Food was OK.  Would likely only come back if someone in my party was really craving sushi...and we were only in Hayes Valley.
author: Helene T.

description:
O-Toro haiku:
  Quaint, limited seats
  Nigiri, ankimo, rolls
  Bi-Rite for dessert!

Expanded:
  1.  This quaint sushi restaurant has nearly as many seats at the sushi bar as seats at the tables that surround it.
  2.  Ordered the O-Toro nigiri, seared hamachi nigiri, amberjack nigiri, hamachi sashimi, rainbow roll, hamachi kama, grilled beef tongue and ankimo.  Seared hamachi nigiri and hamachi sashimi were excellent!  Ankimo (monkfish liver) was very good.  Overall great selection of fresh and high quality raw fish!
  3.  They are very limited in the dessert category, but what they do serve is very good.  Generous scoop of Bi-Rite ice cream in a martini glass!  A classic, but delicious strawberry flavor as well as black sesame which has a very nice toasted sesame seed flavoring.
author: Erich D.

description: Delicious, very fresh sushi. Great atmosphere, great menu and awesome fresh salmon! Probably the best I've ever had!
author: Chrissie W.

description: Sadly a disappointment. In a city with such great sushi this is definitely one not to try. Food was edible but had no wow factor. Fish didn't taste fresh. And most of the rolls we ordered were bland. Won't be back.
author: Jon M.

description:
So, decided to get a healthy meal after my class at Cardio Barre. O-Toro was just a few blocks away, and I felt the many Yelp reviews/positive ratings were a good sign. My friend and I had gyoza and edamame as appetizers, the hip hop and cherry blossom rolls as specialty rolls, with red bean ice cream as dessert. 

A little overpriced, but the sushi tasted fresh, and the gyoza were the right balance of oily/dry. Kourtney, my workout buddy mentioned that the red bean ice cream tasted like a Starburst,lol.
author: Courtney L.

description:
Awesome sushi.  Fresh from Japan.  Loved it!
Seared hamachi belly nigiri
Garlic albacore
Unagi
Seared salmon belly
Spanish Mackerel
Barracuda
Hamachi
OToro

Their rolls looked good too.  The Golden Gate Roll.  And even the apps looked delicious like the Kobe beef, Misoyaki, black cod, scallop dynamite.  Will definitely come back to try it all.
author: Tori C.

description:
Date & Time:  Tuesday April 28, 2009 @ 6:30pm
Company:  Michael
Crowd:  After-Work & Pre-Theatre Going Groups of 30-Something Ladies in Milly or Catherine Malandrino Dresses
Vibe:  Energetic
Music:  Eclectic Mix of Jazz, Motown & Soul
Decor:  Cool & Contemporary.  Chocolate & Blue Color-Block Walls.  Cobalt Blue Drop 1 Pendant Lighting.  Intimate Space w/ Sushi Bar, A Couple of Dark Wood Tables for Quatre & Tightly-Packed Bench Seating for Deux & Quatre
Service:  Witty & Sharp Waiter & Eye-Candy Waitress in Noire
Imbibe:  Sake Sampler:  Cherry Bouquet, Northern Skies, Autumn Elixer $10.75
Devour:  Omakase- Sashimi & Nigiri:  Toro, Aji, Uni, Hotati, Akimo, Otoro, Amberjack, Seared Hamachi.  Kinoko Sauteed.  Miso Black Cod.  Wagyu Tataki. Miso Ramen.  Black Sesame Ice Cream
Total:  $124.64
author: Genevieve Y.

description:
A pleasant surprise...
Made a reservation Saturday night based various Yelp reviews.
The negative comments about the service made me a bit weary.
We were greeted at the door but had to wait for a table to clear.
The subsequent service were prompt and the waitress, despite the serious look, chatted with us quite a bit.
The sushi were fresh and tasty.
Highly recommend the hamachi carpaccio... Came with slices of avocado.... Yummmm...!!
We also tried grilled and cooked dishes...
Everything was well made.
Look forward to come back for more....!
author: YC L.

description: Found my favorite roll.  Yellow Tail with Unagi roll... Wonderfully nice people and always fresh fish.
author: A J.

description:
Menu has great selection with lots of traditional Japanese dish. Their fishes are so fresh and well prepared. I would recommend if you are a fan of sashimi and Japanese hot and cold dishes instead of fancy special sushi rolls.
Good selection of sake as well. Small and friendly atmosphere. Service was ah-ma-zing!
author: May N.

description:
pretty good sushi/sashimi.....still can't match or get any better than our all time favorite Japanese restaurant( can't say)..need to be top secret....
Ambiance was great...staff...great...sashimi/sushi...a hair above average....
great location and it was a fun night out for me and my girl!!!
author: chris f.

description:
As we continued our sushi in San Francisco tour, my buddy and I ended up at O-Toro sushi. It's a small place a few blocks northwest of the Civic Center BART station. It has a relaxed vibe, a good date type sushi joint without overbearing loud music. You get what you pay for, and while our bill was $60 each with tax and tip, it was worth every cent.

We ordered the following:
**Hamachi Carpaccio : 5 pieces of Hamachi doused in Ponzu and layered with avocado and some mango on the side. Amazing. Perfectly paired, and very fresh. 
**Ocean trout: Just a good tasting salmon that I could eat over and over again. Fresh and delicious.
**Butterfish sashimi: light and a little buttery. Good, but preferred the other sashimi dishes over the butterfish.  
**Cherry blossom: can't go wrong with ahi covered rolls with salmon inside. It was tasty, and quite large.  
**Nigiri Hamachi: Tasted fresh, and came out in good size pieces.  

Out of all the places I visited over the past week, O-Toro was at the top of the list in regards to fish freshness.  Every plate came with good size sushi pieces, and felt I got good value for the price. The rolls seem to be bigger than the standard type rolls I have had at other sushi restaurants.  I wouldn't hesitate to come back again.
author: Humberto G.

description:
This little restaurant changed the way I perceive sashimi and sushi in general. I will never be able to eat another piece of sushi again without longing for O-toro.

We came here on a Wednesday night, called ahead just 30 minutes before our arrival with our party of 7, and only waited about 15 minutes before we were seated. We ordered omakase, with the waitress taking into account everyone's dietary desires and restrictions. Every dish that was served to us was an art piece and ohmygod I felt like my taste buds had died and gone to heaven.

O-toro made me understand why people are so crazy about sashimi. Never in my life did I truly understand the fanaticism until that night. And now I'm forever spoiled and will never be able to eat average-grade sushi again!

Arigato gozaimashita!
author: Judy C.

description: Last night, soaked from the rain, we walked into this cozy place and our reserved table was clean and inviting. The room is has a great vibe. We started with warm saki and miso soup to get the chill out. We ordered various nigiri and rolls, and all were delicious and so fresh. The staff is efficient and kind. We walked to Davies Symphony Hall afterwards and vowed to return to O-Toro soon.
author: Robin A.

description:
Got the fresh salmon sashimi and O-Toro roll for takeout.  The fish was really fresh and delicious, the O-Toro roll a surprisingly pleasing mix of spicy tuna wrapped in refreshing mango.  The ambience of the restaurant looked sleek and elegant, so I want to come back to dine-in here and try the other rolls.

Update: Finally came back here a year later, got the Kakuni (special) delicious tender fatty layers with a rich gravy that I could drink straight out of the dish.

Dragon roll was standard, unagi a little mushy
author: Letitia L.

description:
Solid sushi.  Their uni and amaebi are my favorites as is their toro.  It is their namesake afterall.  I generally stick to their nigiris cuz that's how we roll.  Harhar.  Sorry I'll save the cheese for my burgers.

Also, the wait is more bearable than say....Ichi or Sushi Zone, so the ease with which you can just pop in and get your grub on before your stomach devours your liver is definitely worthy of a mention.
author: Uyen N.

description:
Hayes Valley... you have yet to do me wrong.  Having just moved closer to the area, I've made it a goal to explore the cutesy eateries that Hayes Valley offers and I'm definitely not disappointed in Otoro.

Having just come from a meat-filled binge the last two weekends, I wanted something "cleaner" for din with the BF last night.  Searched "sushi near Hayes Valley" and up popped Otoro.  Was able to get same day rezzies on a Monday night but surprisingly when we walked in, it was pretty full.

EVERYTHING on their menu sounded delicious.  We ended up going with the Otoro (fatty tuna), Walu (butter fish), Kanpachi, Albacore sashimi, baked green mussels, pork belly, and shishito peppers stuffed with spicy albacore.  With the exception of the shishito peppers (I thought the albacore would be raw but it was cooked), everything was amazing.  The fish just melts in your mouth and is so incredibly fresh.  Mussels had a crack sauce that was to die for.  And omgahhh..the pork belly!  The softest pork belly ever and even the fatty part, which I usually try to avoid, just melted like butter in your mouth.  All that ended being less than $80 before tip.  Waitress was super nice also.

Since the boy is on a no-carb diet, we didn't get to order any of the rolls but that is definitely on my list for my next, and hopefully soon, visit to Otoro.  Also, I wonder how the ramen is...
author: Jane N.

description:
Went before a show and they graciously accommodated our rushiness. Wonderful fresh fish, I'd eat here every day if I could!. 
Not their fault, but we were surrounded by guys talking loudly about things like having just put $50K down on a car that has a waiting list, because it was just sitting in their checking account anyway. Oh San Francisco, I mourn thee.
author: Kate G.

description:
One of the best sushi meals I've had in the city.

Went here for pre-opera dinner with the girl I'm seeing, who had never really messed around with nigiri/sashimi before.  I figured if she was stretching my comfort zone with opera, I was going to be passive aggressive and make her eat sea urchin.  Worked out better than expected on both counts!

We had three rounds, from "beginner" to "advanced", hah.

ROUND 1 - Kani (crab), hamachi (yellowtail), maguro (tuna)
All solid, hamachi was the star here.

ROUND 2 - Aji tataki (mackerel), barracuda
The aji tataki was one of the tastiest sushi dishes I've had in years.  Served in the hollowed out belly of the fish, there were plentiful pieces of sashimi, with a great ponzu dipping sauce that allowed you to mix in radish and ginger.  They then deep fried the skeleton for us so we can eat the bone -- awesome!  Barracuda was really tasty, but totally overshadowed by the aji tataki -- would order the aji for its own round in the future.

ROUND 3 - Uni (sea urchin), kampachi (amberjack), bonito (katsuo), tuna belly (toro)
Amazing round.  The kampachi was just OK, but the bonito, uni, and of course tuna belly (I always treat it like desert and eat it last!) were all outstanding.  Awesome flavors and textures.

We also got the sake flight, which was excellent as neither of us had ever really experimented with sake before.  The flight came with notes on the general varieties of sake themselves, and then specific tasting notes for the sake chosen to represent each variety.  Great, educational, and fun experience.

They had an unbelievable list of daily specials, and all fish was flown in from Japan.  Incredible selection, and our waitress was very knowledgeable about what fish was particularly fresh and good today.

I'm not sure I'd pay the steeper prices here if you were predominantly getting rolls, but if you want excellent quality nigiri and/or sashimi in a stylish, intimate space, this should be near the top of your list.
author: James S.

description:
This is definitely the best sushi i've had in the city (which isn't saying much, sadly). The place itself is pretty small and compact. It was very busy when we got there but we had reservations. The service was fast and efficient.

There is a ton of stuff on the menu which made our decision very difficult because it all sounded amazing. It's a tapas place so we ended up getting a bunch of things:

Otoro - delicious
Walnu  - tasty
Kanpachi - delicious
Albacore shashimi - ehhh
Baked mussels - AMAZING
Shishito peppers - tasty
Pork belly - delicious

Writing this now i realize JEEZE we had a lot of things but almost everything was delightful. I don't really like tapas places because I never know how much to order and usually end up either still hungry or way too full. Anyways, the fish was all pretty fresh so no complaints there. I'd definitely recommend this place to those wanting to try a ton of new things.

MUST HAVES:
The baked mussels
author: William L.

description:
When we don't end up at sushi zone- we come to Otoro. Why? Because they take reservations

This is just a great sushi spot. The service is attentive, the fish is fresh and the flavors are yummy! the hamachi kama is our go to starter. I'd say this is a neighborhood gem- its never too crowded - which is a little surprising, but I'm glad.
author: Komal B.

description:
None of their sushi, rolls or sashimi blew us away. It was just okay at best. The portions seems smaller in person vs. the posted photos here. Also the temperature of the fish was on the warm/room temp. side which we didn't care for. Maybe if we sat at the bar it would have been different. 

Best thing we ate was the agedashi tofu which had a nice crispy coating, very creamy inside, sitting on a very tasty hot broth. Best version I've had lately. The grilled octopus was on the rubbery side which was difficult to chew. We also ordered the hamachi carpaccio with avocado special which was just okay and at $18.95 doesn't sound like $$. Again, the slices were on the small side and didn't look that great of a presentation. 

Not sure if we'll be returning soon as it just didn't satisfy our sushi craving that night. I also found the host to be very odd. Upon letting him know my name and reservation time, he verified my last name, turned around and started wiping the counters. No welcome greeting at all. So weird. 

Looks like Ino Sushi is still our no. 1 spot. Hopefully Ino San won't be retiring anytime soon.
author: Jane F.

description: O-toro has really fresh fish. We had bowls of nabeyaki and chicken udon and several rolls plus hamachi sushi. All great, and reasonably priced. The other big plus is that they take opentable reservations. So many small popular japanese restaurants in San Francisco don't take reservations, which is so inconvenient for those of us driving into the city for dinner. We will definitely be back, recommend this place highly.
author: MJ L.

description:
Arrived around 8pm and was totally killed by the noise level (104dB!). The place was packed and each table was yelling as much as they could to barely have a conversation.

The food was great but very expensive for small portions (definitely not $$ but rather $$$). The Kobe beef asparagus roll was delicious but priced $13.95 w/o tax for only 4 rolls. The 8 dynamite rolls were priced $14.95 w/o tax.

Contrary to what said in other reviews the service was good (but the kitchen a bit slow which is understandable given the number of tables to serve).

I recommend this place if you can bring your wax ear plugs otherwise pass your way or try to come on a very quiet day (does this really exist in  a hipster area?)
author: John D.

description:
GREAT sushi place in Hayes Valley. This restaurant is about a block away from my boyfriend's place, which makes me a very happy girlfriend. The fish is always fresh and the prices are super reasonable. Anyone who thinks they can get sushi better than this for less $ are insane.

Minus one star because this place is always packed and they're not open on Sundays.
author: Jennifer C.

description: The food was decent, but pricey for the quality. The service, however, was terrible. The waitress had a big attitude and zero patience for any questions about the menu. I definitely won't be going back!
author: Elizabeth M.

description:
Came here for dinner with a friend before heading over to Davies Symphony Hall for a show. My co-worker/friend spoke highly of this place and I'm glad I listened to his recommendation. O-Toro ending up being a wonderful way to start off a perfect night! 

After looking through the extensive menu options, we decided to go family style to get more variety. We ended up ordering the cherry blossom roll, the hip hop roll, a california roll, an unagi avocado roll, and 2 pieces of sake. 

The cherry blossom roll was my favorite out of everything we ordered. It consisted of salmon and avocado with tuna on top. I love sashimi, especially salmon, so it's no surprise why I liked this roll so much. It was very fresh and clean tasting. So simple, yet so delicious! 

The hip hop roll was pretty good too. Shrimp tempura and avocado inside, garlic white tuna on top. The reason why I liked this roll a little less was because the garlic was pretty strong and overpowered the taste of the other ingredients at times. 

The california roll was also good. Pretty standard and on par with what I've had at other sushi places. I happen to love unagi, so I really enjoyed the unagi avocado roll as well. As for the sake sashimi, it was fresh and yummy. Definitely not low quality stuff! 

For dessert we shared the black sesame ice cream. It was good, but not as good as some of the other reviews made it out to be. Needless to say, I had high expectations for the ice cream and I was a little disappointed. 

As for the restaurant itself, decor here was cool and contemporary.  Even in our "theater" clothes, I didn't feel overly dressed since the surroundings were so nice. The restaurant was also small and cozy with dim, romantic  lighting.  Makes it a great date spot! Service was good too. Our waitress was energetic, attentive, and friendly. And our food was served in a timely manner. 

All in all, I had a good experience at O-Toro. Good food, good atmosphere, good service, and awesome company. What more could a girl want? ;)  4 stars!
author: Natasha H.

description: Excellent sushi dinner with friends. Definitely make a reservation or be prepared to wait a while ... But the food is worth it. We had edamame and marinated fried chicken to start, then the veggie tempura roll, Otoro roll, spicy tuna, Philadelphia, and another spicy something special (jalapeño and salmon) ... All delicious. Excellent service, lively (loud) atmosphere.
author: Lindsay M.

description:
More like 2.5 stars but rounding it up to 3. 

The cardinal rule for sushi lovers is that the seafood must be FRESH.  Next comes the sushi rice which can make or break the sushi.


Location: Well, its Hayes Valley so its a nice bubble of all sorts of things.  Parking will be a headache though.

Service:  Meh.  Not rude, but just bad enough to make you want to half the tip.  Server repeated the order to me twice and still messed up one of the dishes. OK...not cool.

Ambience:  modern and clean.  Not a lot of space so make sure to have reservations if you plan to dine in. 

Food:  Nice variety of everything.  Looks great on the menu until it is served.  The seafood freshness was so so (had chirashi and the rainbow roll...disappointed in the variety of fish, some tasted more fresh than others), the sushi rice was meh (tasted old and the vinegar ratio was off) and the proportions were normal.  At this price point, i have had much better and fresher sushi elsewhere in the area.  Overall a big disappointment after reading such positive Yelp reviews (including the fact that it is up for consideration for Michelin ratings...what??).
author: Cher Y.

description:
This is our go to sushi spot in the city. Always can rely on delicious fresh fish and fun gracious service. 

Jimmy is the man here! He always goes above and beyond.

Beware, RSVP on the weekends. It's a small intimate spot and it gets pretty crowded.
author: Judy V.

description:
The best way I can argument these two stars is that there is a lack of dedication at Otoro and it casts a bad light on so many aspects of their restaurant.

- the restaurant did not smell right as soon as we entered (you know what I mean - fishy wrong)
- hamachi sashimi (core of the fish was really cold as in "partially frozen" but just thawed)
- the rice, overall, is really disappointing
- all the nigiri were opaque, not glistening (sign of dehydration)
- madai nigiri (flown from Japan) was spongy. So the point is: flying something off Japan or serving a pristine fish? Your call...
- tori karaage must have come out of a Costco bag. Grey, slightly fowl, covered by the heavy spices of the breading/batter.
- the mango on the roll we had was genuinely "off-flavored"
- ramen is just a disaster. Broth is thin, lacking depth...total commercial flavors. The noodles are ok...menma was meh and so was the chashu. I seriously believe a bag of Chukazanmai would have tasted better.

All in all, Otoro brings noting to the party and is uninspiring.
author: Dario B.

description:
I love that I can have traditional Japanese fare that is *not* all sushi, all-the-time, is created in the classic traditions, and is delicious and fresh.


When I was sick, my husband brought Yasai Udon and Miso Ramen home  for me. The presentation of the Miso Ramen was that of someone who cares about the details: The broth was in its own container, separate form the noodles so as not to over-saturate them.
The noodles and veggies were meticulously arranged in a "To Go" container: the noodles folded and fanned across the bottom, ever-so-carefully topped with spinach, seaweed, corn, zucchini, carrots, broccoli. Then, two gorgeous slices of pork were placed on the top. Beautiful!

The service is always delightful, and although the space is small adn sparse, it somehow works. 

Oh, and Japanese fare, in Hayes Valley, open for lunch *not* overpriced and *not* creating uber-trendy dishes is a huge plus!
author: Heather S.

description:
First off, the service is great. Very friendly and attentive to my party of 4 last Saturday night.

About the food... it was just OK. Now, I travel to Japan every couple of months, so my standards are fairly high. But still, the quality of the sushi was just ok. The rice was over cooked and not seasoned all that well. It was too cold too - in Japan, the sushi rice is semi-warm.  We ordered several plates and a few sushi rolls. The wasabi was made from powder, It's much better from the real root. Not sure why restaurants don't buy and serve it this way. So, the sushi tasted like it was pre-made and just average. Kinda like sushi sold at Safeway. Just saying. 

...and a note to American sushi lovers out there... it's not customary in Japan to DUNK the entire piece of sushi in a bowl of soy sauce w/ wasabi. When you do this, you totally kill the taste of the sushi. A small dab on the top of the fish is the way to go.... just saying.

All-in-all, it's a good place to go -- great staff, clean, and a friendly place for dinner.
author: Tom H.

description:
I came here to eat dinner with a friend on a Saturday evening. My friend made a reservation for 7 PM that morning and was told over the phone that we would probably sit at the sushi bar which we were fine with. When we got there at 7 the owner told us we would get seated fairly shortly. I immediately noticed how small the venue was (the place could potentially seat max 25 customers). My friend and I waited patiently and 20 minutes passed before we asked the owner how much longer. He confirmed that it would be "very soon". By the time we got seated it was 7:40 -- at this point my friend was pretty frustrated because if we had known we would have needed to wait more than 30 minutes we would have made a reservation elsewhere at the get-go. Also, the owner should have provided more accurate estimates / set our expectations of the wait instead of "very soon" as what we considered "very soon" (less than 10 minutes) turned quickly into a 40 minute wait. 

We got seated at the bar and ordered the following:

Japanese Tapas (Hot Dishes): Nasa Denguku (Japanese eggplant with miso sauce)
Sushi: O-toro, Uni, Hirame
Special Rolls: Hip Hop, Golden State

Overall the food was amazing - I love sushi and the fish here was very fresh and tasty. I'd highly recommend the sushi, the O-toro as that's what the restaurant is called and it was amazing! and the Uni sushi. I was less impressed with the sushi rolls (they were very good not amazing and I'd say that the sushi rolls were better).

I had some issues with the quality of service we received from our waitress. It was clear that English was not her first language and we had to repeat our order several times. Also, we experienced at least 3 failed attempts at getting our waitress' attention when we wanted to place additional orders, etc. (we had to shout "excuse me!" fairly loudly above how loud the restaurant was). 

I'd give this place 4 stars if based solely on the food, but the service (the wait and the waitress) brought it down to 3.5 stars for me. Come here for exceptional food but make sure you make a reservation and expect a wait and less than amazing service.
author: Heather Y.

description:
What we had:
-Agedashi Tofu - extra delicious, definitely recommend
-Spicy Tuna roll - one of the best I've ever had, and it's my favorite roll
-Krabby roll - very tasty as well
-Maguro - excellent quality, but had the most gigantic glob of wasabi hidden inside which, without warning, was a pretty nasty surprise

The atmosphere is nice, the warm towels delightful, and the specials all looked delicious. 

We will definitely be back!
author: Dallas K.

description:
Place gets packed, so I recommend reservations.  If you're in a small group, definitely sit at the bar, talk to the sushi chefs, and ask what's good (and what the fish tastes like). Things are fresh here - I've come here on random weekdays as well as wknds, and it's consistently fresh (I am super sensitive to anything fishy). 

Standard rolls and sushi/sashimi available, along with other items (like kampachi, barracuda, hamachi collar, etc). 

I've had some pretty annoying experiences with one of the waitresses, however. She doesn't care or make an effort, messes up on what we order, does not listen carefully, etc. So, sit at the bar if you can.
author: Teresa Y.

description:
Just got back from dinner here. 

I'm pissed at myself that I ate beforehand. I wanted something "light" so I ordered the vegetable udon. Big fat fluffy noodles never disappoint. It was really good-- better than Whole Foods. (Such a sad standard to compare it to, I know, but.. I don't get around to udon places much.)

It was pretty reasonably priced, and I can't wait to go back and order some of their amazing looking rolls. 

Perfect for a first date or a long, casual dinner with friends.
author: Emily D.

description:
I've been going to O-toro since it first opened.  I've eaten many meals (alone and with others) and celebrated a few birthdays there.  After a long absence of about 3 months (considering I ate here almost every week for a while), I walked in last night and was greeted immediately by the owner.

My order was simple (I had a craving for uni, unagi, and something fried) - uni sushi, krabby roll, and chicken skin.  I believe that uni quality is one of the things by which a sushi resto can be measured.  I've had live uni before, and Otoro's, while not wriggling on my plate, was fresh and good.  The roll was yummy and the chicken skin was very satisfying.  Jimmy convinced me to get it even though it wasn't deep fried - they boil it, dry it out in the oven, and grill it.  Comparable crackly goodness with less guilt!  Come to think of it, everything I've ever had here is g-o-o-d.

After my meal, Jimmy slipped a glass of black sesame ice cream in front of me without my even asking...a perfect ending to the meal that had me wondering why I stayed away for so long.

From the service, to the fresh sushi/sashimi selections, to the delectable hot and cold appetizers, to the desserts, O-toro's got me hooked...again.
author: Moo C.

description: Best sushi I've had in the city yet! I worked at a sushi restaurant for a few years in college so I'm pretty picky about my sushi and I was impressed with how fresh the fish was here. They have quite the selection of toro and it's supposedly flown in all the way from Japan. We got the dragon roll, golden state and a salmon/avocado roll. Only downside is that this is a small place with only a few tables and sushi bar, so I would recommend making a reservation.
author: Jing L.

description:
This place has always been borderline, and has just gotten worse. It's the only sushi restaurant in the city where I've had to return a plate because of bad fish. Was there again last night and couldn't help but notice the smell of rotten fish. If you smell fish when you enter a sushi restaurant, that's a bad sign. Fresh fish doesn't smell. 

They only have 2 beers and both are awful imitation Japanese beers actually brewed in Canada. Asahi draft used to be from Japan but now they're using rancid Canadian substitutes. The beer last night was so bad, I only drank 1/4 of the glass. I was on a date and didn't want to complain, so I just didn't drink it. They never even bothered to ask if something was wrong. Just ignored the full glass and charged me for it. 

My stomach has been upset all night since eating there. 

There's no reason to go here. If you're in the area and want sushi, go to Domo.
author: Eater S.

description: Fantastic sushi, fantastic service. Get some chilled sake and watch them pour it overflowing into collection dish for overflowing wealth in your life! Walk in and order Omakase (chefs choice) and tell them how much you want to spend. Easy and delightful!
author: David D.

description:
I can't believe I've been coming here for years for work lunches because it was so close (my office relocated this year, so I can't have it as often, womp womp).

It's a cute little spot, just a couple of blocks south from the busier part of Hayes Valley. The menu is amazing... Lots of great things for you to eat if you're with a group of friends with differing tastes.

Here, I've had the following dishes: agedashi tofu, maguro sashimi, curry pork and chicken over rice, various teriyaki dishes, almost all of the rolls, ramen, and udon. Everything is so good! If I lived closer, I would definitely eat here more often.

The guy who seats you saw me come in for lunch two months ago, and he says, "Oh hey, Melissa! We're almost open... We'll get a table set up for you soon!" My friends and I were shocked that he knew my name; then I remembered that I always paid using my credit card and he got used to seeing me. When I ordered that day, he asked, "Oh, you don't want your usual curry chicken over rice?" Haha! It's always a nice thing going somewhere to eat where you are recognized. Also, he makes GREAT recommendations on what's the best of the fresh fish that's available.

Since I feel myself rambling on and on (typing this on Caltrain and feeling slightly distracted), I just want to say that I've eaten at NUMEROUS Japanese restaurants, even Michelin-starred ones (this one is A Michelin Bib Gourmand), this is by far my favorite Japanese restaurant!
author: Melissa D.

description:
So good.  Extremely high quality and some unusual stuff.  
Of note, I had a mackerel where they sliced up the whole fish (head, tail, etc.).  You ate up the delicate slices and then they deep fried the skeleton, head, tail.  I was skeptical but the bones were very yummy this way.  I wasn't adventurous enough for the head but my date was very happy.
Can be a little bit of a wait but they are friendly and will serve you drinks while you wait.
author: Ric S.

description:
My boyfriend and I cam here for dinner one Thursday after work, about 5:45pm.  We walked in and the sushi bar was full, but all the tables were empty (small place, maybe only 10 tables).  They asked if we had a reservation and since we did not they sat us at the sushi bar, which was totally fine, just odd, considering the tables did not fill up before we left. 

The food was quite good (we didn't have any drinks).  I thought the Lollipop rolls was really good, but my bf didn't like it, as they use a cucumber to wrap the roll instead of rice.  The Hamachi Carpaccio was delicious, and the other roll we got was ok.  

The one problem I had with the place, was it was fairly $$ for not much to show for it. The service was also, OK, but not great.
author: Sarah F.

description:
This is the sushi place that tastes as good as it looks.  My girlfriend is Japanese and she nodded to me that this place has a Japanese vibe, meaning it's Japanese-owned. We came on Wed. night, hoping that it wouldn't be full but it was still full anyways.  We waited for about 15 mins and ofc, I got ourselves a beer courtesy of Sapporo and basically chatted and sipped through our glasses.  Once glasses were gone, we got a seat, so that was a good timing. I came to this place for a reason: to eat some otoro tuna without worrying if they have it available.  And they did.  My gf and I had two sets of it and it was awesome.  True to its roots, if there's such a saying.  We had some more beers and ate other sushi like shrimp nigri.

I knew it was on the expensive side, it was, but I was ready to spend the money and enjoyed the sushi dinner evening with my girlfriend.
author: Nathan K.

description:
The price is right at O-Toro for lunch.  If you're getting it to-go, you could probably go somewhere cheaper, but as a sit-down Japanese restaurant in Hayes Valley, this is the perfect combination of convenient, clean and affordable.  Plus they have a pretty extensive menu for such a small place.

Service is so-so.
author: Erika C.

description:
The sushi and sashimi were good and fresh, but I've had better for way less money.

I feel this should rate 3 out of 4 dollar signs, rather than two.
author: Moos B.

description:
The low rating comes from two reasons:

1. quality of sushi: fish is not fresh---if you ever had fresh sushi in Japan, you know the texture of the fresh fish.  The sushi and sashimi served here were so soft that they were weeks old.  I seriously doubt whether the sushi chef is Japanese or not: the sushi rolls were so loose that they easily fell apart before they were even picked up.  No real Japanese sushi chef with any self-respect would produce a roll of this low quality.

2. Exceptionally small portion size.  This is in comparison to the regular dish portion size of japanese restaurants, which are already small.  Even when compared to those in Japan, these dishes are on the small side, but with a much higher price.  On top of this, the caterpillar roll barely had any fish in it, mostly avocados.  

The quality of food here does not justify the price in any possible way.  It is not authentic in quality, fish, skill or price.  Do not recommend it.
author: Kim L.

description:
I wish I could write a super bad review for this sushi place so that I would not have to wait for 45 mins just to sit at a bar just like what I went through the first time I went there. LOL! But I can't do that to this restaurant.
To start with, staffs here are super SOOOOOOP-PURRRRRRRRRR friendly and attentive. I got my drinks during the wait. There were a lot of customers showing up and the (I beleive to be) manager guy recognised them by name! How coool is that?!?!?!
Then after a super long wait (well, 2 beers), I got seated at the bar, which was super nice. I got to ask the chef (who speaks with a heavy Japanese accent) which fish is good for the season, and etc. 
I finally ordered the chicken skin skewers, the chicken heart skewers, and the Omakase nigiris.
The chicken skin skewers had a fab'sly interesting crispy texture but a bit too salty. The hearts were season perfectly but a bit too tough for my fably teeth. 
The killer of the night was actually the Omakase nigiris. The fishes were super fresh. The o-toro was probabaly the first real impecably-marble-looking o-toro, you know the melt-in-my-mouth slice of fish, that I ever got in SF. (Normally, I would get chu-toro here instead of o-toro at the price of o-toro from other restuarant).

This will be my to-go sushi place from now on.
author: Joelle K.

description: The best sushi in Hayes Valley. Expertly cut fish and good rice, quite delicate Japanese food. Nothing totally extraordinary or to rave about, but this is my staple Hayes Valley sushi place. It is orders of magnitude better than Domo or any of the other Hayes Valley sushi places. Come here if you want good fish that is well handled, and a standard ambiance.
author: Naomi L.

description:
Solid place, would definitely go here again if around the area. Good food and friendly service. It's small so don't go with a group of more than 4+ people.

We had:
1) hip hop roll - excellent roll and would highly recommend. Love the garlic albacore on top. It also had a tiny piece of shrimp tempura that was light and not overly chewy which can plague some poorly fried tempura.
2) Uni - Great uni, and it wasn't gritty feeling or "sea" taste-y which is always a plus. Had a surprising pinch of wasabi so to have the creaminess of the wasabi with the punch of wasabi was a pleasant eye opener.
3) Anago (sea eel) - I'm actually surprised I liked this as much as I did because I'm not really a fan of eel. It was very soft, not tough or charred on the outside with a nice light teriyaki sauce flavor.

On a side note, this place is essentially one big room with no dividers so it can get a bit loud with all the people in there so I'd only come here if you have a group of 1-4 ppl max.
author: Alex N.

description: A solid one. Really awful - will make you sick too!! Dozens of better sushi places in San Francisco with much better managers too - I had to wait (despite many empty seats) for one last person to join our group in order to get sick?
author: Jay F.

description:
First experience was great- I needed to make a reservation for a group of 10 the week of and they were very accommodating! They even let us bring a little birthday cake for desert! 

The sushi was great. The service was wonderful, very friendly and on top of things. 

Only complaints: they will only split a check with 2 credit cards, and they dont have cold house sushi by the caraffe (its only by the glass?). 

Second experience- I called ahead to see how long of a wait it would be for 4 people, they estimated 30 minutes. We were ok with this so we headed to the restaurant. When we got there (about 10 minutes later) we were told it looked like it would be about 15 minutes. 45 minutes later we were told any minute. We waited an hour then left and went to another sushi restaurant near by. 

I will consider going back with a reservation, but without a reservation they seem to not be able to estimate time AT  ALL and it is not worth the wait or hassel.
author: Jess K.

description:
One of the better spots in the City for sushi. The place is small and tends to have a wait, so be sure to make a reservation in advance. 

The daily specials are usually amazing and the namesake toro is fatty and delicious.

Great date spot since there's plenty to see and do in Hayes Valley too!
author: Calvin W.

description: Been going to O Toro since it opened couple years ago, Jimmy the owner is really the face of the restaurant!  Food is consistently great!  We always like to ask  the sushi chef for his recommendation of what sashimi is fresh for the day and order different kinds of fish as an appetizer.   They have a good variety of fish from Japan too.  Tempura is always good here you see the kitchen hand batter the tempura to your order.  I never had a bad meal here.  Albacore tataki is one of my favorites!  And if you see live scallops (in the shell) order it.  It is usually about $20 depending on size  - usually as sashimi and some as nigiri and the muscles as tempura, yummy!  This place can get crowded so call ahead.
author: Edmond T.

description:
On food alone, O-Toro warrants somewhere around 3.5 stars. The fish is cut very well, is the right temperature and tastes fresh. I had the walu (butterfish) sashimi, sawara (barracuda) sashimi, salmon avocado roll, hamachi avocado roll and Oka sake to wash it all down. I'd highly recommend the walu, but I didn't think the sawara was worth the money. Several pieces of my salmon avocado roll came undone at first poke, which is never a sign of quality craftsmanship. However, the rice was the right flavor and texture and the avocado was fresh. 

Atmosphere is around 4 stars. It's dark, small and chic like so many other trendy sushi restaurants.

Now the service. Oh my lordy, the service. I don't know if they were severely under-staffed that night or what, but there was one man doing three roles--host, waiter and server. To say that he was frustrated would be an understatement. I do communications for a living so I can read people pretty well, and this guy had a severe case of "overworked defensiveness syndrome". Every question I asked him (and I only asked a few) was met with a snippish, peevish-sounding defensive response. 

For example, I asked him if it would be all right if we put our names down and walked around outside while we waited for our table (he told us it would be 20 - 30 min), rather than standing around in the claustrophobically small restaurant. His immediate response was, "What? What do you mean? Okay, fine, if that's what you want." Awkward silence as I waited for him to ask for my name and all he did was stare at me angrily. Finally, I asked, "Shall I give you our names?" Immediate frustrated retort of, "Can't you see I'm busy? I'll get to you when I have a chance!" Even though he'd specifically led me to a free computer and had his finger poised over the on-screen reservation system to (I assume) take down my name. (If your expression right now is "???", well...so was mine.)

He got a little nicer as the evening wore on and fewer people came in. I think the fact that I ordered sake and my friend ordered wine also helped, since he was also our waiter. However, he committed a major faux pas. When I pointed to the "Fresh of the Day" specials on the board and asked him what the fish were in the form of, he told me it was sashimi. Seeing as most were priced ~$6, I figured these specials probably only came in 1-2 pieces. Imagine my surprise when my bill arrived and the sawara and walu were ~$15 each. When I spoke to the guy about this, he claimed that he had DEFINITELY told me the prices were for sushi...and of course sashimi was more expensive (condescending look). Thankfully, my friend spoke up and confirmed that she had heard him say sashimi also, and only then did he decide to believe us and apologized several times for the misunderstanding. He did not, however, offer to do anything about the bill and that is a grave mistake in my book. If you mislead a customer and misquote a price (esp with a $10+ difference), it is only good customer service to honor the misquoted lower price that YOUR stupid mistake caused. 

I'm Asian and I grew up with brusque customer service. This went beyond brusque. It was downright awful service. With so, so many sushi choices in the Bay Area, don't come here. Save yourself the headache and expenditure, and go somewhere where you'll actually be treated with courtesy and respect.
author: Josephine L.

description:
In the past two years, I have lived in Pacific Heights, Twin Peaks, Nob Hill and now Tiburon. During all those changes, my go to sushi spot has inexplicably remained the same! The only reasoning behind this is obviously I am all about this place! 

From the homey ambiance to the tight management and all the way to the melt in your mouth tuna belly, O-toro Sushi has found the formula to sushi success! Don't miss out on the hip hop roll or the cherry blossom, two of my stand by favorites. I have actually not found anything on the menu that I regretted trying. The nice thing about this menu is there's seriously something for every palate. The Japanese tapas are tasty, especially the miso eggplant and even the usually mundane items such as miso soup or spicy tuna, are done extraordinarily well. Do yourself a favor and try this place- on behalf of myself and the many visitors I have taken here, you won't be disappointed!
author: Hannah M.

description:
Came here for the first time tonight with a friend. We walked in around 7pm and it was all booked up already with reservations so we had to sit at the bar.  The restaurant itself is quite small with only a few tables.
We ordered a few of the speciality rolls. The fish seemed fresh; taste wasn't extraordinary, just as expected.  The place is definitely geared toward fusion sushi.  The prices aren't bad either for the neighborhood (14-17 dollars per roll).  
I can see it being a good date restaurant. 
3.5 stars/5.
author: Patricia S.

description:
GET THE PORK BELLY. The 5 start review is based on the pork belly appetizer alone. Seriously, probably the best pork belly I've had. And it's only SEVEN dollars, and is a large serving. 

Ate here on a Saturday evening, got in without reservations, but it was busy. Sat at the bar, which was a good experience. We waited a little too long to order our food, but the wait was worth the pork belly.

I'm pretty sure I ordered the Dragon Roll, and it was good. Kind of a typical dragon roll. My sister ordered the Nabeyaki Udon and enjoyed it. 

This is a good-to in my mind for sushi...and pork belly.
author: Chloé M.

description: So, since our son knows the owner, we walked in with no reservation (still had to wait 40 minutes) to this hoping sushi spot.. wow, what great fresh fish (hope this is for everyone, and not because our son was a regular there).... differ rolls, unusual pieces , great presentation, and absolutely outstanding service and food. I am usually leery of sushi places (other than my regular on in Diamond Bar Ca.), but this spot really impressed me.. well done!
author: Mark K.

description: Small but awesome sushi place. I came here with 3 friends and we ate our fill of sushi and sake. The owner is incredibly nice. We also loved the Bi-Rite ice cream that they have on the dessert menu. The only downside is that it can be a bit of a wait but it's worth it.
author: Cindy B.

description: Not a bad place but way overpriced. Didn't have the best experience here.....had to wait for our food for a while and some of the sushi tasted like it had been sitting for a while. We ordered a special that was $14 that was scallop topped with salmon and ikura. The portion was ridiculously small and the salmon was overcooked. I've been to many sushi places and you can get equal to or better quality for half the price just down the street. Wouldn't recommend.
author: Zak S.

description:
My favorite neighborhood sushi place!!! They have absolutely super fresh fish and a lot of types that are not available elsewhere. It's a great place where the fish is really good, but you're not going home broke.

My favs here:
Live scallop served in shell
Hamachi carpaccio with a hint of truffle oil
Nigiri: Madagascar blue shrimp; Blue fin tuna (they also have a bunch of other tuna options), trout, uni

They also cook every part of the fish, for example they will tempera the shrimp head if you get the Madagascar blue shrimp or tempera the scallop lips if you order live scallop.

They can also do an omakase here where you dictate the price yourself.  However, when you do an omakase, they tend to serve you the more unique but also pricey dishes that add up to more or less the price you dictated.  On your receipt, they will itemize the dishes, rather than one charge for omakase.  So I recommend you do it only when are willing to spend over $30-$40 per person at least.  Otherwise, if it's a low key meal, just order the reg rolls.

Note I've always hit $40-$50 per person every time I'm here and more if you're ordering sake.
author: Li Y.

description:
great find in hayes valley!  i love the ambiance and the smaller seating.  definitely a great date spot or a dinner place for a small group.

food:
uni (reasonably priced! only $6/75 for 2 nigiri)
negihama maki roll: we were too full by the time we had this
salmon nigiri: fish was really fresh!
agedashi tofu: silky, light, and delicious
hip hop roll: my tip is to press the fried garlic piece into the sushi for a great texture
saba shioyaki

definitely make reservations here!
author: Carli F.

description:
I have been to O-toro twice and have been impressed with the sashimi both times.  great variety and really fresh.  

TIP: check the special board before ordering off the menu, it all looked so good!
author: Laura P.

description:
Came here and had a good non-pretentious meal within walking distance of Davies Symphony Hall.  Sashimi was good, but we really liked the rolls; call us inauthentic but anything with a tempura shrimp in it was quite excellent (seriously -- we've had our share of tempura shrimp and tempura shrimp-containing rolls, but their shrimp in particular were better than any in recent memory).  

Place is pretty small but we had no trouble getting in at 6 before the Paul Simon show.  Would go again.
author: Michaela L.

description:
O-Toro has the most horrendous parking situation (Good goodness that I grew up around here so I could parallel into the spot faster than the cars were making their rights) but such a quaint little place to eat at.

Stuffed Mushrooms, De-Lash-US. I was politely on a date (obviously knowing he was going to treat) so let him eat most of it, but I am not sure I would ever be able to do that a second time.

Mussels! Same thing! Now that I think of it maybe I should have eaten the majority of the food.

Gyoza was extremely appetizing, though I normally do not have a thing for Chinese potstickers that I can make myself... Which he ate most of also.

Hamachi Sashimi. We would have had a chopstick battle for this one because I LOVE the stuff. Sweet and beautiful melt in your mouth taste. This is the time that I turned him onto Hamachi. Hamachi needs to be coupled with Wasabi, albeit nowhere near as much as I use, but needs at least a little bit to truly bring out the fresh and sweet flavors in the fish. So if you didn't like it before, try it, and let me know!

Then we had a roll. Eh. I don't remember much about it, but I don't remember any misses! Good job O-Toro. I can't wait to visit you again and practice those parking skills!
author: Winè C.

description: I've been trying to find a good sushi place that doesn't cost an arm and a leg ever since my favourite place changed owners.  I think I've found it!  This will be my new go to sushi place!
author: Vincent K.

description:
Went here last night for dinner. Really nice atmosphere and killer specials menu. We had a reservation at 8:15 but had to wait about 20 minutes to get seated. The waitress was really attentive though and the fish was incredibly fresh (I got the spicy hamachi roll and the unagi avocado roll). We also split an order of seaweed salad which was delicious. 

I'd recommend making a reservation if you plan on eating here--the place is really tiny. Otherwise, great experience!
author: Stephanie A.

description:
Fresh fish + top notch sake. Try the Nishida Denshu; I can (and have) shared an entire bottle with my dinner date, but it's worth just a glass if you'll be driving after dinner. Smooth, delicate and complex flavor goes well with the punchy wasabi.

Great for intimate conversation, but the acoustics make it hard for bigger groups.

The menu leads with timeless favorites such as the fatty tun and hamachi, complemented by a rotating ensemble of fresh imported fish from Japan - meaning I can always eat something I know I love, and explore new flavors at the same time. 

The nightly specials are elegant and tasty, such as the Aji special: light lemon zest on the fish, artistically presented, plus they fry the bone & skin for you at the end of the meal - crunchy and savory. 

Jimmy runs this busy little restaurant smoothly and with a smile. He remembers names and faces quite well, adding a personal touch. It is busy - if you prefer a table to sitting at the sushi bar, make a reservation. 

I'm a regular, and I don't mind driving up from the Peninsula to enjoy the evening.
author: CK K.

description:
Was recommended this sushi spot by a colleague who is a local. Brought a special lady here for a date. Was able to make reservations with only 1 day notice and only had to wait 5 minutes to get seated.

It is a very small, intimate establishment. For what they lack in size, they make up with quality of food. The bottles of chilled sake are the size of regular wine bottles (to my surprise) and if you do not finish, they will let you take the bottle home. Everything we ordered was delicious and of great quality.

My only critique would be that I wish they would stagger the delivery of the dishes as we ordered a lot of food, and ran out of room on our table. 

Best fatty toro I've had at any Sushi establishment in the Bay Area. I also appreciate that it is not a tourist trap. We were seated to a lovely local couple, celebrating the husband's birthday. We shared a shot of sake with them and left them with our unfinished sake as we made our way to the next stop of our evening. 

I will definitely go back the next time I am in SF and craving sushi.
author: Peter Y.

description:
Delish! A friend and I went for dinner the other night, couldn't decide on what to get, so ended up going with the Omakase specifying that we only wanted to spend $60 each. 

$60 worth of food was just the right amount. Was definitely full before the last dish was served. We got a variety of different fish but my favorites were the sea trout, live scallop, and blue fin tuna.

I'll have to come back another time for their special rolls.
author: Jen D.

description: Fresh sushi - walked here after a class at Urban Flow.
author: Jiahui Y.

description:
Been there twice and both times the service was impeccable. Everything was really really fresh and they had a very interesting appetizer menu.

The some of the items on their appetizer menu vary depending on the seafood they have. Otherwise the mea/vegetarian appetizers are pretty much always the same. 

First time we were there we pretty much just ordered a bunch of Nigiris and sake. At the end we asked the chef to impress us. The chef made us a peacock (that's how he called it) it was pretty much albacore tuna, king salmon and something else (can't remember at the moment) wrapped in soy paper in the shape of a peacock. My description might not sound very appetizing or special but trust me it was pretty awesome!

The second time we were there we ordered a variety of Nigiris and to finish we asked the chef for a Uni, Ikura Donburi and he agreed!!!! It was AMAZING!!!!! We were pretty surprised he even agreed to make it for us because it wasn't something on the menu and the ingredients were pretty expensive. 

Both times we were extremely happy with the food!

Will be back because this place is the TO GO PLACE for AMAZING sushi!!!
author: Vickie Z.

description:
This place was great - my only complaint is that parking in that area is AWFUL.  It's not that close to my place so it takes a drive, and I am not kidding when I say I spent a full 15 minutes trying to find a spot anywhere in the remote vicinity.  Obviously not their fault, but just a warning.  They handled it nicely and still sat us even though we were 15 minutes late for our reservation and were busy (we called to let them know about the situation).

I shared sushi and edamame with a friend - the 3 big special rolls were plenty of food, edamame had a nice crunch and perfect sea salt.  House sake was tasty as well.

The service was really great - it's hard to balance attentiveness while not making you feel rushed, but they nailed it.
author: Nicole D H.

description:
I REALLY wish this place was closer to my place, but it's more than worth the trip to another neighborhood. It's really small, so go early or make a reservation. The customer service is above and beyond at this place. Everyone is nice, friendly, and helpful. The manager (or owner, not sure) remembered my name after being there only one time. I had been there on a blind date the week prior and although that date was a dud, the food was awesome and the manager even remember my date's name!

You have to try the Hamachi with truffle oil. It's amazing!! Everything else I have tried there has been equally amazing, but don't leave without trying that dish in particular. I'm salivating right now as I write this review.
author: Brenna S.

description:
Hit or Miss tapas.

Food:
Hip Hop Roll- very bland and fishy
Spicy Hamachi- friend liked it
Veggie Roll- bland
Yakitori- grilled chicken skewers- ok

Oka-Cherry Bouquet Sake- very light and refreshing actually

Ambience:
Cute little place, with only like 7 tables or so

Service
They were way understaffed and service was slow
author: Sangita A.

description:
4 stars? Huh?
