Brief Tirade: it turns out Yelpers are SUPER BAD at reviewing sushi.  If it has a good california roll, its "Woohoo! as good as it gets!" This has been a consistent theme for most sushi restaurants in SF.

 These competing sushi joints also have 4 stars: Koo, Ino, Eiji. That is ridiculous, as all three are vastly superior to O-toro.

I tried:

-cucumber salad with octopus.  not that great - octopus was super rubbery.
-ankimo. OK.
-uni nigiri. fine, but the seaweed was pretty sloppily wrapped.
-other nigiri - generally fine but a bit on the small side and the rice was clearly rolled by amateurs.

-the host was weirdly rude as well - didnt acknowledge us, then didnt say anything when we had a reservation, then pushed by me in the hallway. 

-overall I would say it wasn't BAD but it certainly wasn't four stars.  If you need sushi within a 5-block radius, then O-toro is fine
author: Anthony L.

description:
Have been trying to hit up as many sushi joints in the city since moving here. 

I got the salmon avocado tuna roll and the yellowtail roll. Both were good - sushi was fresh - but there wasn't much diversity on the menu. 

Small, modern decor, but if fills up pretty quickly in the evening so I recommend a reservation.

Greene out.
author: Doron G.

description:
Love going to Otoro .. Jimmy the owner
Always takes care of me and my Friends

Good price , excellent food
author: Scott L.

description:
Why???  overpriced food, under cooked rice, bad service, loud, drunk, unruly patrons, yet overcrowded.
I pity the poor neighbors who have to listen to these drunks when they spill out on to the illegal chairs they have on the sidewalk.
Go somewhere else, cause this ain't it!
author: K. K.

description:
A okay. good menu. Good food. Nothing exciting but nothing bad either...The skewers were a little over cooked but still tasty and edible...Nice little spot to enjoy some good Japanese...

Id, recommend it if you are around the hood...but i would'nt go out of my way to come. Above average to the average...just not that above to me ;)
author: .I I.

description: I don't know why this restaurant is rated 4 stars.  The service is good, but the sushi here is expensive (should be $$$ and not $$) and does not even taste all that great.  I would give it 3 stars if it weren't for the expensive price tag.  This restaurant is sadly overrated.
author: Sabrina H.

description: Really outstanding sushi, perhaps the best we've had since returning from Japan. The rolls are stellar, but be sure to try the hamachi and kampachi too. Great care is taken to ensure that the rice is perfect in terms of flavor and texture, which is critical to the final product. The staff was very nice and everything came out super fast. This is now my favorite sushi spot in SF!
author: Boris G.

description: Terrible service - host is the worst, we left because of him.
author: David S.

description: Most of the sashimi (hamachi, amberjack, salmon, ocean trout,) I'd tried was very good, not mind blowing with exception of the fatty tuna (o-toro).  I believe they bring that in from Japan - haven't had something quite like that in some time...Melts in your mouth.  I like that they had ocean trout which is one of my favs - not the best I've had, but good enough for me to place another order.
author: Leland H.

description: We made a reservation were seated immediately at the bar. Great menu, food and service. Love the small restaurant atmosphere. Would definitely go back again!
author: Erinn D.

description:
Otoro has decent sushi but you can find equally as good food at a place with better service.

My boyfriend and I made a reservation here on Thursday night for our last date before he left SF. We arrived on time but had to wait 15 minutes before we were seated. And even then we weren't given a table; we were placed at the bar. I was extremely disappointed in this poor service and the host gave no indication he was sorry for the wait.

As for the food itself, the sushi was good but not great. We split two rolls -- the rainbow and the spicy tuna. Though the sashimi was good and obviously high quality, I was disappointed by the tuna used in the roll. Rather than use sashimi for the spicy tuna roll, the chefs used a premade mixture of what looked liked canned tuna cat food. 

On the plus side, the food was fairly priced. For two rolls, gyoza, and edamame, we paid about $30. I'd say it's comparable to the quality. 

In the future, I'd probably order takeout from here avoiding the tuna rolls and focusing on sashimi, but I would not eat in the restaurant again due to their very poor service and disorganized reservation system.
author: Kate O.

description:
4.5 Stars

My roommates and I came here on a Friday night with no reservation (not recommended) so we had to sit at the bar. Not a problem since we actually got to sit and eat, not get turned away.

The service is fabulous. The owner/manager (Jimmy) is super nice and accommodated us in anyway he could. We ordered a bottle of sake while waiting and he served us like we were at a table. Very cool. For food, we ordered a few rolls off the board and in the menu. All of the sushi was absolutely delicious and super fresh. Jimmy made sure we had a good time there and would often strike up some conversation with us. Seriously, he made the experience. After watching so much Gordon Ramsay on TV about bad owners/managers who should not be in the business, Jimmy clearly knows how to run a restaurant and keep customers coming back.

Make no mistake, this place is NOT cheap but you are paying for QUALITY food here. I recommend this place to anyone.
author: edward k.

description:
The Good: We only had a little time for lunch and these guys did an excellent job. The standard rolls were executed flawlessly, the spicy tuna was especially delicious. The Otoro roll had fresh mango laid on top and was sublime. The hip-hop roll had tiny slivers of crisp garlic standing up on top, beautifully presented. The fish was very fresh and of excellent quality, cut by someone who knew what they were about. The produce was likewise flawless. One roll we ordered had tiny perfect peeled and translucent slivers of lemon placed on top of salmon- a triumph of a flavor profile. 

The Bad: It's a small gripe, but they serve soda in cans, so no free refills. Call me tasteless, but I want Diet Coke with sushi and I had to be content with one. 

Overall: Beautiful, small sushi joint with an excellent color scheme, good help, and great food. Clean, efficient, delicious. I would go again, and I recommend that you try it.
author: Meghan E.

description: My go to Hayes Valley sushi spot.  Just moved out the neighborhood and will very much miss the wonderful service and always freshest selections.  But promise to come back and visit! Thank you for always making space at the counter for me!
author: Megan W.

description:
Great restaurant, great sushi. Highly recommend O-Toro if you're in the Bay Area. Delicious fish - best of the night had to be the Grasshopper Roll - stuffed with spicy tuna and topped with avocado.

Being from the East Coast, I don't often get a chance to try true Japanese fish, and that was an extra treat. The Madai and Spanish Mackerel (not sure what Spanish Mackerel is doing in Japan, but I'll go with it) were delicious!

Cute little spot, and I do mean little. Even going in at 9.15pm, I still had to wait for one of their few tables. But the chef was talented enough and the fish good enough to be worth the wait!
author: Alex W.

description:
This sushi is pretty good, but not good enough to create mouthwatering memories.  

High Point:
- Garlic Soft Shell Crab - delicious!

Low Point:
- Mirugai (giant clam) - rubbery and bland

This is a cool place to go if you're in Hayes Valley, craving sushi, and don't want to venture too far.
author: Jade F.

description:
The sushi is good and they have great staff, very friendly. 

I have been back twice since our first visit a few weeks ago, 

The pork belly is a must too and the ribs!
author: Neil A.

description:
My favorite sushi place in the city - hands down.

Best part about O-Toro is the LIVE specials that they have from time to time (Uni, Scallop, etc...).

O-Toro changed my outlook on Uni - I've always been slightly turned off by the taste of Uni from other places - but after having the live uni special here I've been addicted, and the only place that gives me a good fix is O-toro.

BONUS - super cool guy named Jimmy is always there to greet us with a smile - no matter how busy it is =)

***If you know you're on your way there - give them a call and let them know - you'll most likely decrease your wait time a ton***
author: Thomas W.

description:
Small restaurant, just off Gough.  Hip, black decor.  Good sake list!  Great service at the sushi counter.  The sushi chef was open to answering all my questions about fish and cranked up each of my orders right away.  The waiter made some good sake recommendations, returning for my second request just as I was about to finish my first.  And I like a restaurant that keeps my water glass filled.  Especially, if it's not an expensive place.

Lots of interesting stuff on the specials board.  I was in an all-nigiri mood, so that's what I had.  O-Toro oh so hooked me up.  The salmon belly was sublime and the portion generous.  Aji, AKA Spanish mackerel, was friggin' delightful.  But the butterfish was just pretty good.  Monk fish pate was pretty good here to, but Ino Sushi's was so mind blowing, I'm ruined for anywhere else.  I did not order the otoro.  Which gives me an excuse to come back.  Off the regular menu, the hamachi, saba  & unagi were all very good.  And with prices starting at just $3.95, it adds up to a 4 star experience.
author: Ted R.

description:
Caught in a bind here. The food here is awesome, but was pretty expensive!

The spot is a very clean and trendy alcove in the middle of the street. Really like the dark greyish tones that are set off by the lights in this place. There are about 6 or 7 four person tables and about 8 spots along a bar area. This tends to be a popular place to eat so a wait should be expected if you don't have reservations.

I recommend taking a look at the specials before taking a look at the menu itself, because I ended up ordering several specials. The menu does have some of the standard rolls that one might be looking for at other sushi restaurants. With my friend, we ordered some individual orders of Sashimi and about 4 rolls, the Grasshopper and the Negi Toro off of the set menu, and two rolls of the specials menu, which I cannot remember off hand. The sushi was very fresh and this amounted to a very fulfilling meal. We were not able to try their tapas, which is actually more what this place is known for, so there will most likely be a second trip involved. Otherwise, the food provided was good. We supplemented this with a sampling of sake from the "gold" list.

The waiter and waitresses were very nice and courteous. The owner asked us how we were doing. He even told us about the significance of the $1 dollar bill on the registrar, ie the first dollar registered at the restaurant. A lot of places do this... I know, but it's still respectable and down to earth. However, like I said before, the value is somewhat hard to justify as the meal ended up being upwards of 35 dollars each person. Hard to say I'll be back here soon, but I'd like to come back to try the tapas, and when my wallet stops hurting.
author: Michael C.

description:
My go-to for Japanese tapas and amazing fish.

Pro-tip:  Get the pork belly, and obviously the O-Toro is amazing.
author: Nick H.

description:
I tried the soba salmon - it was a small-ish portion, but the sauce made it absolutely delicious! The vegetarian rolls are generic - same as you'd find anywhere.

But what blew me away was the special of the day - the grasshopper roll. I thought it would just be crunchy and green, but it was actually crafted to look like a grasshopper - with eyes, and green onion legs / antennae, and everything! It was no longer just food, it was art! It was too pretty to eat!
author: Catherine Y.

description:
I love a small, intimate, sushi joint that is pleasing to look at. Especially one that is always packed. That usually means the food is good right? But of course.  We went here for a friend's birthday because they serve uni, which is sea urchin, and he loves it. Now , as I mentioned in a previous review on Japanese restaurants, I'm more of a bento box girl. Reason being is probably because one does not have to wait to eat a bento box, but sushi......sushi is such the hipster thing and I pride myself in not fitting into that category. Also, when I'm hungry, I despise waiting in line for food. Okay, no diss to sushi, but having grown up with rice, I like more substance than rice and either a whole entree or bento box suffices my Japanese food fix.

   We did open table on line, but when we got  there, just like I have already predicted,  there was a line out the door. Now I say this because literally, there are about seven tables and a sushi bar that maybe sat about eight people. There were two parties ahead of us, and he asked us if we had already made a reservation. Despite reserving on line on open table for our slot, we still had to wait until after three more parties. So if you are planning, call and speak to a live person if you so choose to dine here. I don't think he has time to check the internet for reservations. When he realized that we still had to wait despite our on-line rezi, he finally offered possibly having some drinks while we wait. More than anything I think it was just his way of keeping up quiet so that we don't reem his ass for being too stressed out to accommodate us. 

Otoro has  a good selection of Japanese tapas, cold dishes, hot dishes, ramen, donburi, and of course, sashimi and sushi: vegetarian, makis, and special rolls. The sushi is fresh and delectable. This is the reason why I'd give this place a four. But as you can see, our experience minused a star that they should deserve.

So I mentioned that it was a friend's birthday. Well, I took it upon myself to make the host aware of this and he said," Buy some dessert and put a candle on it." Wow. I don't know if he's just used to the snooty hipsters or yuppy folk that patronize this restaurant, but where I'm from, born and raised in the SF, when you inform a restaurant that one of your party has a birthday, they comp you something to show appreciation and show love. Lamentably, my friend is a diabetic, but he could have put  his best foot forward and tried even the most slightest acknowledgment of this. I guess his offering of a candle in a sushi was his way of doing so. 

I'd go back here for the sushi, but I wouldn't hold my breath for the host.
author: Granolia G.

description:
Great food, but horrible horrible non-kid friendly non-family friendly staff. 

Do not go here if you have children. We have two bad experiences with who I think was the manager or owner,Asian male, that we encountered both times 

1st visit:
All the staff welcomed my wife and I with our 2 kids and 1 stroller, except for the dirty looks and unfriendly greeting from that Asian male. We sat through an amazing meal and was continually served by a friendly staff except for that other male. 

2nd visit:
Walked in with our same group of 2 adults 2 children and 2 stroller. A couple was being seated in front of us which left one table of four open for us!!! Perfect timing. Well that same unfriendly Asian male was who I approached for a table. He first looked at my kids, then my stroller, then the empty table of four, the back at my children, back at the still empty table of four, then rudely told us "more than 1 hour wait" then turned around and walked away leaving us standing there...

Conclusion:
If I could get no stars I would. Hayes valley is a growing family friendly environment. STAY AWAY FAMILIES!
author: AJ J.

description: A pretty solid sushi place with fresh fish and well-made rolls. Worth the $$.  However, nothing too extraordinary to note. Therefore no 5-star... perhaps next time I will be wow'd!
author: Lindsey O.

description: Small cozy sushi bar with good quality fish. There aren't a ton of tables so reservations are a good idea. Cute small sushi bar seating area as well. They also have a lot of daily specials with unique sushi options. Located in the new trendy Hayes Valley.  A cool spot to try out when you are in the area.
author: Sara B.

description:
Last night was the second time I've eaten at Otoro, and it's now cemented itself as by favorite sushi place in San Francisco.  

I entered the restaurant at around 7:00pm without reservations (it was already booked up), just to see if I could score a table for me and 4 friends.  Jimmy greeted me, and he was AWESOME.  He suggested I wait 15 minutes to see if a party with a 7pm reservation was a no-show.  I waited, and they didn't show.  He promptly awarded me and my friends the table, and was generous enough to find us a close parking spot.  

Dinner was sublime.  The Hamachi carpaccio with truffle oil was one of the best carpaccio dishes I've ever had; we were trying to find anything possible to dip into the  sauce once we finished the fish.  As if that weren't enough, I couldn't recommend the Takashi roll even more.  The exquisite blend of sweet pumpkin and garlic albacore was brilliant.  And then there was the Kakuni (pork belly).  Holy crap - sweet and tender - true decadence (we secretly drank the sauce when we finished).  

We also had the walu and hamachi sashimi, both of which were wonderfully fresh and generous in portion.

Jimmy took great care of us personally, having a special roll prepared that included salmon, asparagus, and jalapeno topped with sriracha sauce.  Our mouths burned with AWESOMENESS.

All in all, I couldn't recommend Otoro more.  And, I can't wait to go back there.  Jimmy - thanks for the amazing service and attention!
author: Barry G.

description:
This restaurant could be pretty great if they only changed their host. I called earlier and found out that there would be a 15-20 min. wait on a Friday without a reservation. Got there earlier than my friend to wait in line. Place is tiny in a highly trafficked area and the door was kept wide open to accommodate the line. It was windy that night and unpleasant while waiting. 

I was soon offered a counter spot but I told host my friend had texted me he was 3 minutes away, so he would not seat us until we were both there. He let a few people that were behind in the line, go in front of me twice. Place only seats about 20 so when I saw him give away the two stools at the counter I knew that meant death!!

Long story short we waited over an hour and 20 minutes and the whole experience ruined the meal. It was too late to go anywhere else, and the higher-end restaurant on the corner was overflowing with people as well, Host was just incredibly rude and complacent (Yuan N. calls him "despicable" in his review down below) and when we expressed our dissatisfaction with his rigidity and ironic style he told us "if we weren't happy we should leave his place".

It's tough to justify paying over $100 for a small meal for two when as a patron one is made to feel frustrated and undignified by putting up with such unacceptable behavior. This whole situation could have been neutralized by offering to buy us a beer and/or offering some kind of veiled apology. Host made us feel like we owed him something for "letting" us eat there. Food was OK, the waitress was nice but that manager (hope he isn't the owner!!) HAS TO GO!!

Don't even think about ever going there without a reservation and even if you have one, don't be surprised if you have to wait (see Stephanie A.'s review) upwards of 20 minutes. Enjoy!
author: Sandra V.

description:
Otoro sashimi was absolutely delicious! 

Service was great and fast! Recommendations were really nice too!

Atmosphere is great, just beware of Market Street during nighttime. Would definitely go again!

Rolls were just a little bit smaller than what I'm used to, but nevertheless delicious!
author: Amy C.

description:
I don't like sushi.  I don't eat fish, and veggie sushi is somewhere below brussel sprouts and soggy bran flakes on my list of favorite foods.

That said, this place was pretty bearable.  The prices are quite reasonable, and the service was great.  When I ordered the agedashi tofu, the server noticed that I had also ordered a veggie tempura roll and asked me if I was vegetarian.  She then told me she'd ask the kitchen to skip the fish flakes on the tofu.  Great catch and so appreciated.

Can't comment on the real sushi (the reason most people probably go here), but the service and the environment were great.  The tofu wasn't bad either.
author: Gowri R.

description: Our favorite neighborhood sushi spot. Fresh sashimi - always. I'm personally not a fan of rolls, but their specials (on the chalk board) are good recs for guests who like rolls. Get the uni, trout, and seared sake.
author: Bella B.

description: From the very first visit, I've been a huge fan of O-toro. It's my favorite sushi restaurant in the Hayes Valley area and I go almost every other week for a solid sushi meal. Not only is the quality of the fish outstanding but the creative rolls and the amount of sushi you get per roll is better than a lot of other sushi restaurants I've been to in SF. My favorite is their signature O-toro roll. The space is small, dark and intimate so it's the perfect place for a dinner with 2-4 people. I would recommend making a reservation before going though to avoid a wait.
author: Priscilla L.

description:
This review is for the to-go since I have never dined here.

More like  $$$. I only ordered sashimi and a roll and it came out to $40. What the heck? I waited a while for it too. I'm pretty sure that the hostess took the wrong order or must have overcharged me. I didn't like him neither, he got a stuck up attitude. Next time I come here to actually dine, I will make sure to keep an eye on my receipt. 

Other than my pricey to go. The food was good.
author: J C.

description:
Yummy! We ended up coming here since the wait at Sushi Zone was too much, but good choice!

We ordered a 5 dishes total: the otoro roll, hamachi cappacio, pumpkin tempura roll, agedashi tofu, and the garlic shell crab.  Except for the agedashi, which was mediocre and slightly bland, everything was really good.  

p.s. You can reserve a table online through Yelp, which I really liked.  This place is small and does get busy.
author: Jean K.

description: I had dinner at O-toro on a weeknight and found that the food was just average. I ordered the karaage which wasn't very flavorful being that it was fried chicken. I also had the hip hop roll which was satisfactory but left me wanting more. Also, the texture of the fish atop the roll, white tuna I believe,  had this not so smooth choppy texture vs. a buttery one. I tried my friend's shoyu ramen which had a decent tasting broth. Service was courteous and although there are a variety of menu items, I find them to be quite pricey.
author: Maya S.

description: O-toro has a cute atmosphere and an ARRAY of sake options; delicious sashimi/sushi. Best miso soup ever. However the salted grilled mackerel shioyaki was terrible; chewy and oily with no flavor.. although the hamachi appetizer  was out off the chain good.
author: Button L.

description:
***Reservation needed during dinner rush.  Hole-in-the-wall. Limited seating.***

Came here for my birthday with a co-worker. What a splendid treat, indeed!

Try the Golden Gate (california roll with salmon and a sliver of lemon on top).

Also, try the cucumber-wrapped roll from the specials list by the bar counter. So good... I ordered TWO. Now I order them to-go after a long day at work.

DO say YES to Bi-Rite ice cream from the limited desserts menu.

Pricey sake. Additionally, my favorites were not on O-Toro Sushi's sake list.

Wish they had the option of allowing customers to bring in their own bottles with a corking fee. Ah, a girl could only dream....
author: Drea B.

description: The sushi here was amazing and I recommend the golden gate roll- insane mouth orgasm! But the service we received from our waitress was atrocious (the owner however was very friendly and accommodating). My fiancé and I went here for my bday and I ordered sushi and he got a chicken dish. Mine came out 20 min after we ordered, but we waited for his to come out for literally 45 minutes. Mine was obviously completely eaten and done forever before his came out. I'm pretty sure she forgot to put in his order- why would fried chicken take over 45 min?  but said nothing about the mistake and never offered to take it off the bill. We had to flag down a busboy to ask about the dish because she never came around to check our table. She was impossible to get a hold of and we felt like we were being ignored the whole time. There were barely any customers because it is a very small place, so it was seriously perplexing. When I gestured her for the bill she made a gesture back like 'one min' and then proceeded to run around doing menial tasks like cleaning cups and picking stuff off the floor. It took so long and we felt so disrespected that we just went up and had it processed at the register. Overall it was pretty stressful and I don't think we would go back again despite the good food.
author: Roxy F.

description:
Me and a buddy stumbled upon this gem on cinco de mayo.

Our Orders:
Stuffed Shiitake Mushrooms - My favorite of the evening
Monk fish Pate 
Chicken Udon
Blue Fin Tuna
Giant Scallop 
Lava Roll 
Rainbow Roll

Something that looked really good that we didn't order was the lollipops, if it's not a special they don't have very often these looked very appetizing. 

Everything was excellent, the service was friendly and prompt.  Most importantly (especially with sushi) the place was immaculate, I liked the semi-open kitchen where you could see that it was just as clean and orderly in back as out front.  

I will definitely be back!
author: Adam R.

description:
My friends and I went on Saturday for a girls night dinner and had one of the most melt in your mouth sushi meals I've had in a long time. By the time we got there were were borderline hangry after a day spent wine tasting in Tiburon so we ordered a lot (ahem, I mean we got to try out more of the menu than we normally would). 
What we got:
 - AMAZINGLY fresh hamachi starter (seriously melts in your mouth) that had truffle oil and mango. Seriously, order this. 
 - goyoza (a little greasy, but not over cooked). Meh, I'd pass on this one. 
 - Dragon roll: I usually stay away from tempura, but this was perfectly flakey without being guilt inducingly fried.
 - O-toro roll: spicy! This one had a little kick, but the mango helped mellow it out so my weakling taste buds could still handle it.
 - Golden State: I'd definitely come back here just for this roll. The salmon was incredibly fresh and the lemon pairing took up to a notch! NOM.
 - Another roll off the seasonal chalkboard menu: I think it was called the caterpillar roll? It came with almost an entire avocado on it and was the piece de resistance. I'd easily come back here just for this roll again, if only I could remember the name. 

Moral of the story: ALWAYS order off their special/chalkboard menu. My top 2 favorite items from the meal were off of that. Also, their rolls don't come with a lot of rice, which is fantastic because you get more fish (aka more for your money)!
author: Shanna C.

description: Quality sushi places are surprisingly hard to find in San Francisco. O-Toro is hidden between Hayes Valley and Civic Center, and it has a great menu with a variety of sushi, noodles, and other small dishes. My boyfriend and I got takeout to avoid the wait, and the noodle soup was still good even eaten out of takeout containers. I had the nabeyaki soba, which came in a homey broth with a huge portion of noodles. We also tried the grilled squid and one of the sushi rolls, both of which were filling and tasty. Although it might blend in with some other sushi places around the city, its proximity will definitely have me coming back for more.
author: Ashley T.

description:
Great service, we barely waited 1 minute to be seated although we had no reservation.
The food was great, especially the otoro and uni.
The sesame ice cream is also worth trying.

A place I definitely will go back to.
author: Olivier V.

description:
Mmmm...first time here. I came here with some friends and the bF. My friend's dad and brother works at this joint. We were able to get seats fairly quick before the rush hour hit. 

The beef udon was yummers. The broth was just right. Beef was tender. I absolutely loved their spicy tuna roll. The caterpillar and dragon rolls were just as yummy. 

Service was fantastic. All the rolls were reasonably priced. 

Reservations are accepted, which makes this a plus!
author: Serena F.

description:
I only started eating sushi about a year ago, or any fish for that matter. But I think I'm starting to get the hang of "good sushi" vs "great sushi". O-Toro is within about 5 minutes from me, and I can't stray away from their Golden State roll! It's so good! You can really taste the crab meat, and the salmon on top always tastes so fresh. I'd like to try other things on the menu, but then I read the description of golden state roll again and keep ordering it!!

I've only tried one other sushi place in Hayes Valley, Domo. Domo was good, but it's more of trendy, warm, topping covered sushi. O-Toro is more traditional, basic sushi. I've never eaten in the place, but it's pretty nice inside and seems like a good place for a date or something. It's not very big, so you might want to get a reservation. But it never seems TOO crowded either.

Anyways, this place is my local spot for when I'm craving sushi. They don't give you any shit for using a card. It's a little pricey, but a good treat for the end of the week. Also, I don't give out many 5's unless I'm REALLY wowed by something, so 4 is pretty high for me! If you're craving sushi in this area, come check this place out.
author: Mike C.

description:
My dining experience at O-Toro went something like this:

Me (bite into one of O-Toro's dishes)
Me (struggle not to exclaim aloud how good the dish was and then whisper furiously in hushed tones about how good the dish was)
REPEAT 

I tried several dishes off the daily specials menu and each item was better than the next. We started off with our least favorite dish of the night, grilled shishito peppers stuffed with spicy albacore. While the grilled peppers were sweet and delicious, the albacore filing was underwhelming. But the dishes kept getting better and better.

Next, came grilled hamachi belly nigiri. The light grilling imparted a smokiness to the hamachi, which was sweet, richly marbled, and creamy. 

Then, we had the tori karaage. I'm a dark meat girl. And these were my personal kaarage heaven. Tender, juicy pieces of chicken thigh meat, battered and deep fried until golden. Usually, I prefer a dipping sauce for my karaage, but these were perfect with a light squeeze of lemon. 

The 2 sushi rolls we had were so memorable. The combinations were creative, yet simple. First, a black & white roll: asparagus tempura and butterfish. The asparagus tempura was fresh out of the deep fryer and an excellent contrast to the sweet butterfish and salty black cod roe. Next, the takashi roll: pumpkin tempura and garlic albacore. Yet again, the pumpkin tempura was crisp and newly fried. But the garlic albacore was the star of this roll. I've never had anything like it. The albacore was infused with an intense garlic essence that was a surprisingly ideal counterpoint to the sweet pumpkin. 
 
I'm extremely happy to have found a local sushi joint with 1) high-caliber sushi quality and 2) innovative, creative sushi rolls that respect the integrity of the ingredients. I cannot wait to return and try more dishes off the daily specials menu!
author: Monelle A.

description:
Came here for my best friend's 30th birthday dinner.  Just me and here for a light dinner before a night of drinking.   
Reservation is a must!  Very small restaurant and very limited seating. 
Dinner:
-Agadashi tofu - not bad. 
-Seaweed salad - yum!
-Dragon Roll - HUGE! I love crunchy texture so this roll and the spider roll are the two rolls I know that has a crunchy deep fried seafood in the center. 
-Otoro Sashimi - Fatty tuna... oh it melts in your mouth. So good!
-Downed two Sapporo beers and off to a night of fun!
author: Ying F.

description:
I've been here twice in the past two weeks.  This will probably be my favorite Japanese restaurant within walking distance from the office.  I take a late lunch, so by the time I get here it's usually around 1:30 which is perfect because the crowds have died down.  Be sure to check out their specials board. 

Suggestions:  Otoro, Ramen, Any of the rolls, Agedashi tofu.
author: Stacey L.

description:
Stopped off here on a recent trip to San Francisco based on other's reviews on yelp. While the restaurant was small in size the atmosphere was warm and comfortable. The night I went, it was quite busy and there was a short wait to be seated however this is something to expect at any good place the night before Thanksgiving. upon being seated it quickly became apparant that the food was worth the wait. It was one or the better sushi places I have been to recently, especially considering the price. The food was fresh and the fish was absolutely sushi grade - Not frozen or processed. restaraunt as a whole was authentic - modern with touches of sophistication,  but authentIc none the less. The staff was friendly, attentive, and well educated on the menu which proved helpful for some the items we were interested in.

While I had a great evening out, the restaraunt is cosy, which would be ideal on a slow weekday night however when it's full it might be slightly too cozy, but you're sure to feel at home as part of the neighborhood. Also while we were dining it took slightly longer than I would have liked to get our waters refilled as well as to flag down the server for the bill at the end of our meal however this may have been due to the busyness of the night as the servers were constantly moving thought the evening. 

With the above being said I did enjoy the night out and I will return in the future, I'll just be sure to make reservations or attend on a less busy night the next go around.
author: Josh O.

description:
O-Toro has a very comfortable vibe, making it a good place to catch up with an old friend. We didn't order too much food, but the sushi and rolls we ordered were delicious. We also had hot sake (always great on a cold day).

I was able to easily make a reservation online. When we got there, we were seated immediately.
author: Emily Z.

description:
WOW!  I should have tried this place long ago!  Good location.  Great food.  Excellent service.  Reasonable prices.  Clean and pleasant.  I had a very nice experience from the moment I entered until the moment I left!  The spicy tuna was perfect and the hamachi melted in my mouth.  

I WILL be back!
author: Michael F.

description:
There are so many sushi joints around town, it's nice to find one that serves some hearty ramen that is more conducive to a rainy evening.  Small venue, but seemed easy enough to get a seat at the bar.  Definitely hit the spot.

Tori Karaage: From Oakland to Osaka, I guess everyone loves fried chicken!  Unlike like the Colonel's, these babies are all dark meat and without bones.  The chicken is ultra crispy and they have a light soy based sauce sprinkled on top to enhance the flavor.

Miso Ramen: The noodles tasted fresh and hearty, not like those cubes of ramen from a deli.  The roast pork was a little bland, the side of it could have been marinated better.   It was tender though.  Liked that the bamboo shots were tender, you'd be surprised at the tough ones some places will try to pawn off, like you're a panda or something.  There was a glob of baby spinach which made me feel like it was healthy.  The broth itself was a lot saltier (i.e. tastier) than typical miso.

Shoyu Ramen: The ingredients were the same as the miso, but the broth was clear and full of soyliciousness.  Might be my favorite of the broths, but such a shame they don't serve the richer tonkotsu ramen.
author: Adam B.

description:
A good Japanese restaurant in an unlikely location on Oak and Gough. I had high expectations for an authentic Japanese izakaya experience, and the food was good but not exceptional. 

Four of us met for a weekday dinner with a reservation. No problem with the reservation or service. There is a specials menu on a chalkboard by the sushi bar, with some interesting additions

We shared all of the dishes and a bottle of sake (I think it was Masumi) and came out a little over $30 per person, which is very reasonable

-Miso soup, standard and good to warm up
-Whole grilled squid with ginger (ika maruyaki), squid was cooked well, still soft
-Pork belly (buta kakuni) was quite delicious, two pieces which we split
-Beef tongue (gyutan) was on a skewer and good, though didn't bring out the flavor it could have
-Several rolls - yellow tail with scallion (negihama), spicy tuna, one of the eel rolls, salmon skin - quite good
author: Aki N.

description:
Otoro roll (favorite)
Lorelei roll
Hip Hop roll
Golden State roll

I would've loved to try all the rolls here, especially the Charmander roll and Lava roll, but I got a good sampling. I would definitely recommend getting the specialty rolls and none of the regular rolls. Aside from the rolls listed above, we also tried:

Tebo Shioyaki (great)
Gyu Nambanyaki (too tough)
Shiitake Tsumire (too small)

Overall, ok quality food and service.
author: Jennifer W.

description:
Made a dinner reservation for 7:15 on Friday night. Arriving right on time, we hardly were able to open the door. The restaurant itself is extremely small and on this night, the entrance was packed with people waiting to be seated. Clearly, the waitstaff was overwhelmed because it took them a while to even acknowledge us and ask if we had a reservation. I happened to glance at the OpenTable monitor and thought no big deal, we're at the top of the list anyway and since two tables just got up to leave, we'll be seated right away. Better yet, they had preassigned us to one of the tables that left already. 

Then we waited for 15-20 minutes. It's funny how you can look at a restaurant and judge them by how good or bad they would be at Diner Dash. They would probably get a low score here. After giving our table away to a larger walk-in party, we were finally seated at the bar. 

FOOD:
Miso Ramen - filling and large for one person but forgetful. We wanted to replace the urge of ordering miso soup. Pass next time.

*Cucumber with miso sauce - very thinly sliced cucumber with a good amount of the miso dressing that was refreshing and a great start

*Chicken Skin - horrible for your health but done well. Crispy on the outside and moist and chewy on the inside. Can't be worrying about what it says on the scale after this one.

Cherry Blossom Roll - typical roll with tuna and salmon but the flavors blended together, canceling out anything special about the roll

*HIP HOP ROLL - The best thing about Otoro may just be anything with their GARLIC ALBACORE

Despite the disappointment early on, Otoro made up for it with their food. And that's how I feel restaurants should be judged. Good luck finding a reservation and a parking spot though. 

FYI
Health score - 94 as of 12/2011
Parking - extremely difficult in this area at night
Wait times - longer than preferable
author: Dennis L.

description:
Update 9/4/12
Decided to give O-Toro a second try. Last night, I went there and had an amazing 4Star experience.

It is clear the Japanese Tapas are the strength of O-Toro. We started with the Shushito stuffed peppers with Spicy Tuna, which is one of the most amazing dishes I've ever had at a sushi restaurant.

Second, we tried the vegetable gyoza, which was also fantastic. The gyoza are stuffed with a delicate veggie mixture that is not just bland, but has some kick and surreal flavor. The gyoza are lightly pan fried and crispy on the edges to perfection.

Finally, we tried the Cherry Blossom roll and a simple Salmon Avocado with a few pieces of assorted sashimi. This time the fish and rolls seemed very fresh and full of flavor and not bland. Kudos!

Original Review August 2012 - 3Stars
I made my first visit to O-Toro last week and enjoyed the experience overall, but was left wanting/expecting more - especially at the price point. I was very excited to try O-Toro b/c there were several advertisements claiming the place to be Michelin recommended, which I know isn't a huge deal, but I expected more.

One key tip to know is this place is very tiny (maybe 8-10 tables, plus 6-8 seats at the bar), so during dinner hours, it's a really good idea to have a reservation, even for parties of 2, but certainly for parties of 4 or more.

The restaurant has a great ambience and feels very cozy. It is not very loud inside and the staff is incredibly helpful.

On our visit, we stuck mostly to sushi/sashimi and rolls and felt that the sushi was a bit bland and lackluster overall. Specifically, the specialty rolls were not that creative and were not that bold on flavors. The sashimi was certainly fresh and delicious, but serving sizes were very small given the price point.

After looking back at our experience, I think I will come back and focus on ordering more of the Japanese "Tapas" / Small entrees on the menu, as those dishes seemed more creative and more adventurous. The couple next to us looked as though they were being amazed by their food, which was all hot food, in contrast to our sushi experience.

My final conclusion is that O-Toro's sushi is average, but likely has some unreal hot dishes that our authentic Japanese cuisine, which I am looking forward to trying when I return.
author: Justin O.

description:
Fantastic fresh fish/seafood.  Delicious specials.  A rather small space that gets very loud - we went on a Saturday evening.  We come here for the food and not the quite atmosphere.  5-Star Food.
See you next time.
author: Darius A.

description:
mmmmmm..otorotorotorotorotoro

cute little joint with modern decor
service was great, and food arrived promptly even once the restaurant filled up
absolutely delicious sushi
intimate yet casual enough for each small table to enjoy their conversation

the udon wasn't as awesome, so I'd prolly try something else next time
..along with more otorogoodness, some of the best I've ever had
they have a wide selection of standard sushi as well as more creative rolls,
all extremely reasonably priced.
They seem to be busy even on week nights, so I'd recommend making a reservation!
author: Jade T.

description:
A little gem in the district of Hayes Valley.  Who would have thought this place existed? Never really venturing out to this area to eat are even hang out, it was the suggestion of a friend we decided to try out this tiny sushi place.  And yes, this place was really tiny -  with no more than 6 tables at most this place can easily get packed on a weekend night.

It's sashimi seemed to be the highlight of this place so I quickly decided on a couple of different nigiri orders and rolls.

Butterfish nigiri - really lived up to it's name.  It  seemed to just melt in my mouth.  Although it wasn't as rich as toro, it still was worth it due to it was probably half the price of toro.

Seared hamachi - my fav of the night!  They lightly seared the hamachi giving it a nice grilled flavor. To top it off they had a jalapeno on top of it to give it the extra kick it needed.  Absolutely delicious.  

Spicy hamachi - it was good but nothing too out of the ordinary.  Consisted of a 6 piece roll that had the spicy hamachi in a mayonnaise sauce.  Something I've had before but it was still good. 

Shout outs to the owner Jimmy who really took care of us from start to finish.  He personally took our orders and made sure that got everything we needed.  He even threw in some free sesame ice cream which really completed the experience.  I really enjoyed the food and atmosphere of the whole place.  Will absolutely drop by here for dinner again if I'm ever in the area.
author: Jenny H.

description:
Had lunch here yesterday.  Decided to try the seared hamachi belly sushi, pork belly, & beef tongue.  Sushi 2 pieces as expected.  Searing it took away the fatty texture I enjoy.  Would not order again.  Pork belly = 2 cubes about 1.5 inches all dimensions.  Tasty.  Beef tongue was grilled on a skewer, 1 piece about the size if my pinkie.  Not worth it.  I should have order a roll or noodle or something else.  Had to get back to work so left hungry.  
Will go back because there are other things I want to try.
author: David L.

description: Best sushi I've had in San Francisco. Fish has been fresh every single time I've gone. Their specials are always delicious, and their regular items are reliably great as well. Great ambiance and great sake, too.
author: Tori H.

description:
The restaurant is small but it looks nice and modern. We usually went here for lunch and got either ramen or the chicken katsu/teriyaki combo. I love the ramen with miso broth, it's delicious. The chicken katsu/teriyaki tastes descent, but I don't think there are a lot of room to mess these 2 dishes.

Service is very good. You can expect your tea to be refilled promptly. I probably drink 10 cups of green tea in one sitting. If I overdose on green tea, I gotta blame them.
author: Novalina N.

description:
O-Toro is a wonderful place for sushi - I come here so frequently that the manager Jimmy and I are besties.

I always order the O-Toro roll, why try anything else if you want the best? Having Bi-Rite ice cream right in the middle of Hayes Valley is also not a bad deal. Their other special rolls are yummy, though if you come with an empty stomach, you shoulder order a bunch. I don't think their single serving of sushi roll is enough. It is a bit on the pricey side - 6 friends and I came for dinner and we spent about $50 each for food and drinks. 

The environment is intimate and stylish, and it always looks full of young people and urban professionals.
author: Nancy L.

description:
Since I live in the Sunset and believe that most Asian cuisine is superior on the western part of the city, I was a little harder on this place in terms of seeing what I'd rate it. I've decided that this place gets three stars because it was good but overpriced. I can get the same quality of sushi just 15 minutes away in the inner Richmond for half the price. 

In their defense though, everything I had was quite good though.
author: Rylan C.

description: This is a cute little place. I have tried many of their rolls and sashimi pieces. And I have not been disappointed. The quality of the meat is good. And their udon is quite good as well. Just go ahead and order away:)
author: Maggie Z.

description:
Hm, I thought it'd be better because this place had good reviews but I walked away unimpressed.

I ordered:
spider roll: expensive for 5 (6?) pieces and sorta bland.
agedashi tofu: also sorta bland

Maybe I ordered the wrong dishes or something but I've had better Japanese food elsewhere. Most likely won't be back again.

Service was slow. Had to wait a long time to get our check.
author: Leslie C.

description:
I have only given a 1-star once before, but this place was just bad! The food was ok, nothing super incredible, but the service (especially the manager) was just despicable! We were a party of 6 who went out for a special occasion. When we were about to pay, we saw they had charged $20 for this tiny little scallop dish and figured it was pretty expensive for a few thin pieces of scallops. But then we saw that they had put three of them on the bill! We let them know about the mistake and explained that we hadn't ordered, nor received three. They finally corrected it but the manager had so much attitude and basically stood there and yelled and engaged in a fight with me over this! He totally destroyed the evening with his rude behavior. I had gone up to the register to take care of the issue so the table wouldn't feel uncomfortable, but he was so inappropriate that he, after having engaged in a huge fight over this, decided to go down to the table to involve the rest of the party! Unbelievable! 
Eeeeek! Methinks definitely not!
author: Yuan N.

description:
I wish I could comment on the quality of the sushi.  Unfortunately, we weren't served any. Waited for nearly a half hour to be seated, then another fifteen minutes to order.  Twenty minutes later, we asked the waitress what our chances were of being served before the performance we were planning to attend later that evening.  She assured us that she'd hurry our order to us.  The next time we saw her, she was delivering orders to tables that had been seated and ordered well after we arrived.  We paid for our drinks and left.  

If you like restaurants that treat you with contempt and make no apologies, this the place for you.  Personally, I will be having my sushi elsewhere.
author: Philip H.

description:
Went for dinner. Started off nicely with warm towels when we arrived but that was about the highlight. The food wasn't bad by any means but only average for sushi in San Francisco. If this were in South Bay this review would be four stars. 

It did have some unique rolls. Hip Hop and Otoro roll are highly suggested. I am not a tempura fan as it usually is heavy and seems to be dripping in oil. This was nice and added a little crunch to the roll. The Otoro roll was the best dish but I'm a mango whore. Good ripe mango that was draped over the roll nicely and added a bit of sweetness. If you are a big spicey tuna fan (emphasis on it having a bit of a kick) this is not for you. No kick. 

All in all not bad but the quality of the fish was below par.
author: C N.

description:
My family has been coming here for years. 
It has always been our sushi spot. We moved out of San Francisco, about 40 minutes away and still always come here just for the sushi.

In our experience, it is the best sushi in the Bay Area and we are sushi lovers. We attempted to try other places but once we found Otoro, we haven't been anywhere else.

Nothing else compares.
author: Kate B.

description:
One of the BEST sushi experiences I've ever had and that says A LOT bc I live for sushi and eat it every week. The main reason it is so good is the fish is ridiculously FRESH so if you like sashimi and nigiri this is the place to go. 

Also, the service is awesome! The waitresses and chefs are all so friendly and very attentive. They immediately refilled our sake glasses every time they were empty and brought us more wasabi without us even asking for it (we use a ton and ALWAYS have to ask for more). 

They also have some awesome specials with unique ingredients that change depending on what's fresh, which is how all sushi restaurants should operate.

This place is a must if you are a sushi lover!
author: Janina T.

description:
Like most places in the Hayes Valley, you'll drive or even walk right past it if you're not careful.  However, once you get inside, the decor is very sleek.  The one thing I noticed that might be an issue is all the tables are 2-tops.  Maybe you could combine them into something bigger, but this place isn't that large.

The lady and I ordered several special pieces of nigiri, I had a couple of rolls and we split some sashimi.  We were both pleased with the quality and taste of the nigiri (toro, butterfish, albacore, etc.).  I was also pleased with the rolls - negi toro, dreamy sensation, and krabby.  The gf isn't a huge fan of cream cheese in maki sushi, but I am.  The weird thing about the prices is that the maki rolls are either $6 or $12, nothing in between.  However it seems like a decent price for SF.  We only shared an order of salmon sashimi (5-pieces).  Although it was fresh, the texture was a little tougher than we're used to...I'm not sure how else to describe it.  And for $9, I would've expected closer to a full order of sashimi, like 8 pieces.  I guess that makes up for some of the inexpensive rolls.

Our server was pleasant enough and everything came out pretty quickly.

I'd eat here again, especially since it's only about 3 blocks from the War Memorial.  This is a good spot for pre-show sushi.
author: Dylan T.

description:
This place has become my favorite sushi spot.

It's small on the inside so I would recommend reservations.

The menu comes out on an iPad, which is kinda cool, but the germaphobe in me didn't like it too much.

We were recommended this role that had bits of fried garlic in between the fish and the rice.  The burst of garlic was a pleasant surprise.

Side note: they let you order sake while waiting for your table (major points!)
author: Mrs. N.

description: thursday dinner for five...beer and sake always first...viewing menu and chalkboard specials second....drinks flowing and hunger growing...few appetizers on a stick to start...beef tongue and chicken skin grilled...crispy crust chicken skin perfection....beef tongue nice chewy texture and fine...enormous sashimi platter second...basic cuts and specialties....some decent and some not...finding disappointment in extremely firm chewy o-toro...slightly fishy...confused by blue shrimp amaebi..never experienced raw blue shrimp....fried shrimp head battering bit thick and not as crisp...just edible..finding same in large omakase sushi platter...good and bad...but, sushi platter better.....still a great atmosphere to drink and eat...indulgence bringing total to $eighty per person....
author: Hen A.

description: Service was fast & friendly. Chef was very approachable and ensured the sushi was liking. Otoro was very tasty. Smooth and buttery...just as it should be. Small place, can get crowded but worth waiting for.
author: Mel F.

description:
They have an interesting variety of fish flown in fresh from Japan. The seared barracuda, in particular, has a nice texture and the right amount of umami. O-Toro is not my favorite cut of tuna in general, but theirs is admittedly smooth, decadent, and buttery.

One time I walked in and they were willing to seat me right away as long as I wrapped up before the next reservation arrived. I always respect a restaurant that is willing to put trust in their patrons. The flip side, however, is that since it is a small restaurant, if you have a late reservation, they might not be able to seat you on time if the previous party is lingering.
author: John T.

description: Worst service ever. We made a reservation and they made us wait 30 minutes for a seat. The waitresses are rude, food was average - Definitely not worth the wait and poor experienxe. Will not be returning again.
author: W H.

description:
Love Otoro Sushi! 
They are in the neighborhood from my work and my boyfriend and I decided to come here after work. I like them because even though they are small, there is never an outrageous wait which i appreciate. The sushi has always been fresh here and i like that they offer more than just your average sushi place.
We ordered Miso Ramen which was awesome on a cold rainy night. It was awesome. The people who work here are also always very friendly and smile. This is definitely a Hayes Valley go to and ill def. be back!
author: Scott Y.

description:
Heaven. In. Your. Mouth.

No need to check the Yelp Highlights- order anything and you'll be pleased. Sushi is fresh, sake is smooth, and service is amaze balls. Not only was our server "Ahmal" attentive.. so was the owner Jimmy. I'm a real stickler for good service so I'm so happy the service matches the food quality... for once! The place is small so definitely make reservations. 

I must say, I salivate when I think about the Golden State Roll. So the only bad thing I have to say is that you eventually get full and have to stop eating. Total bummer.
author: A W.

description: Delish sushi and excellent service in my neighborhood...we will be back!
author: Koshika S.

description: I arranged a dinner here with some girlfriends last night and made a reservation for 8:15pm. I arrived at 8:10 and wasn't greeted at the door for a while which didn't really bother me but the service went downhill from there so fast that I felt inclined to write this review. The waiter came over and asked 2 out of 4 of us what we wanted to drink and then walked off. He came back and asked what we wanted to eat and as we opened the menu up to remember what we wanted he walked off. When we finally got food ordered and to our table it was about 8:45. At 9pm we had a woman walk up to our table asking us to please pay because people had been waiting for our table for a while. What?? We had been there 45 min. She hovered around our table until we paid. I chugged my sake that I had to chase down our waiter for and left. The food was decent but there's other good places in the area that will treat you better, I don't plan on coming back.
author: Kristal G.

description:
I had the pleasure of checking out Jimmy's new restaurant last night with couple of close friends.  I have been a customer for years at his previous employer, and was anxiously waiting for this opening.

I expected the quality of the fish and the remaining dishes to be delicious... so that was not my worry.  I did have two concerns however: parking and price.  Surprisingly, parking around this area is not bad at all, especially after 6.  I saw plenty of metered and non-metered spots open around the block.  Prices were also very reasonable... seemed like there was no "S.F. premium"!

Decor is nice inside... feels cozy in a sense because there aren't that many tables.  Chef Maki is also very entertaining, so I suggest that you try to sit at the sushi bar if available.  Rest of the staff is kind as well, and service was prompt.

Ahh... time to detox from all the sake I drank last night... and upload these pictures...
author: Eric P.

description:
I could gobble down their delicious pieces of o-toro sushi all night long. And their seaweed salad is tasty too. 
I would have given it four stars had it been a little less pricey, and had the service been better. Not that the service is bad, it just didn't feel very welcoming.
author: Jenny F.

description:
Small sized restaurant but delicious and well priced for SF.

Our order:

1) Go Green roll: spicy hamachi, cucumber, top with kiwi - spicy fish contrasts with refreshing kiwi fruit!
2) Takashi roll: pumpkin tempura, topped with garlic albacore - yum, pumpkin!
3) Spicy tuna roll: good
4) Shishito (sweet pepper) stuffed with spicy albacore - good
5) Beef tongue - overcooked, kind of chewy
author: Mary W.

description: Really delicious sushi. We got the Lava roll and the Otoro roll, both of which I would highly recommend. I also really enjoyed the ambiance. It's intimate, but lively.
author: Brinley D.

description:
3.5 is the real rating.  I'd definitely recommend this joint, but it's not tops.

Brownie points:
-they let you design your own rolls
-good garlic white tuna nigiri
-good karaage, needs more lemon though
-helpful service, not the friendliest, but very helpful

OK points:
-good texture to agedashi tofu, not quite the right flavor
-not the most creative rolls menu

Minus points:
-no mochi

I will go back to try the skewers, kal bi, ramen...and make more rolls!

PS the acoustics get really noisy inside so this is not an ideal cozy date kinda place.
author: Priscilla T.

description:
Finally, I discovered an excellent place for sushi within walking distance of Davies Symphony Hall for nights that I crave for sushi dinner before a performance. It's a small restaurant with a very nice interior. The seating is limited, but since I came by myself I was easily seated at the sushi bar, with an empty seat beside me providing some space.

I'm used to ordering combo or chirashi plates, but here they didn't offer either during dinner. That's fine, it forced me to think more and be more creative in my ordering. :) I ordered a variety of nigiri sushi and a spicy hamachi roll. All were fresh and delicious.

The size was very size also. On top of that, the two young ladies working the tables were cute, in particular I admired the one with a touch of non-Asian look. :-D
author: H K.

description:
Everything was fresh, staff was on top of things and friendly but damn their portions SMALL. We ordered from the hot and cold plates as well as sushi. 
I went with three other adults and I know we all went home hungry and not satisfied. Not knocking the quality of the food just the potion sizes. I'm not a big eater either so if I'm complaining about small portions then trust me, they are microscopic. Maybe a good joint to go for a snack, not a meal.
author: S. M.

description:
y-u-m!!! I really liked Otoro Sushi. :)  Probably because the company was so awesome (it was a reunion with an old college buddy), but also because everyone was super nice and I love places with great service.  My good friend Eric knows Jimmy (the owner) - but everyone was so amazing.. it made the dining experience even better!  I'd definitely come here again for Jimmy's kindness, the hot Korean waitress, and the funny old sushi chef.

the sushi:  super fresh.  we had a ton of different types of fish (I'm not a sushi snob but thankfully Eric knew what he was ordering).  everything had a good proportion of fish to rice.  I know that good sushi is indicated not only through its fish, but also through the rice.  Both were great!

the menu items:  YUMMY.  The black cod dish (aka: Tara) is a must.  It just melts in your mouth and it's delicious and warm. :)  The duck livers were interesting - i'm not a fan of liver, but as long as you don't tell me what it is.. i'll try it.  i actually ate the whole thing.  one special comment:  the fried wontons.  as an asian chick, i don't usually waste money on wontons (cuz i know it's usually a cheap menu item that isn't worth it usually)... but wherever they get their wontons.. yum!! oooh ooh and the fried chicken wings.. not your typical chicken wings.  lightly battered and gently fried.  good match to a cool glass of beer.

drinks:  I told Jimmy that i'm not a big drinker so he made me a really light lychee martini.  it was pretty good.  not the best i've had but it had a really cool garnish. :) 

dessert: OMG. you must end your meal with the black sesame ice cream.  this is my new favorite flavor. :)  as a high purveyor of ice cream.. i will rank this high on my list. :)

overall a great experience and a great night to catch up with a good friend.  i would definitely recommend the place.  it's a small joint but you know it's good cuz it was continuously packed (and we were there for some time!!).  Service, food, and venue were great. Come check it out!
author: Kimmy C.

description:
This place was pretty good - good service and a nice sushi selection.

I've had better in the city, but for a place in Hayes Valley on Oak and Gough, it was tasty. 

It was a great spot to hit up before going to the ballet!
author: Kelly B.

description:
Disclaimer: I don't eat blue fin tuna (sushi tuna) anymore because it's overfishing is creating environmental problems all over the world. However, this restaurant offers a lot of other delicious alternatives.

I walked in wanting hot noodles because it was a particularly windy and chilly night. I noticed most of the reviews rave about how fresh the fish are, so I had sushi instead, partly because the prices were pretty good.

There is a blackboard by the sushi bar with their "fresh of the day," and if you get what's on the list you won't be disappointed. I ordered walu (butter fish) and lightly seared hamachi (yellowtail) and I was transported to sushi heaven. I savored every bit of flavour and enjoyed a small hot sake to wash it all down. I also had ikura (salmon roe) and a dragon roll (eel, snow crab, shrimp tempura, and avocado) which I thought were good as well. I would, however, recommend the fresh catch nigiri above all.

They also have tapas style hot dishes and a big selection of bottled sake to share with a group of friends perhaps. The kakuni (pork belly) is quite good. The place is small though, so if you intend to show up with a group it's a good idea to RSVP.
author: Rina W.

description:
With dark wood accents and muted walls, Otoro offers a decidedly down-tempo, loungey atmosphere in which to enjoy your raw fish fix.  However, this newcomer offers nothing that you can't get from any other established sushi join in SF.

Overall, the fish was good.  Two standouts were the masu (sea trout) and the toro (fatty tuna).  However, Otoro made two mistakes that call into question their commitment to presenting the best dishes possible:  (1) Served cold, the edamame had a pasty texture indicating that it had been overcooked and refrigerated, rather than prepared to order.  (2) The slightly shriveled ikura (salmon roe) was noticeably old.

Otoro is fine overall, but with Sebo and Sushi Domo in the neighborhood, I'm not sure we need another sushi restaurant in Hayes Valley.
author: CJ G.

description:
Not that great. The sushi was mediocre..as were all the hot dishes we ordered. Sad to say I also had the worst bowl of ramen I've ever had here. Even instant noodles tasted better than the Miso Ramin I got. Yuck.

That said, the staff is very accommodating and fast!
author: Nadiyah S.

description: One of the best sushi restaurants I have had in San Francisco!  Loved the fresh scallops, unagi was fresh and not too sweet. Not a huge fanboy BBQ tuna but it was done very well. Shoko is very friendly  with great service and a smile!  Will definitely be back and soon!
author: Patty H.

description: Meh. My food was pretty good sushi, though nothing memorable. My partner ordered vegetarian ramen, and got something with pork in it. We were in a rush so didn't ask them to change it, and I'm sure they would have. Overall fine but probably wouldn't repeat it given the bounty of good restaurants in that hood.
author: David P.

description:
Very good fish. 
Salmon belly, walu, scallop, hamachi.. all was so soft and good!
author: I B.

description: The first miso Ramen I've ever had that was not too salty for me! The noodle soups have huge portions and the miso Ramen seemed the biggest (my friends ordered the chicken udon). The bamboo shoots were really flavorful and there were lots of green veggies, which I was happy about. The restaurant is on the smaller side so made sure to make a reservation!
author: Nancy C.

description: This place is nothing special IMO... why?!?! Because they didn't make the rainbow roll correctly and they did not have a depth of rolls. Plus I don't think they had alot of tuna. Still the rolls we got were tasty. The service was really nice we were fit in lasy min on Valentines day after being turned down by 10 other restaurants.
author: Christopher C.

description: I love the stir fried mixed vegetables. The ubon is a bit salty. Unagi ushi is great!
author: QL M.

description: Very interesting sushi menu...many outside the normal options to try. Def my sushi spot in SF
author: Joe C.

description:
My friend and I came here after going to Sushi Zone (1-hour wait!) and Domo (30-minute wait!). At O-Toro, it was 15-minutes. Note to self... Thursdays are busy sushi nights apparently. 

O-Toro is pretty small and we ended up sitting at the bar which I liked. It's a tight squeeze at the bar too but we were at the end so a little more breathing room there. 

We had a few appetizers - pork belly and seaweed salad. Pork belly was good though the meat a little overcooked when it was thicker. The fatty part was yummy. Seaweed salad is pretty routine - a small portion though. We got a few simple roles - none of the specialty roles. Roles were fine - nothing stood out but nothing to complain about either. I had an order of salmon sashimi which was good and fresh - thinner slices but decent portion. 

Overall, it was a good meal - 3.5 stars. Nothing over the top, but satisfactory. Staff is really nice so that's why I give a 4. I wish there were more options in SF for sushi/japanese. In comparison with So California/LA, I feel like SF is much more limited. I'm not sure I'd come here again as I don't really live/work nearby, but it's a good option to have if you do.
author: Veronica H.

description:
One of my top picks for sushi in San Francisco. In particular, O-Toro is reasonably priced and a good choice for sushi when you don't want to go completely balls out. There is always great presentation with a lot of variety in the sushi and sashimi. It's quality all the way around and it's also usually possible to get a table on short notice.

O-Toro has the distinction of being the only restaurant where I've received an ovation from an entire restaurant. As I was wrapping up the bill at our table which was several feet from the bar, one of the waitresses accidentally knocked over one of those large ceramic sake carafes. It began to slowly roll toward the edge of the table. The waitress grabbed for it but it was just out of her reach. Acting on my innate ninja instinct, I lept about 6 feet forward landing on my right foot and catching the carafe with my left hand simultaneously. 

The action in the restaurant paused for a moment and then everyone started applauding me. After the applause died down, the maître d' bought me and my friends a round of some decent sake. It was a slightly embarrassing but mostly proud moment. I just hope next time I go there I can live up to my reputation.
author: Aaron V.

description:
Came with three friends for dinner on a Saturday night. We decided about 7pm, and the earliest we could get in would be at 9:30p. The place is tiny and gets packed. We didn't get seated until maybe 25 min after our reservation. But the host was very nice about it and really, you can see all the tables, so they couldn't have done anything.

Now, on to the food. We got the Hawaiian poki, spicy tofu salad, pork belly, chicken hearts, yakitori, o-toro (fatty tuna) nigiri, saba (mackerel) sashimi, spicy tuna, salmon avocado, caterpillar and dreamy sensation rolls. So much food.

The standouts: O-toro (so smooth and fatty, just melted in my mouth), pork belly (two huge pieces with a tasty sauce and smear of mustard), saba (first time I've tried it) and all the rolls were delicious.
The ones I would pass on: Not that they were bad, just not as good as everything else. Chicken hearts, hawaiian poki, yakitori. Maybe I was just in a sushi only kind of mood.

Environment: tiny space, loud, some bar seating otherwise in tables.
Service: friendly and prompt. Told us when the kitchen was closing so we could make any last orders. Asked if there was anything wrong with the yakitori since we were too full to finish.
author: Kailyn G.

description: O-Toro is one of my favorite lunch getaways. They have specials for around $10. Sometimes I get the shoyu ramen. If I do, I get it spicy. Sometimes I get the sashimi. That's usually if I'm with someone and we want to share. The fish is fresh and pretty good quality. I try and get there early so there isn't a wait. It can get busy over the lunch hour. I've only been for lunch. I'd like to go for happy hour or for dinner sometime. If I do, I'll get try the Japanese tapas. Looks like they have a pretty decent selection of drinks too. Since the restaurant is small, I could see it being a lot of fun on a Friday night.
author: Kelly C.

description: Good sushi, good service. Menu has good variety from sushi to izakaya style small plates. They also had a focus on sustainable seafood.  Food was good. Pricey, with portions on the smaller side.
author: Harry K.

description: Little Hayes Valley sushi gem. Amazingly fresh and delish rolls, nigiri. Loved the crispy tempura. The hamachi Kama melted in my mouth
author: S V.

description:
sushi was good but not amazing and service was disappointing. 

i tried to make resos for 2 but they were full. they 'strongly recommended' we should walk-in bc they have room for walk-ins. that sounded promising enough for us to go. when we got there they said the wait was 20 minutes. no problem! we got a drink and chatted. 20 minutes went by and nothing but who really expects the estimate to be accurate? more time passed and tables opened up but they didn't seat anyone. i figured they were for reservations but they held them empty for at least 15 minutes while there were several waiting parties packed in their tiny space. it was a third of all their seating! they also seated a party of 2 at a 4-top when there was a 2-top open which i didn't understand. we finally got seated at the bar AN HOUR+ later. that happens but what's super irritating is that they are super unapologetic about it.

another thing that i thought was strange was that when you sit at the bar you don't order sushi from the chefs. that's the perk of the bar!

i'd maybe go back if i had reservations but from reading the reviews here it seems those aren't managed very well either.
author: Emily C.

description: Great atmosphere. Eclectic variety. Delicious sushi and miso soup.
author: Kelly W.

description: came here on a Tuesday night to celebrate my friend coming to visit.. Rolls are delicious here... We had the rock n roll and caterpillar both of which were amazing! Their karage was a little dry but still well spiced and tasty.. All in my only complaint is that it is a little pricy... Between the two of us we spent around 110... I guess it's not horrible considering how much we drank
author: James H.

description: Solid sushi spot, one of my favorites i the city --- very fresh and nice ambiance AND not too crowded on a weeknight, so I like that I can just walk in for dinner after work and have some warm sake and food immediately!
author: Shivani S.

description:
Never knew this place existed since it is tucked away off Gough. it is a cute place and if you walk in, you are likely to get a table or seat at the bar rather quickly. 

The thing I liked the most about O-Toro is that they have hard core sushi for sushi lovers, but also have a lot of Japanese Tapas and ramen, udon and soba dishes for people like me. I ordered the miso ramen and it was HUGE! The waitress warned that it was a large bowl, and it definitely was. The broth could have been seasoned a little more for my taste, but I really enjoyed the corn, seaweed, bamboo shoots in my ramen.

They also have BiRite ice cream and this black sesame ice cream from Japan, which was delicious!
author: Natalie S.

description: Really, really, really amazing fish assortment.  I can't recommend anything specific because when I've gone it's always been an avalanche of randomly ordering whatever was up on the specials board and just gorging myself.  Also, I always seem to get the same waitress (she seems to be the only one) who makes absolutely exquisite recommendations each time, not just for seafood, but sake as well.  The price point is higher than other sushi restaurants I may casually attend, but the quality of the fish absolutely makes up for it.  It wouldn't be my every day sushi restaurant because of the price point, but when I want something special I know where to go - here.
author: William C.

description:
Otoro Sushi is my favorite place for sushi in San Francisco. First, the fish is very fresh and the variety of dishes (not just sushi) is amazing. Second, the service is outstanding. They always remember us! The staff consists of the same people. We have always received such a warm welcome. 

We always order "omakase" (whatever the chef suggests) and that is what I recommend that you do. The prices are reasonable considering the quality of the food.

Ambiance: it is a small, intimate place which is perfect for dining with friends or business colleagues. 

Crowd: young, chic and mostly Asian (which I find to be a big plus).

I really love Otoro Sushi and recommend it to anyone who likes sushi in San Francisco.
author: Esme V.

description: The place is small, so make sure to have reservations. Ambiance is nice for dates as well as small groups (6 or less). Sushi was made fresh and tasted good, but there wasn't anything super special about this place.
author: Kim L.

description:
Small portions - seaweed salad was tiny in comparison to the one at Domo but about the same price. 
Place is small-  probably not ideal for big groups.
Service was great- very attentive staff. Also the green tea was strong (which is a good thing!) and the refills free and continuous.
Spicy tuna roll was good, but I appreciated Domo's more. This one had a creamy consistency (I want to say mayonaise-y but I dont actually think there was mayo in it ), whereas the one at Domo was more fresh, clean cut, pure fish. Spicy tuna roll was reasonably priced. But their specialty rolls were in the $13 range.
I'd be interested to try their ramen - especially on a cold rainy day I think it could be really satisfying. 
Finally, they were out of Bi-Rite ice cream.
author: Kimya P.

description:
Mmmmmm....sushi. Just thinking about my dinner on Saturday is making my mouth water. I've been driving past O-Toro for years but have never actually made the trek to Hayes Valley to eat there. I'm usually too distracted by other options, like Absinthe. Anyways, my friend and I decided to finally go in for dinner. 

Pros:
- The fish is amazing! Fresh and served in perfect portions. Each piece of the roll was bite sized...didn't have to figure out how to bite it in half and still keep everything together. The rolls were also not overloaded with sauces, which meant you could actually enjoy the flavor of the fish itself. 
- The atmosphere is cozy-neighborhoody. There was a large group in one corner that was clearly celebrating and a family with two small boys. It was fun to watch the younger child chow down on the sushi...he could not get enough of the salmon sashimi.
- It was a touch pricier than I usually pay for neighborhood sushi, but the freshness and overall quality made up for that. 
- Decent wine list and really well priced...mark up wasn't nearly as high as I was expecting. 

Cons:
- Make a reservation. They are on Open Table, and it will save you from a long wait. We had one, but the group of three girls behind us did not. While they were happy spending a half an hour with sake, I would have been annoyed. 
- The service was mediocre. The servers were friendly, but slow. I couldn't tell if they were short staffed that night or what, but it took about 20 minutes to have someone take our order. 

Overall
A solid sushi choice in Hayes Valley...I'll give it another go if I'm in the neighborhood.
author: Jenn G.

description: Love this place. The tapas are some of the best in the city. The staff is friendly, the environment is cozy and intimate - perfect for a date night, and the fish is fresh and delicious. This is one of the only places I think the takeout is just as good as the in-house dining.
author: Alex C.

description:
Pretty good sushi and not overly expensive. It's a TINY tiny place, which seems to be the norm for trendy neighborhood restaurants of SF. They have maybe four tables that can seat 4 people, one 2 person table, and then the sushi bar that seats about 8-10. 

I opted for an assortment of sushi while my friend got the ramen. We ended up sharing everything and here are my thoughts on all the items:
