-Otoro- despite the name of the restaurant, this wasn't very good. The color looked great, but there was a sinewy bottom to mine. Maybe it was a fluke, but I like my toro to be melt-in-the-mouth good. It's hard for the fish to melt in your mouth when there is a stringly part. disappointing for $12
- Garlic albacore - absolutely melt in your mouth delicious. I would recommend this one. 
- Kanpachi(amberjack) - very good, very fresh.
- Sake(salmon) - standard salmon, not bad not great.
- Grilled chicken skin - squeeze some lemon on this..it is amazing. 
- Shoyu ramen - really good ramen considering this is a sushi place. I was pleasantly surprised, especially since I was bitching at my friend for getting ramen at a sushi join. Everything was on the slightly sweet side, but the soup was really soothing.
- Spicy tuna toll - standard fair
- Salmon skin roll - now, this item came out as an accident because the kitchen took my grilled chicken skin order wrong and thought it was salmon skin roll. I tried it without knowing what it is, and did not like it at all. To be fair, i never ever order salmon skin roll but out of the few times I've had salmon skin roll, they were better than this one. 

It's a solid sushi place even though I'm sure there are better in the city. I strongly recommend making reservations.
author: Julie K.

description: Sushi was pretty good.
author: Michael E.

description:
This is one of those places you want to tell your friends about.  It's a nice little sushi place in San Francisco that's not trying to rip you off with Philadelphia rolls.  

Otoro means Fatty Tuna, and yes they have it. Highly recommended. Also if you have the nerves, try the barracuda. It's not going to blow you away, but you can brag to your friends about it, and that's worth the price alone.
author: Mike C.

description: I walked out of here on cloud nine. The 1) hamachi carpaccio with truffle oil and 2) otoro sushi are game changers.  They topped it off with great service.  I was happy to find black sesame ice cream too.   Yummy!
author: Jenny K.

description:
Snagged a seat as a walk-in, so truly lucked out.  Edamame was a bit tough, but the pork belly was surreal.  Richly flavored and felt like butter.

Sushi was delicate and smooth, very flavorful.  Would go back in a heartbeat. Service was prompt and attentive.
author: David S.

description: Great place for date night! Had a sake flight while waiting for the table and then got a series of amazing rolls! Really fresh and delicious. Best restaurant experience I've had in SF thus far.
author: Alex A.

description: Tiny little restaurant, but still gets the job done. They take reservations, which is helpful for a large group. The sashimi was fresh and delicious. We also tried the eggplant appetizer dish, which was a little too salty for me. The tempura is a great option for vegetarians. We had the pork belly, which was very tasty, but a little heavy and strange to eat alongside sushi. We tried chicken heart skewers, which they seasoned and fried like no other, so it was very good, and did not taste weird like chicken heart normally kind of does. Service was a little slow, but very friendly. Parking is a huge pain. Consider public transit.
author: Jamie C.

description:
Awesome sushi place. Great daily specials, good fish. I especially liked the o-toro roll and sake butteryaki. The atmosphere seemed like an interesting combination of zen + yuppie. Super close set tables - expect to hear adjacent conversations. 
Only sore point was our server seemed a tad snooty at first, but her attitude seemed to change based on the amount of food we ordered (expecation of a bigger tip?). In any case, the food trumped her attitude, and we'd go back again if we were in the neighborhood.
author: Shweta V.

description: I live around the corner and called for a takeout order of nabeyaki udon. They said ready in 5 minutes, which it was. $16 got me a salty soup with noodles, a couple pieces of chicken, half a boiled egg, some spinach and a shrimp tempura. Pretty sad. Would come back to try the sushi, but noodles are defiantly not worth it!
author: Lindsay C.

description: I love ramen and nigiri and this was not the place to get it. The food was overpriced and the fish and ramen were bland. I left feeling unsatisfied and wished I had gone to another sushi restaurant instead.
author: Ashlie C.

description: Came to this restaurant for my Brother-in-Law's birthday, and it was definitely crowded.  It's a very small space, so definitely make a reservation.  The service and the food was definitely great, and I would definitely come back!
author: Jackee K.

description:
I took my family & friends there on Friday. The restaurant was loud and busy; our waitress did not have a clear command of english. So in that interaction, somehow my order of kampachi sashimi ($12) became two orders of the chefs special sashimi platter ($500!!), in addition to the almost $200 of additional sushi orders.

We noted the error immediately, and one of the platters was snatched from us. We asked how much the platter left behind cost, and we were ignored for 30 minutes -- no water, all other orders withheld. The manager gave us an angered standoff about the price of fish, and demanded that we pay for the mistake.

All in all, extremely awkward and tense. Such a shame, because the meal would otherwise have been lovely.
author: T K.

description: My absolute favorite sushi restaurant in San Francisco. Everything's super fresh and delicious!
author: Stephanie C.

description:
I came here with a girlfriend for lunch and was pleasantly surprised with their nice service, super fresh fish, and atmosphere. I have walked by this place before and it seems to be quite busy at night and now I know why! 

We ordered salmon sashimi and two or three other rolls which were all very delicious and fresh. The atmosphere is great because the restaurant only seats about 20-30, so it's a great intimate place to bring a potential date! Would definitely come back again.
author: Marina S.

description: This place continues to impress :) highly recommend for lunch or dinner. The truffle hamachi appetizer & Hip Hop roll are my favorite!
author: Tori M.

description:
Our table was the scene of a feast. We could barely fit all of the rolls we ordered and ourselves around the table. The rolls were spot on with fresh fish, a bite to the rice and a balance of flavours. My favourite? The feature one entitled "The Grasshopper" which was slathered with avocado and filled with unagi yumminess!

O-Toro is small, the place is a tight fit. We reserved for 4 and arrived with 5 in our party, and they did a good job at accommodating us at a table in the corner. However, service was uncomfortably slow, from getting our drinks to them bringing the cheque. If you're having a leisurely dinner, you'd feel at home here, but anything faster than snails pace, and you might want to consider another venue. 

Really though, that's my only lament. With good company, and some sake, the time went by quickly.
author: Crystal H.

description:
L: "Hi, Dinner for 2?"

J: Um, sorry we are busy tonight."

[looks around at a semi-full restaurant with people getting ready to leave]

L: "Are you serious?"

J: "Yes, I'm sorry."

L: "Damn, he must have read my Yelp review."
author: Lisa W.

description:
O-Toro! I am proud to be mayor of this place (at least for the moment) on four square. Relatively cheap and delicious eats + friendly service! The owner/manager, a bald asian guy, always smiles and greets me when I stop by for a bite.

My favorites to order as appetizers are either the fried tofu or roasted eggplant ($5 each) and as for rolls, their eel and avocado roll is only $5 (as are most of their traditional maki rolls). However they always have a menu or ever-changing specials and speciality rolls. The Otoro and Lava rolls are really yummy in particular. 

Other cool things they have include bi-rite ice cream as well as black sesame ice cream imported from Japan and refreshing iced green tea. I love this place, so sad that I don't live close by anymore.
author: Sabrina M.

description: Food was tasty, but a bit on the expensive side. We had reservations, but still had to wait ~15 min to be seated. The water glasses smelled like a fish tank.
author: Gregg M.

description: Excellent customer service, ambiance and fresh sushi with great seasonal rolls. Takashi and Golden Gate rolls are a must!!
author: Adrienne L.

description:
O-Toro Sushi - I really really like you. 

They are so small inside, yet make up for it with fresh sushi and lots of heart. We had really nice service, weren't rushed in and out, and only had to wait about 10 minutes for a table on a Wed. night. Sushi roll prices were reasonable to and they had a good mix of specialty and regular sushi rolls. 

Favorites: Negi Hama - good small basic roll. Loved the Cherry Blossom - worth the $$. Tempura Roll was a nice change from the fresh rolls. They all had very good flavors. 

Only minus - glasses of wine seemed a little steep at $8 for brands that are not very expensive bottles. 

Overall great atmosphere, good food and very friendly service.
author: Natalie N.

description: I'm a fan. The waiter knows my usual order and recognize me when he sees me around the neighborhood. Yeah, I guess I come here a lot.
author: Diana G.

description:
New sushi joint, and its really very good. We ordered A LOT:
green salad, spicy tofu salad (not spicy, but good tofu -- really yummy), carpaccio (loved the fresh jalapeno), spanish mackeral (not my fave), Hawaiian roll (tuna w/ macadamia nuts--mmmm) etc. My friend's pricey specialty roll with salmon and lemon and crab was OUTSTANDING -- truly the standout of the evening. They were very attentive with tea refills. Owner dude is hilarious. He kiss-raped my friend (a male) on the lips as we were leaving.
author: Andrew K.

description: The place is kind of hidden like a gem. The food is reasonably priced for the neighborhood. The fish was fresh and the broth that was with the soup was flavorful. The soba is served hot which made the noodles a bit too soggy. There was something missing with the ramen...until we found the chili powder. The lava roll was good but on the smaller side. It was a good meal just nothing out of the ordinary.
author: Eve C.

description:
I'm typically not good with my nigiri - I'm more into rolls, really. Ha definitely no sushi connoisseur, here. My companion and I went here the other week, and, while I don't know my nirigi, he certainly does. 

He ordered a handful of nigiri, but unfortunately I don't remember all of the orders. I do remember we ordered salmon nigiri and raw scallops. Both were absolutely DELICIOUS, especially the salmon nigiri. The salmon wasn't too overwhelming in "fishy" taste, and melted in my mouth. Amazing. The scallops were also really good, but I'm typically not a huge fan of scallops. 

I really wish I remembered the rest of our order, as everything was very tasty. The chefs also make sure you enjoy your dish but checking up on you, too. 

I highly recommend coming here! Even the signature rolls look awesome! I'll definitely be coming back again!
author: Kristina K.

description: Great ambiance, good service. Great vegetarian sushi selection. Will return.
author: Emily H.

description:
Single diner, Omakase at the bar, a not busy Monday prime time. They didn't ask any questions about how much or what I liked, they just brought me $100 worth of food, which I thought was way too much for someone dressed down in a t-shirt and not drinking. I know, I ordered Omakase without specifying a limit, eff me right?

I've had Omakase at pricier restaurants but was very surprised to see that they just included a $15 tempura and $20 sliced scallop alongside 5 nigri + 4 sashimi. The fish was of varying quality, the namesake toro and bluefin was great (although I've had better), the snapper and amberjack were poor.

In my opinion, not the kind of place you can order just anything or trust the cook's judgment. This is the most frustrating kind of sushi joint - hit or miss.
author: Mitch G.

description:
Probably one of my favorite sushi places in sf! I can always count on fresh fish and reasonable prices. 

Its a small intimate place that still has a modern feel and I like that it doesn't get too crowded. So far I've been able to just walk in and get seated right away. 

Craving for it right now as I type...
author: Bernadette L.

description: Really great sushi!!  Loved the hamachi carpaccio with truffle oil and the hip hop roll is very good.  Small place, so you definitely need to make a reservation.
author: Tracy W.

description: Took the Mrs. here last Friday after work and got seated at the sushi bar... Got 2 rolls: O-Toro and Hip Hop,  and a bunch of nigiri: O-Toro, Amaebi, Uni, Walu, and Red Snapper... This place is on the small side and probably can get a little busy. The service was good and the food was on point. Good job O-Toro, I would definately come back and recommend this place.
author: Barry H.

description:
Excellent food, very nicely decorated and friendly sushi chefs. 

I stopped by on a Thursday night and ordered the Fatty Tuna sushi and it was yummy. (be sure to ask what market price is: $25 for this meal scared me when I saw my bill, but wow, was it ever delicious!).

Ordered a spicy hamachi and it was fabulous and my next maki roll I requested a little less spicy and they accommodated that request perfectly. Highly recommended!

Can't talk about parking since I walked there, but still, I think everyone should walk after a big meal here!
author: Patrick E.

description: good little intimate stop for some a-ok sushi.  definitely not the worst i've had, but not the best either.. good toro nigiri!
author: Laura M.

description: Came here for my 30th birthday for dinner with friends and I've got to say that this place rocks! Great atmosphere, excellent service and very, very good sushi.
author: Toan D.

description:
The sushi was absolutely wonderful!

The sushi was fresh and flavorful. Had a couple of rolls, eel, salmon, and seaweed salad. Everything was delicate and tasty.  

It's a small place; the atmosphere is cozy. 

I am looking forward to going back for another meal.
author: Jennifer And Uri W.

description: I thought it was weird to have to wait 20 minutes for a table, even though we had a reservation. However, it was worth the wait. Some of the best sushi I've ever had, and the service was really good.
author: Kane A.

description:
All I remember is the takashi roll (tempura pumpkin roll with garlic tuna on top!!!) and the agedashi tofu.  

and the BLACK SESAME ICE CREEEEAAAAMMM!

good memories.
author: Laura B.

description: The seared fatty tuna and salmon were divine!
author: Stacey L.

description:
I will have to go back to be double...if not triple sure of my 5 star review... because well...recently I have had some health problems that have really limited my diet. I mean, I can eat only processed foods and like broth and soups and stuff. Boring!!

So after a long day at Wondercon in a ton of pain (the con was great...my insides were not so much)...we drove towards The Smugglers Cove...but since they were not open and we were hungry..

Sadly... most places I can not eat at...so I earlier in the day had voted sushi..because I could get things like...rice...hahaha 

Ok ok... so its like 4:15...we find out no sushi is open until 5 so we just wander around. After searching Yelp on my blackberry we found 2 places that opened at 5...one was only 2 blocks away so off we walk some more (feet tired)

There were 4 chairs outside of O-Toro ... and 10 minutes until they opened. Perfect.

Right at 5 they seat us...

Looking over the menu I had pretty much figured I would be stuck with miso and rice for dinner...with with the way I was feeling, was fine with me... but to my surprise ...they had ramen on the menu!!

I ordered the shoyu ramen (did I spell that right??) ... the boys ordered sushi ...and some sake flights.  Yes folks...just like when you are at a wine place and want to try a few kinds of wine...they have SAKE FLIGHTS!!

Everyone was happy... we were thrilled... I mean seriously. This was the best ramen I have had outside my own house. The broth was flavorful but not fatty... (like some other ones have been in the past) ...but yeah.. YUM YUM YUM.

We made out of there for about 100 bucks....it was very well worth it. Everyone was smiles...we were totally full.

I promise as soon as I am better...I will go back and try more things! They had Japanese tapas and tons of yummy sounding sushi...I am excited to go back.

If you are up there ...living close enough (San Jose is not close enough for me!) ...then make sure you get some yummy stuff in your tummy and visit O-Toro sushi!!
author: Jessica M.

description:
I'd be giving 5 stars to O-Toro, except they're just too pricey for us to dine there more than occasionally, which is a bummer because their food is fabulous, their seafood is very fresh, and their chefs are creative. 

Average Yelp price says $$, but be prepared to pay well over $30 a person if you get drinks (sake included), appetizer and more than one serving of sushi per person. 

Their pork belly is phenomenal and I always order it. Always. 

Their rolls are very good, but their sashimi and nigiri are better, if you have to choose between one or the other. Their unagi is very decent, but not the best I've had in the city. 

Service has always been 100% friendly and attentive.
author: Andrea B.

description: A bit of a long wait, but good original rolls and sushi!
author: Lorenzo R.

description:
My favorite sushi place in Hayes Valley! The quality of the food and dining experience is always good and gets better each time I go. 

Sake flight and beef asparagus wraps are two things I really look forward to when I go. Everything I've ordered off of the Specials Menu has been melt-in-my-mouth delicious.

Fairly small & not too loud, it's great for a group of 2-4. For a group of six, id definitely suggest making a reservation. Owner & staff are awesome!
author: Niki C.

description:
Another very trendy, expensive spot. One time they "lost" our reservation, which instead seemed like we fit bumped for a regular. So if you do want to regularly drop $9 (minimum) for an order nigiri, this what you can expect:

-it is always packed and service will be slow
-extensive sake menu ad knowledgeable staff who can help you pick the right bottle
-creative rolls and fresh exotic fish

I highly recommend sitting at the bar and talking with the sushimen. If you buy them beer expect some good stories and possibly some freebies as the night wears on. There are excellent items on their itzakya menu as well, but it's really all about the sushi here. It is expensive and slow which is why I dock stars; Sushi Delight is less expensive, has shorter wait time and has just the same quality, just less innovative in rolls, though some might say that would make it more authentic than a place with mango in their maki. Still, this O-Toro is a great date spot, especially if you want to flex your baller-ness and is a fun place to get drunk with you bros/ladies off good beer/sake with really fun sushimen.
author: Benjamin M.

description: Decent, reasonably priced, sushi in Hayes Valley.
author: Michael S.

description:
Yummy!!! everything was super good. Came on a Friday with a friend. A little long wait (tiny place) but they served us saki while we waited!  I had Yelp'd for ramen (craving all day) and found this place. We were sharing our meal and they split the ramen bowl for us!

the food was delicious, but kinda small portions.
author: Angela B.

description:
Some of the best sushi I've had in San Francisco.

We had: 
- Kobe Beef with Asparagus Tapas Appetizer
- "Gold" Sake Flight
- Miso Soup
- Spider Roll
- Dragon Roll (Eel, Tempura Shrimp, Crab)
- California Roll
- Salmon Nigiri
- Wild King Salmon Nigiri

Pros:
- The person who sat me (sounds like Jimmy, the owner) remembered my name from when I stated it to claim my reservation at the beginning throughout the meal, which was a very personal touch.
- The food was high quality and very filling
  - The Kobe appetizer in particular was amazing - and real Kobe, not Wagyu
  - I highly recommend the sake flight. 
  - While not #1, the miso soup was on par with other high-end restaurants I've visited
  - Same for California roll
  - Some of the best Nigiri I've ever had - the chef was definitely experienced enough       to properly moderate the wasabi. 
  - Food presentation was a major plus
- The service was mostly flawless - quick to bus dishes and refill water
- Jimmy and the sushi chef were both very nice and knowledgeable - I asked a question about my sake and received an educated answer. 
- Very nice tapas selection
- Very good sake selection

Cons:
- My date ordered hot tea that never came
- I had a reservation for 9:30PM but I had to wait 5-10 minutes to get seated.
- Definitely not good for a group of more than 4 people.
author: Tim W.

description:
A little mishap with our reservation is the only part that went a little haywire. Otherwise the place was smooth as butter and the food was OMG delicious. I usually worry that I will be hungry right after with sushi, nope! We ordered a ton of food... at least 8-10 rolls. The bill before tip was about $90 I think. Yea check that math, it means great prices for good sushi. 
Its small, intimate and the service is spot on. Attentive, good suggestions but also knew how to leave us to enjoy. Not to mention that they came by to let us know when they would be closing soon so we could order more if we wanted to. Thank you, cause we did. I can't wait to go back here.
author: Natasha M.

description:
2.5 stars.

I wouldn't call myself a sushi snob per se...but I do love it and have it enough to know what's good.  

Otoro isn't bad, but with all the amazing places around the city, it's nothing to write home about.  The sushi selection is kind of scant although the rest of the menu has much more of a variety for both hot and cold appetizers and noodle (udon, ramen, soba) options.

I had a Philadelphia Roll and the lunch special (saba, rice, miso soup, and salad).  The roll was alright, but the miso soup was way too salty and the saba left me feeling kind of sick the rest of the day...I love fish, but it was really fishy (if that makes sense!)

My dining companion had the soba noodles which seemed like it had a lot of ingredients in it  He finished it all, so I don't think there were any complaints there.

Though the food was just alright, the place loses some points for service.  There was only one waiter and even though it wasn't busy, he left the restaurant for a few minutes!  He was outside and I saw him move some of the parking restriction signs...and meanwhile my sushi was waiting on the counter.  I hope he washed his hands before serving our food... 

Tip: this place does serve Bi-Rite ice cream!
author: Alvina W.

description:
Very good sushi!  Place is small - could be a bit to wait - I would suggest try and definitely make reservations prior to getting there - fortunately you can even do it on the way to the restaurant (which is what we did).  

I really enjoyed the food - highly recommend Otoro specialty roll and the butter fish (on the Specials Menu - check chalkboard near the bar).  The butter fish - literally melts in your mouth - sooo good!  A must try!

Only criticism - place is small - otherwise food, atmosphere, ambiance A+ - and the bathroom was clean!  :) 
Price wise - its pretty on-par with standard good sushi ~$20-25/pp (w/out drinks).  I will definitely go back.
author: Bhavin M.

description: Such great sushi! I was in town and popped into O-Toro based on good yelp reviews and close proximity to the ballet. I was feeling adventurous so I sat at the bar and asked the chef to surprise me with some of his favorite rolls. He did not disappoint! My favorite was the lollipop roll which was delicious and beautiful. There was a nice sake selection, too.
author: Karen G.

description: Consider the Price, the fact that they have plenty of seating and reservations, and take payment in non cash forms  AND the FANTASTIC fresh fish and unusual rolls. Love this new find. I have only been there once and am writing this. Check it out. You won't be disappointed.
author: Penelope S.

description:
I loved this place! I came here for my birthday with a group of friends, and we ordered a ton of food. The service was friendly and quick, and the sushi was extremely fresh and creative. One of the rolls had mango slices on top, and another was filled with fried pumpkin. I believe that was one of their seasonal rolls. 

Ramen could have been better - the bowl was very pretty but the broth was only ok. It tasted similar to chicken broth with added salt. 

They also sell Bi-Rite ice cream for dessert, one of my favorite SF treasures!

The meal itself was a little pricey, but I'll definitely come back again!
author: D C.

description: Terrible service out of the gate (in the gate?).  We waited in the half empty room for 10 minutes on a week night without being acknowledged, staff just walking by again and again. When they finally did they told us it would be 20 minutes before they could seat us.  We left in search of more attentive fare. Thanks O-Toro, for not telling us right away, and making our two hours away from the kid that much shorter.
author: Colin S.

description:
Came here for lunch today and have to admit it was pretty solid. The 6pc rolls are moderately priced for sushi in sf, of which I got the negi Hama and spicy tuna. It's a slight shame the spicy tuna wasn't really spicy, and there was something oddly crunchy in my negi Hama. 

But the real star was the katsu donburi, which is great by my horrible SF standards where everything is expensive like nobody's business. But, on a cold windy day a nice hot donburi is the best you can ask for.

My recommendation: try the curry donburi when you're cold and looking for a hot fix.
author: David H.

description:
This is a review for the udon only. I did not have sushi so cannot comment. What I can say since I was sitting at the sushi bar is that it is certainly clean & the sushi chefs seemed to take care in the cutting of the fish.

Ok- on to the udon.  I got the chicken udon. It was the greasiest soup I've ever eaten. Literally. Greasier than canned chicken soup. The chicken did not taste like high quality. After 2-3 spoons of greasy broth & small bites of 3 different pieces of chicken (just trying to give it the benefit of the doubt) I mostly ate the noodles with chopsticks. Even after avoiding the broth as much as possible and not eating the chicken there is still a greasy coating of fat lingering into mouth 40 minutes later.  I asked and was told they boil the chicken in the broth with the fat & skin, which explains it.  The vegetarian udon might be better if you would want to try it. For me- when eating udon, I'm wanting a different experience.
author: N A.

description: My "go to" neighborhood sushi restaurant ! Inexpensive but super quality sushi + souzai (tapas). Even if you are not vegetarian you should try their eggplant sushi. It's to die for. And otoro / chutoro here are just amazing ! Don't forget to reserve before you go!
author: Takahiro K.

description: I have to say this place was a happy accident! My boyfriend and I had been in a pinch for time and in search for food near the Bill Graham and I'm sure glad we stumbled onto this. They were very accommodating with our rushed dinning needs and sat us right at the bar. Hands down some of the best Ahi Poke I have ever had with just enough heat to it. Along with their Black Cod so much so we ordered a second serving as dessert. Very casual with a modern feel. I loved it as a little date spot!
author: Hailey R.

description:
Had it not been for C, I never would have found this restaurant.  It's tucked away on Oak, a couple of streets down from the Hayes Street shops, restaurants and boutiques, nestled in a more residential area.

Immediately upon entering, I was impressed by the clean, modern, warm decor - rich brown tones, high ceilings, great lighting and large windows that let in the sunlight.  Almost immediately, a cup of steaming green tea appeared before me - I hadn't even seen the server drop it off!  Shortly after my girlfriend joined me, tea was set before her, along with two plastic wrapped hot towels for us to clean off our hands.  Really, really impressive service.

They ordered a ton of rolls and sashimi, which they remarked was very fresh and tasty.  I ordered a seaweed salad and grilled octopus with ginger, which came to the table sliced in pretty, thin rings.  For the price and quality, I definitely thought it was a great value!

Three girls who haven't seen each other in a month spend an inordinate amount of time catching up.  We were there for at least an hour after we had finished eating, and not once did they make us feel like we needed to leave.  No pointed fly-bys asking if we needed anything else, no slipping of the bill on the table before we asked for it.  Instead, they kept coming by to top off our teas so our drinks remained warm.

Fresh sushi and seafood, good portions, and EXCELLENT service!  That's my kind of restaurant!!
author: Janet L.

description: It's a small cozy place with amazing sushi . . . one of the best sushi restaurants I've ever been to. The fish is very fresh and simply amazingly tasty. The owner is a very friendly fun guy. I'll be going back here for sure, so should you!
author: Haleh H.

description:
Really great sushi place. Came by here for an early dinner. Greeted by a very friendly staff and did not have to wait long for a seat. 

We ended up ordering the otoro roll, caterpillar roll, and hirame sashimi (halibut). Everything tasting really good especially the otoro roll. It was the first time I had a roll wrapped in mango. Didn't think I would like it at first but ended up loving it. The mango added the perfect amount of sweetness to the roll. The hirame was also very good with the fish sauce that was provided.

Defintely give this place a try if you want some good sushi.
author: Ajay K.

description:
Sushi was good and not expensive however it wasn't memorable.  Due to the proxmity to a couple other really good sushi places, its hard to choose this over those (nobu (fancy), domo (yummy), and sushi raw (cheaper)).  With that being said, this place is still better than 77% of the sushi places in the city.  

Go early on weekends or you'll be waiting in line....
author: Eric A.

description:
O-Toro has become a monthly staple for me. I discovered the place while living in Hayes Valley, and continued to come here because it's close to work.

The sushi is fresh and expertly prepared. The katsu curry is the perfect asian comfort food when you're starving and in need of a hot meal. My only complaint is that the ramen could be better.

The service here is always excellent. Grab a seat at the bar and watch the itamae do his magic.
author: Cristofer P.

description:
OMG, where did this place come from?!  I work around there and have never noticed it and it never came up from my yelp search for sushi.  I discovered it from the Michellin's guide (totally spelled it wrong I bet, oh well).  I went to try it w/ my coworkers and OMG I am addicted.  Everything is great there.  My personal favorite is the Katsu Don.  One of the best ones I've had.  And if you like hamachi, oh MAN.  You've got to try to special nigiri, Seared Hamachi Belly.  Just eat it.  You'll know what I'm talking about.
I'm secretly hoping that not everyone will discover this place, that way it can still be accessible to me!  I love not having to wait for a table for lunch now a days.  But they are getting busier!
author: Lily Y.

description:
Delightful experience...after a few chef sashimi platters, multiple rolls, and sake perpetually flowing I had an ahhh-mazing Saturday evening.

Big highlights:
 - super fresh, melt in your mouth sashimi
 -innovative rolls 
 - intimate setting, seating 30-35 people
 - doesn't slack on decor and inflate prices- super modern chic
-quick, friendly service 

I really liked how they offered to fry our fish head off our sashimi platter...yum. 

Score in Hayes Valley! :D
author: Charlene A.

description:
It's a small Japanese restaurant (fits..30 max?)  run by Chinese.(at least I can overheard waitresses/waitors/sushi chefs are using cantonese to communicate.  

Came in @6pm for a early dinner.  Seated immediately.  There're another 3 parties there. (1 solo diner, 2 3-person parties)  We are a group of 4 and ordered 6 different things.

-Miso Ramen
Soup base is light, not much oil.  Noodle is okay, wish it's a bit more al-dente.  Meat, not much, typical 1 slice of boiled pork without much flavor.  Few bamboo shoot and spinach.  Wish they include half a boiled egg.

-Beef Soba
Pretty generous on beef.  Soup base is light but with good flavor.  Soba is average.

-Otoro Roll
Spicy tuna & mango goes well together.  

-Krappy Roll
Real crab meat with unagi.  Both goes well together.  Another surprise.

-Tora Karaage
Deep fried chicken.  Skin is included.  If you're health conscious, don't get it but if you like fatty food, you will be in heaven.

-Ika Maruyaki
Grill squid.  Plain and squid is reasonably fresh.  Unfortunately, my stomach doesn't like chewy stuff and starts complaining not long after. :(

We're asked to order couple times with 5 minutes apart.  The waitress asked nicely but could tell they want to get us out before peak hour starts.  I don't blame them as their space is very limited.  Anyhow we finished our meal before any line is formed.  Total bill: $56 + tips.

It's a decent place but I had better Japanese food somewhere else.  Worth a visit if you're in neighborhood as their price is reasonable with their quality and location.  BTW, parking is tough there...it's SF after all.
author: Penguin L.

description:
Came here for a mid-week lunch.  Decent sushi.  Broad menu consisting of noodles, cooked foods (chicken katsu was prepared quite nicely), rolls, nigiri, sashimi, various dons, etc.  Black sesame ice cream was yummy.  The chalkboard said the ice cream was from Bi-Rite, so how can you go wrong?  Decor was minimalist and clean.  Staff was friendly without being overbearing.

Plan to go back for dinner and have more sushi/sashimi, maybe sit at the counter, so might be able to change to five stars...
author: Isabel M.

description: I now have two awesome neighborhood sushi places. The first was Sushi Zone however this is my new favorite place because they take reservations and even when I don't have one, I don't have to wait 1.5 hours to get a table. This place has a small staff with very friendly service. And all of the sushi is delicious and fresh. I love that they have barracuda and sustainable blue fin tuna. If you like rolls go for the Lava Roll and the Otoro roll. They have an incredible appetizer of glazed black cod that just melts in your mouth. They also have a nice simple tempura ramen that is yummy and good if I'm looking for something simple and cheap. And their sake selection is wonderful. The Denshu is smooth with a little sweetness that balances the sushi perfectly. This will be go to sushi place from now on.
author: melanie k.

description:
Nice variety of hot dishes, cold dishes, and specials. We ended up ordering mostly from the sushi specials list, but included a few items off the regular menu as well. A unique feature of the menu were the "cold tapas" and "hot tapas," all which appeared to be carefully crafted.

It's easy to go a little overboard here and end up with a larger bill than you expected especially if you're knocking back sake. The specials are all great, but about $2 more than anything you would order off the regular menu.

FOOD: All of the sushi we ordered was fresh and well portioned, though a few pieces of nigiri were a little heavy on the wasabi. The walu sashimi was especially delicious.

SERVICE was good enough. From what we observed, sitting at the sushi bar might be the best experience.

ATMOSPHERE: Modern yet cozy. There were maybe 10-12 tables and 8-10 spots at the sushi bar. Pretty easy to get a table, but toward the end of our meal, they stopped seating walk-ins to get ready for a party of 10.

WILL WE COME BACK? Probably not unless we're already nearby. Every neighborhood seems to have at least one sushi place at this level, and there's no reason to make the extra trip.
author: Emily C.

description: overprice, sushi rice is not authentic & the seafood are not fresh. will not go back again.
author: Carol C.

description: I enthusiastically recommend visiting this quaint little sushi spot.  The food is great, atmosphere is casual, and service was fantastic.
author: Chris D.

description: Good tasting sushi, decent prices and a lot of specials of the day and fish flown in from Japan! Small seating. So not a group spot but 2-3 people max.  Good spot for an intimate sashimi sharing and a bottle of Saki.
author: Christopher K.

description:
We went here after reading the good reviews on yelp. We went on a Friday night at 7pm and the small place was busy, but we were seated right away.
Food:
Chicken Soba- big bowl of noodle soup with only 3 slices of chicken (no exaggeration). The flavor was good and I can't complain about their generous portion, however the lack of chicken was comical.

Lava Roll- decent, nothing special, but again, good portion size for roll sushi.

Ikura (salmon roe/egg)- here's where the whole experience took a dive. This was the first piece of sushi my wife bit into. She immediately spit it out into her napkin and said it tasted rancid. We quietly brought it to the attention of our waitress who took the remaining piece and called over the manager. My wife explained that it was rotten and the manager laughed a little and told her that they make their own Ikura and so it tastes a little different than other places. My wife then told him that this didn't taste "different", it tastes rancid, like the eggs are old/bad. The manager continued to say that they had just eaten those for lunch and they were fine, as if we were stupid and didn't know the difference between rotten/smelling sushi and fresh, non-vomit inducing sushi.
The manager finally volunteered to take it off our bill. The rest of the meal was pretty much ruined by this bad experience.
When we got our bill, they had not taken off the Ikura off our bill and we had to remind them.

There are plenty of good sushi places in the city and we will not be returning to this one.
author: Doug E.

description: I finally got around to checking out O-Toro.  I almost always go to Sushi Zone since it's closer to my place, but often it gets too crowded.  At O-Toro, my favorite piece was the sake belly aka seared hamachi.  I also had the sake (salmon), unagi and shiro maguro.  The rest were pretty good, but the pieces aren't super huge.  A good solid sushi spot...
author: Gene X.

description: It was just ok...meal wasn't horrible nore fantastic. I didn't like that I had either ginger or fish egg for salad dressing (just nasty). Also, a little pricey.
author: Nneka G.

description:
This is a very elegant and welcoming place; the entire staff is polite and friendly, and every roll we had (8 in all) was delicious.  My particular favorite was the negi roll, which is made with delicate slices of kiwi fruit.  Dipped in soy sauce & wasabi, the sweet and salty taste is delightful!  

It didn't start to get busy in this small place until after 7:00 p.m., so my early-dining group had ample time to talk and enjoy our food.  After dinner, the staff presented us with a gift in honor of Otoro's 1 year anniversary; a pair of chopsticks in a wooden case.  I wish I could become a regular here!
author: Meridith H.

description: Good find!  It's not that pricey, original rolls, and lots of variations for people who just don't want sushi.  I'm putting this at par with Tataki and Kiji (local vibe in Noe).  Definitely a solid choice and interesting grub.
author: A A.

description: This is a smaller place, but they have pretty good quality fresh fish. Also had the miso ramen and a few of the rolls before. The grilled saba and nigiris are all delicious. If anything, this place will be consistent. I've liked everything I've gotten here before (uni, hotate, kampachi, hamachi, among others) but it lacks the IT factor to push it to 5 stars. With that said, I've come back here a few times so this place is definitely a safe bet if you want some good Japanese. Comfortable, clean, decent food and service.
author: Antoinette S.

description:
Very disappointing dining experience--had to walk out of the restaurant without even eating!

Had a performance to go to at 8pm at the Opera House on Saturday night.  Called at 6 pm and was told that they didn't accept reservation and we had to be physically present and sign up in order to be in the line.   Arrived at the restaurant at 6:20 and found that the restaurant was tiny and was packed.  There was no host and no place to sign in.  Had to excuse 6 people to get to the bar and waited there for 10 mins and still no one came to acknowledge us.  Finally someone came and put down our names and told us the wait was 20 mins.   At 7pm, finally got seated at the bar thanks to some people had to leave without eating because they were out of time.  Ordered some simple rolls and waited until 7:20pm - still no food was presented.  Talked to the waitress and she promised that the food would be ready in 5 mins.  Waited until 7:30pm and saw the sushi chef had not even started to make our rolls.  We finally decided to leave with an empty stomach so that we wouldn't miss our show.  No apologies received whatsoever!

We wasted 1.5 hours in total and did not even get to eat our food.  Is that the kind of dining experience this restaurant is striving to offer?!  Is this the kind of "authentic" Japanese service this restaurant is trying to provide?!  

Our overall impression is that this restaurant is extremely arrogant probably because it was having a busy night.  Well, if you don't mind putting up with their attitude, then don't hesitate to give them a try.
author: G C.

description:
This place is great. The fish is fresh and the rolls are very neat and tasty. I like that they don't oversauce them.

The waiter was very friendly and since the place is small, it's pretty easy to catch his attention. I like my rolls on the raw fish-heavy side, so I liked the Cherry Blossom a lot. The hot tea is good too.
author: Abbey S.

description: The food was pretty good, but a little overpriced for what you can get at most sushi joints. I think by virtue of the neighborhood, they were able to charge a bit more. I enjoyed the food and sake selections as well as the convenience to the opera hall. However, I don't think I would come back just due to the overall value. The restaurant is also quite small and crowded. The service was okay... maybe a little on the slow side. We had to wait quite a while for our check and, considering how many people were smushed together (right next to our table) waiting for a seat, you'd think they would want to turn tables over faster.
author: Becky H.

description:
O Toro turned out to be a nice little surprise in my backyard. No, seriously, I live like three blocks away, my work place is farther than this restaurant. Works out great for me as now I have a decent sushi place that's within walking distance whenever I feel the need.

Despite being in the border area that separates the gentrified part of Hayes Valley from the slightly scuzzy area near Civic Center/City Hall, O Toro is a nice, fancy little upscale sushi place, complete with the dim lights, wall of expensive sake, and wine glass candles. It's the kind of place you'd go on a dinner date to try and impress a lady - first since it's near a hip little neighborhood, second because it's Japanese, and third because it's classy. Joking aside, I loved the intimate atmosphere of the place, and I definitely felt a bit underdressed coming here in a t-shirt and jeans (my girlfriend and I were going to a concert at the Great American Music Hall right after, so... yeah).

Food-wise the menu isn't terribly extensive. The main focus is the sushi, and they have all the types whether you want just a mix of tekka maki and California rolls, a hand roll, or just some nice big pieces of fatty tuna. Most of the entrees are the usual Japanese staples like donburi, ramen, udon/soba, etc. I liked what I had - soba with a Krabby roll - and I'm eager to try some of their other items. The price isn't exorbitant, but it's not cheap either.

Also, you definitely don't want to come here with a group of five or more, since it is an extremely tiny joint, as most sushi bars are. There are maybe seven or eight tables seating about four people each, though when I went most were occupied by couples. It's not bad if you eat early (like around five), but it fills up fast.

The staff was nice, specifically the one guy greeting all the customers and seating everyone. Very quiet, but efficient and quick. Though it did kind of strike me that, even though it's a small place, no ever came around to give us refills on water or ask for dessert or anything, and it took a lot longer than necessary to get the check despite the fact we were just sitting there at a near-empty table for a good 15 minutes. Yeah, don't mind us, we're just here taking up space, guys.

Overall though I really did enjoy O Toro. I might start getting take-out from here (I saw a lot of others doing this) since the price is decent and the food is good. If you're in the neighborhood and want to try out a good sushi bar, O Toro is a good place to start - and end.
author: Will C.

description: The food was good was a but little pricier than places I've been in the city with similar quality.  I would probably go there again if I was in the neighborhood.
author: Nirea S.

description:
Otoro is my go-to work sushi spot. I really like it. 

Their sushi is as good as their hot food. I usually get some nigiri, a simple roll and some sashimi. 

For hot food, their katsu curry is super filling and comforting. It's great on a cold day. 

No complaints - if you're in the area and jonesing for sushi, I recommend Otoro for sure.
author: Alli J.

description:
I went there on a random weekday. Looking for a place to eat dinner with my fiancé, we found O-Toro. Yes, we were the first one so it was good. 

We ordered:

Appetizers/ Tapas:
Tempura - Really good. Soft & crispy
Pork Belly - a sweet stew type. I didn't eat it, but my fiancé loved it! He wanted to eat it with rice.
Chicken Skin - 2 small skewers - I guess that's what you call Tapas

Special Rolls:
O-Toro - The mango on top made it taste so good with the tuna! - Rolls kind of small
Rainbow - It was just ok but the fish was fresh! - Rolls kind of small

Main Dish:
Katsu Don - it was Ok, like any other Japanese Don type

Drinks:
Silver Sake Sampler - I guess it was ok, having 3 small glasses to sample. I think it was a bit pricy but hey I got to taste 3 different sake. 

Dessert
Black sesame ice cream - Good but not a wow factor.

Service was friendly and attentive or maybe we were just the first customers and the only people there at the time. But either way, I enjoyed myself... A bit pricey and small but I will still go back.
author: Nokie N.

description:
Ok, brace yourself 'cuz I'm going there:  Otoro is the BEST SUSHI in the city.  Done.

I know that's a controversial statement but I stand by it.  The fish is super fresh, high quality and like butter.  The menu is creative, tasty, and satisfying.  The sake selection is respectable.  

Start with the off-the-menu-in-the-know lychee mojitoes.  A must.  I've had the Hawaiian Poki and the Saba Miso for apps and I almost cried, both were so good.  Then, when you're ready for it (and not a second sooner), order the Lava Roll.  Its got a kick...and its amazing.

The place itself is decorated nicely and totally appropriate for a date, an out-of-town visitor, a bday party w/ friends, a "must have sushi or I will die" night for dinner, and more...
author: Susan L.

description: I'm in love with this sushi place.  My favorites are the baked mussels, uni, ocean trout, butter fish, yellow tail and ikura.  Their sushi is fresh and melts in your mouth.  I usually also get miso ramen with my meal, which is a light and tasty accompaniment to any sushi meal.  The garlic soft shell crab comes deep fried and is delightful.  Also try the glazed black cod.  It's incredibly flavorful.  They also have black sesame ice cream, which is the perfect blend of sweet and savory.  Get a reservation if you come on a Saturday night.
author: Irenka P.

description:
This place is pretty good.  There's nothign that really sets it apart tremendously from most others but it's definitely a good meal.

warning: do not accept the table by the door when it's cold.  It's a miserable experience.
author: D D.

description:
Food = 4 Stars
Service = 2 Stars

Came here with my boyfriend because it's an easy sushi place to walk to from muni.  We ordered hirame and hamachi sashimi, the cherry blossom roll, and a krabby roll.   Everything was great.  The hamachi was really fresh, and the krabby rolls were surprisingly great.  The interior is nice, it's dark and dimly lit.  It's small, but it seemed slightly more spacious than the average sushi bar.  

Overall I liked this place a lot minus the service.  My boyfriend and I stood at the door for probably 10 minutes before we were greeted.  The host didn't acknowledge us at all - not even a "I'll be with you in a minute."  After we were seated and had our order he never came back to check if we needed more tea or water, and he took forever with the check.  I felt bad for the waiter, he seemed to be by himself so it wasn't all his fault that he couldn't give better service, but they obviously need to hire more staff because the one person hosting and waiting tables is not working out.  During the time we were there, this place lost 2 groups of customers because they were tired of waiting to be greeted/seated.  Regardless, I would go back because the food was great!
author: S. F.

description: O-Toro Sushi is great! The sashimi they serve is very fresh and the sushi is top of the line. I loved the ramen, pork belly, and kalbi! I would definitely recommend this to any sushi-goer out in the bay area.
author: Brendan L.

description:
Yes, this place is right down the street from me and I walk by it at least once a day (usually in the morning when it's closed).  In all honesty, I've only been there once (many months ago), and I had good intentions of writing a review right away, but alas...

Anyway, I think this is a probably one of the better sushi joints in the city.  The fish is super fresh, the service is quick and friendly.  The ambiance is nice...but it does tend to get a little crowded, so you may have to bug a fellow diner to allow you squeeze your way out.

I will be back, Otoro! I promise!
author: Evelyn K.

description:
I friend told me about this restaurant, so I thought I'd give it a try. First off I called
around 7:15 in the evening and asked if I need a resurvation for one, the door man
said if I get there before 8:00PM no problem seating me, I got a glass of wine while 
waiting and 6 pairs of couples were seated be for they got to me, people came and
got seated at the bar finally 45mins. later the seated me at a two top near the door,
I felt like some kind of cast off the food I had was ok not any extra special. I was also
told on another occasion when I came in early, the I needed to call at 4:00 the day of 
to get a seat for one at 8:00pm that night! That was my clue that this restaurant
does not prefer or accommodate singles at all! So doubtless I will never go back!!!
author: Brian Michael S.

description: This is my go-to spot for dinner before the symphony or ballet. The food is delicious, there are many interesting options besides sushi, and the service excellent. They make a special vegetarian agedashi tofu for me which I also appreciate.
author: Laurel E.

description:
I guess you could say Otoro Sushi and I got off on the wrong foot.  You see, I was a big fan of Laurel's Cuban restaurant...so when they closed and Otoro came in it's place, it had some very strong and much loved mojito glasses to fill.

After months of walking by Otoro and saying to my boyfriend halfheartedly "oh we should go there sometime" to which he would unfailingly respond by staring longingly into the distance, no doubt reminiscing about fried plantains with garlic butter, we finally went.  We were greeted with a half hour wait.  Really?  Half an hour for mediocre sushi in the middle of a residential block?  Am I missing something?  Because last time I checked there were three thousand over-priced sushi restaurants in this city and the blogosphere didn't give a shit about a single one of them.   That's why people go to restaurants, right? Blogs?

Anyway...the food came out sushi rolls first, edamame and gyoza last (WHAT?) and we just decidided to cancel the miso soup because it would have gotten there after dessert.  

The stars are for the service, which was pretty good.  Fine, I'll give them that.

Basically what I'm trying to say is that you need to just walk the couple extra blocks to Sushi Zone or if waiting isn't your thang then Sushi Delight by The Mint (karaoke, not federal).
author: m a r l a s.

description:
I was going to go to Domo a few blocks down, but I waked by Otoro and looked at their menu and decided it was a done deal.

SUPER cheap for the quality of their sashimi. 5 pieces of delicious albacore tuna for $8.95? pretty good deal if you're a sushi snob like myself.

Got the Otoro roll with spicy tuna and mango...very delicious, not too spicy.

Also got the Cherry Blossom roll, delicious as well. 

The waitress was really sweet and brought us miso soup and edamame about 3 seconds after we asked for it. The atmosphere was intimate and relaxing. All in all, a new favorite sushi spot.
author: Hannah L.

description:
Surprisingly we didn't have to wait for a table on a Friday night.  I thought it was pretty good.  I would have gave it 5 stars if the portions were a little bigger or if the prices was a little cheaper.

I would definitely go there again if I come back to SF.
author: Kyle N.

description:
Yum!

Walked in on Valentine's Day around 8:30pm with no reservation and they seated us within 10 minutes. Awesome. This place is tiny so I would recommend a reservation on a weekend night if you have a specific time in mind. I know for next time.

The food was delish. BF and I are vegetarian and they had several options for us. Everything was great, including the prices.
author: J D.

description:
I love sushi, no seriously I could eat it for every meal if I wasn't afraid of getting mercury poisoning, so I've tried a good number of the sushi places in the city.  O-Toro is my current favorite.  I love the Tako Poki, you get large chunks of tako and the poki sauce is really flavorful.  I am very impressed with their fish selection and the quality of their fish

The service is usually really good, but it can get really crowded.  I'm also not sure what was going on the last time I was there but it is really cold and I wasn't sitting anywhere near the door.
author: Katherine S.

description:
Yummy! Very fresh fish in a great neighborhood. I recommend the hip 
hop roll and shrimp dumplings. Can't wait to go back.
author: Zoe B.

description: Truly one of the best Sushi restaurants in SF.  Expect to pay more.  Expect to wait longer.  Expect it to be worth it.
author: Nobody M.

description: Great smaller sushi spot with a solid and static line up of rolls... if you dont have a reservation, be prepared to wait for something to open up; they will usually try and work with you with a smaller party though. Because of it's smaller size, one large party will make it LOUD fast. Love this place. Check it out with your sig other.
author: David B.

description: The rolls were lacking in flavor, and the walu was still a little frozen when it came out. The kalbi was tasty, but would benefit from better quality meat.
author: Jamila A.

description: This place was just ok to me.  My husband and I came on a weeknight for dinner without reservations.  The wait wasn't very long.  Cute and intimate place, but the service left much to be desired.  We waited at least 10 minutes before anyone even came over to give us a glass of water or take our drink order.  Then it took another 10 minutes for someone to take our food order.  Meanwhile the two staff that were there were chatting up regular customers.  We ordered a variety of sushi rolls that were pretty standard and not unique in the slightest.  Sigh.
author: Julie P.

description:
I love sushi.  I mean I love quality sushi.  Therefore, I love Otoro Sushi.

Beside sushi the food there was great.  Owner and waitress are super friendly.  Place is quite hip and in a nice area.

Highly recommended!!
author: Kelvin C.

description:
Seating is limited, so make a reservation or come early to avoid a wait. That being said, at no point during the evening did O-Toro feel crowded. As it filled up, I wasn't crammed in and I wasn't forced to listen in on our neighbors' conversations. It was the perfect spot for a small group of family and friends to catch up.

Service is attentive and informed, menu is great, including the sake menu, and the quality was superb. Don't miss the specials on the chalkboard!
author: Anna R.

description:
The good:

1) Prompt, friendly service!  We showed up with no reservation on Saturday night with 5 people, and the host managed to get us all space at the bar.  We had an order in quickly, it was easy to get our server's attention, and the check was handled without delay.

2) Fresh, tasty, interesting sushi.  Try the special nigiri orders.  The spicy scallops were unique and delicious -- diced scallop in a spicy mayo sauce, served over seaweed-wrapped rice.  Also make sure to get the seared hamachi belly if they have it.  Lightly torched, and topped with sauce and tobiko.  And it was all delivered quickly.  The tuna was very fresh, and the salmon had a buttery texture that is rare to find.

3) The sake selection wasn't huge, but it had some good picks on it.  The small bottle we ordered tasted exactly like the description in the menu.  How often does that happen?

The bad:

1) Nigiri orders came with 2 pieces.  We had 3 people splitting nigiri.  Many sushi restaurants will let you get orders of 3 pieces, obviously scaling price as appropriate.  Not so here.  This left us having to split unevenly.  Meh.

2) For $40, I'd expect to eat more, even when we're talking about sushi.

I'll probably return, but more to try the non-sushi plates.
author: Jay M.

description:
Let me start off by saying that the food here is excellent.  I ordered many different types of sushi and the pork belly appetizer.

The only problem I had was the fact that I'd made a reservation for 2 at 8:30pm, and when I arrived at 8:25pm, it took 5 minutes to finally be acknowledged by the host. Granted, it was busy, but when I finally told him that I had a reservation for 8:30pm, he told me that it would be a while before I could be seated. I then asked him if it was customary for reservations to be ignored, and he said no, that they are typically honored. 

About 5 minutes later, a table opened up and, to my surprise, he sat another couple that was waiting before I'd gotten there. I don't know for sure if they had a reservation, too, but I doubt it because I think the host would've said so when I told him of my reservation.  

Anyway, I was optimistic and hoped that another table would open up soon, but after waiting another 10 minutes, I realized that my making a reservation didn't make any difference. It was ignored and I was being treated as a walk-in customer.

One of the things that also irked me was I noticed the couple that sat before us had drinks while waiting, and the host never offered us drinks despite the fact that we were the only ones waiting and we'd been waiting almost 20 minutes. I finally asked him if we could get a drink menu and he handed us one to share. He was very polite, but I was already upset at that point. When two seats opened up at the sushi bar, he asked us if that would be ok, and I accepted because I was tired of waiting. It was 8:55pm.

Again, the food was excellent, and my girlfriend and I had a great time, but I did walk away thinking that the night could've gone a lot smoother if they had honored my reservation and if the service had been better.
author: Marion L.

description:
Strengths: All the sashimi were fresh and rolls were well put together.  Portions were adequate, and rice to fish proportions were balanced.  Baked mussels were the highlight of the meal; the fresh scallop and butterfish sashimi were a close second and third.  Host/server's was superb.

Weaknesses:  There isn't much waiting area, so if you need to wait for a table, head over to Sauce's bar.  

Opportunities:  Skewers can use a bit more marinade and a little longer on the grill for more crispiness.  Ramen can be less sweet with a couple more toppings like egg and corn.

Threats:  If you live around hear, there is nothing close to Otoro in terms of atmosphere, food, and service.  If you can venture outside of Hayes Valley, try Blowfish and Okina.

Total:  $140 for 2 ppl.
author: Jenny K.

description: Loved it. Sushi was really perfect. Recommend the Hip Hop, Golden State, and Lava roll. Small place which was nice but I image it can fill up fast.
author: Juan K.

description:
We wanted Domo, but friends wanted something other than rolls, which O-Toro had.  

Everything was delicious.  We all had various rolls which were delicious as was the edamame.  

Very small space but great wait staff.

Definitely recommended for quality sushi.
author: Kate M.

description: Good fresh fish, decently priced.  Average to small sized rolls.
author: Kim K.

description: Yum!!!  Small cute restaurant- the owner is super friendly, the sushi is fresh.  I liked it!
author: Laleh J.

description: I was looking for a dinner spot that opened fairly early and was close to bill graham civic auditorium and found O-toro due to great yelps! We had a reservation for 4 but our friends bailed and the folks at O-toro were very cool about the change even though it was Saturday night, they put us at the sushi bar which was great! Staff were friendly and helpful, smiley and funny!! We had fatty tuna (OMG awesome) some uni, a couple of rolls ( the names are eluding me) and everything was spot on! Fresh, clean, delicious and not terribly expensive! The 2 of us got out of there for $80 including some pre- phish show drinks. Loved it would definitely return! Thanks O-toro for making our bellies so happy so we could dance all night!!
author: Michelle O.

description: Very fresh fish. Friendly service. Nice small, cozy space in convenient location. What's not to like? Oh, yeah, the prices aren't cheap but I'd say pretty good value for what you get.
author: Jim B.

description: I can't say enough about how good the sushi, sashimi, noodles, or the service are! Highly recommended. Very hospitable :)
author: Mark S.

description:
The service was good. She was able to recommend sakes to our tastes. Polite but not extremely friendly. Once we finished a dish, it would be taken away. 

We went in at 8:20 and finished and left around 8:55pm sharp since they implemented last call at 8:40 or so. Felt rushed and for the money the O-toro didn't really taste the best. I've worked in a couple of Japanese restaurants and have also tasted my way around at least half of San Francisco Japanese restaurants. If I'm paying a premium for Otoro, it should be top notch in terms of freshness.
author: Wanster L.

description: Definitely our favorite Japanese restaurant in the city. The food is wonderful, as is the ambiance and the staff. The fish is fresh and delicious, miso soup always reviving. A nice selection of Sake as well as traditional beer. Not to mention Jimmy, the owner, always greets us with a warm smile.
author: Mick C.

description: Came here with my boyfriend and it was Amazing. Great service, great sake selection. Try the Otoro, the potstickers, and have some bi- rite ice cream for dessert!  It would be wise to get a reservation though, it is pretty tiny and gets packed pretty quick.
author: Susan T.

description:
You had me at your ika with shiso.  Oh god.  Just thinking of what you did to that piece of squid, tucked under a leaf of shiso and cradling a small symbolic strip of seaweed to add more crunch to the chew and the crunch and the chew.  

This restaurant is situated such that it's right where my two buses converge.  It's where I transfer from the 21 to the 47.  And on one afternoon, I got off work early enough to grab a snack (my poor BF, he made some dinner that ended badly and no one wanted to eat it).  A snack means a miso soup, 1 order of aji, 1 order of ika, 1 order of kampachi.  It was less than $20.  

While the ika was the best because of the shiso, the rest of the fish was not as...fragrant.  I have this theory that when fish is first caught, it has the scent of flowers.  Some wild, floral scent that fades as the fish is transported from fisherman to merchant to chef.  After too much time, it develops the "fishy" smell.  But somewhere in between, there's also a non-smell.  The fish here did not have any hint of the bad fishy smell.  But it was not as fragrant as some fish that I've experienced.  I want it to have noses of flowers.

No, I do not grind up fish paste and snort it, you sick chuck.  

Some fish just have a fragrance.
author: Christina C.

description: The food here was pretty subpar given the outstanding reviews.  The fish was not particularly flavorful or innovative.  It was expensive for the quality.  I would stick with some of the other places in the area -- like Domo or Sebo.
author: Sue N.

description:
It's great sashimi, very fresh. On the pricier side. The rolls were good but nothing creative and nothing especially stood out.

We ordered the salmon, hamachi, amberjack sashimi and then had the spider, hamachi green onion, krabby rolls.

The scallop warm appetizer was a little too much mayo going on.  Nothing compares to sushi zone.
author: Amy S.

description: great selection of fresh fish. overall, excellent food. only knock on it is that we had to wait for about 30 minutes past our reservation, but the place is tiny so that's somewhat understandable.
author: Cam M.

description:
4.5 stars!!!  

The sushi was soooo good!!!  Fresh fish, good portions, decent prices for the quality, nice waitress, great atmosphere... What more could you ask for?!

Ok, the parking could be a bit better and the wait at such a small restaurant could be horrendous (hence the -0.5 star), but don't let that keep you from trying this place!
author: Celia L.

description:
Thus far, this is my favorite sushi place in the city.  Started off with the tori karaage and agedashi tofu and both were delicious.  I generally prefer to have a sauce go with the karaage but a squeeze of the lemon wedge was yum too.  For rolls. we ordered the krabby roll and spider roll, which were both also really good.  But the best part of the meal was the sashimi.  We had ordered tuna and salmon sashimi and oh my goodness were they amazing.  They tasted like butter and melted in your mouth.  I'm itching to go again soon!

Prices are good.  It's a small but really cute restaurant.  Lots of bars and dessert places nearby so it's perfect for a date!
author: Jessica W.

description:
I completely missed this place the first time I walked by it but I met up with some friends here for a delightful meal!  The first thing that strikes you when you enter the restaurant is the sleek, earth-toned decor. It's very intimate and makes for a nice casual dining experience.

We started with orders of gyoza (perfectly steamed and pan-seared) and agedashi tofu drizzled in a sweet and salty dashi sauce.  We shared the spicy tuna roll, spider roll, shrimp tempura roll, and the otoro. Everything was delicious and I would definitely order again, especially because I'm a sucker for spicy tuna and soft-shell crab.  The price was completely reasonable for the amount of food we had. Will definitely come back soon!
author: Ben T.

description:
My husband and I got hooked on Otoro when we lived in Hayes Valley.  The fish is always fresh, the owner (Jimmy) is awesome and has good recommendations, and the prices are reasonable given the quality.  

Even though we live in Noe Valley now and there are plenty of sushi places to choose from in the city, we still visit Jimmy and/or pick up take-out a couple times a month.  We usually order some nigiri, edamame, and a roll or two.  You can't go wrong with the usual nigiri - toro, sake, hamachi - but my new staple is walu (butterfish).  When we don't know what to get or want to try something new, we ask Jimmy what's fresh and what he recommends.  He has never led us astray.  Once he recommended a special roll they were featuring with pumpkin in it.  We were skeptical, but it was amazing!  

If you're looking for good quality, fresh fish, there are many places you can try in SF.  But if you're looking for all of that and good company, visit Jimmy at Otoro and you won't be disappointed.  If you go on a Friday or Saturday night, be prepared to wait for a bit since the place is small and gets busy at peak times.
author: Johanna C.

description:
Fresh fish, some interesting variety, and super friendly service. I've only tried the rolls, but the rest of the menu items look good as well. 

Prices are decent, and like most sushi places, portion sizes are somewhat small, but nothing you wouldn't expect.

Bonus points for being one of the only places in Hayes Valley that's open until 10 during the week.
author: U K.

description: Excellent service. The owner gives his personal service to everyone. Tiny place though snd expect a wait even with reservation. What I liked best was the Sake. The sushi is good like in any other 4 star Japanese restaurant.
author: Anand V.

description: specials board.  otoro was $12.  good but not the best cleanest taste.  same with the flying fish.  ahi poke sauce not very special, more red pepper.  hamachi truffle oil ok.  karaage batter good but a little dry.  while you may see a michelin recommended sticker, I don't agree.  much better to go to Ino, Kiss, Kabuto, Koo, Eiji, etc.
author: Rob C.

description:
Intimate, cute (love the blue stripe bathroom tiles) little place in my new fav neighborhood of the moment, Hayes Valley. 
Loved, LOVED the roll with the lemon in it (crab + salmon). Perfect medley of flavors.  All the fish was fresh, melt in your mouth deliciousness.  The Albacore sashimi with garlic was also heavenly. No boring sushi here.
I would eat at this place everyday and I just may.
author: Kelley D.

description:
Question: 
How many sushi joints can one neighborhood tolerate? 

Answer: 
An unlimited amount if they all offer something unique. I could eat sushi 7 days a week if my budget allowed it. As it is, I'm relegated to 4 or 5X a month so I need to be picky about where I go. 

I'm not sure that Otoro will make my short list, but they are doing fairly well. 

- Service- 5 stars! The service is the one thing about Otoro that stands out from the other places in the hood. 

- Edamame- 2 1/2 stars Served cold, not the way I prefer it 

- Nigiri- 5 stars Very good and reasonably priced- next time I'll try the Shiromaguro sans garlic though.

- Specialty Rolls- 2 stars We had the Otoro Roll. A specialty roll shouldn't cost $13 in my opinion. I was disappointed that rather than being filled with a beautiful slab of otoro, it was chopped instead. I can't remember if this was mentioned on the menu. 

- Less expensive rolls- 3 1/2 stars The spicy tuna and the Hawaiian where both tasty (the tuna was again chopped up, but I think this is fairly common for a spicy tuna roll) 

- Sake- 5 stars Great selection, reasonably price 

- Acoustics- 0 stars Just plain sucked. Way too loud. I know that tapestries probably don't fit in with the minimalist vibe this restaurant is trying to present, but they need more fabrics in there to absorb the sound. B/F knocked on the wall and mentioned something about concrete vs. sheet rock, it all went over my head, but in a nutshell, whatever the deal is with those walls, the sound just bounces all over the room. We had to shout to hear each other.
author: Michelle D.

description: Great rolls, quality fish, and good service. Glad O-Toro is in my neighborhood - will definitely become a frequent flyer here.
author: Stephen H.

description:
I am a regular. It's the best sushi at this price point. What I mean is it's not the best in San Francisco, but it's very close and it's reasonably priced. It's a mystery to me why this restaurant doesn't receive more praise, and my saying all this will only make it more crowded.

The fish is fresh and the selection very impressive. Some items from Japan. Other items live -- great presentation of the spiny shell of the uni (sea urchin). All of it surprising for a place that is not at the highest level of cost. For example, ankimo appears on the menu regularly. That is unusual.

Also nice small dishes. Standard items such as tempura are done at the best quality. Numerous specials. The pork is fabulous, especially with the mustard. 

The sake list is lengthy too.

Attentive service. A little loud. 

Very convenient to Davies Hall and other cultural institutions.

To sum up, I have two favorite Japanese restaurants in San Francisco. Koo and O-Toro. (Yes, I know there are others that receive greater acclaim. But I am sensitive about how much I spend. Those places are good. They just don't deserve the premium.)
author: Frank W.

description:
I cannot write enough good things about Otoro or say enough thank yous to Jimmy (the owner) and all of the staff. They took AMAZING care of me + my 12 friends for my birthday dinner on Friday.  As a self-proclaimed sushi smarty-pants, coupled with the heightened importance of the meal, they were up against a tough battle to earn my yelp stars.  But they easily deserve 5 stars and then some!  The service was impeccable (which is difficult when dealing with a large, rowdy-ish crowd).  The fish was super fresh, delicious, plentiful, and well-priced. They kindly did a sake tasting for my group and even comped extra bottles of sake.  Without anyone in my party saying a word, at the end of the meal, the lights in the restaurant went out and Jimmy led the entire restaurant in a birthday serenade as he delivered a complimentary mochi birthday cake.

Even if it's not your birthday:
- you will love the sake flights (I don't think the other Hayes Valley sushi spots offer this) 
- you will be impressed with the quality of the fish
- you will be well taken care of

I live just down the street, so I think I may have found my new "regular" sushi place:) Thank you, Jimmy & Co.! :)
author: Geri-Ayn G.

description:
I've driven by Otoro multiple times and have been hoping to find just the right occasion to give you a try.  Survey says: Mmmm... I'm a fan!  

I came here with my bff for the first time tonight for one of our routine "let's get sushi" dinner outings [translation: let's platonically dine on our favorite cuisine while we catch up on each others lives, exchange stories + share advice].

Let's start with the decor.  Otoro is the new kid on the block in the Hayes Valley 'hood and with the low lighting and dark masculine wood touches, it fits right in among its other hip neighborhood dining establishment counterparts.

My dining partner and I were feeling adventurous and decided to order the kampachi, hirame + uni sushi and indulged in the Hip Hop + Golden Gate rolls.  Yum!!  Everything was so fresh + flavorful + oh-so-artfully plated, I was sincerely impressed!

The service was very attentive and our waitress was uber cute, telling me where I could pick up the navy blouse that I complimented her on.

The price is reasonable and if you swing by for dinner relatively early on a Sunday [7ish?] then you shouldn't find street parking to be a terrible pain.  Hoping to come back again soon!
author: Katie C.

description:
My friend brought me here for dinner as I was craving sushi.  When we walked in, I immediately liked the decor and atmosphere, but I will say the space is really small.  We walked in with no reservations and were quite lucky enough to be seated quickly.  

We only ordered sushi and did not venture into the other dishes, so I will say this review is strictly about the sushi.

The starter we had was tako (Hawaiian) poke, and it didn't really come out as poke.  The first thing I noticed was that it was missing spice, secondly it was covered with onions, and it was drenched in a soy based sauce.  I'm not sure what this was, but poke it was not.  The tako wasn't that fresh, as it had been resting long enough that it was chewy.

The next not so great bit was the maguro sashimi.  It had the right colors, but it was slightly off.  

The rest of the food was fresh and delicious.  Lorelei, Golden State, negi hama, aji, and o-toro.  Their rolls are a little different, but mix components that make them interesting and new.  For instance, the Golden State roll as thin slices of lemon on top of them which make them very citrusy; the lorelei comes with macadamia nuts sprinkled on top.  The aji and o-toro nigiri were delectable and slightly butter in taste from the fats in the fish.  

The service was amazing.  Out waitress in particular was great.  I would go back just to see here.  She even brought me some gelato for my birthday.  I think the staff is very attentive and pays attention to detail, so they have that nailed down.

Oh, and the sake which we ordered.  I found it very interesting how they poured it for us.  First the glasses were set in a little box container of sorts.  Then the sake was poured into the glass until it overflowed into the box.  I suppose that means you get your money's worth, but it's sad to see the little bit of sake spill over and not get drank.

I would certainly come back here, but it may be worth calling in a reservation just in case.
author: Brent A.

description: Meh not great but not horrible. Overall a little pricey for what you get. Not everything seemed fresh or was fresh but was still sort of too cold (almost half frozen it tasted like sometimes) I think the decor and location of this place are pretty good though and the service is very kind as well.  I think if you had a small group of friends, in the area and just wanted to snack on something light, this place would be the place to do such that.
author: Greg G.

description:
My friend made a reservation for a little bit later on a Saturday, and we still waited over an hour, in a tiny restaurant that really has no real waiting area. Luckily they let us order drinks and edamame while we waited, otherwise we might have just walked out. (It really didn't help that this middle aged couple was making out in the corner - really, who does that?!)

I rarely consider threatening a bad Yelp review, but with how long our wait was I almost did. They must have read my mind because they sent over two comped desserts, turning a 1 star review into a 4 star review.
